Creon puts his case with lucidity and force. We are remindedComparison with Plato's Crito. of that dialogue in which Plato represents Socrates, on the eve of execution, as visited in prison by his aged friend Crito, who comes to tell him that the means of escape have been provided, and to urge that he should use them. Socrates imagines the Laws of Athens remonstrating with him: â€˜Do you imagine that a State can subsist, in which the decisions of law are set aside by individuals?â€™ And to the plea that â€˜unjustâ€™ decisions may be disobeyed, the Laws rejoin,â€”â€˜Was that our agreement with you? Or were you to abide by the sentence of the State?â€™ When Antigone appeals to the laws of Hades (v. 451), might not Creon's laws, then, say to her what the laws of Athens say with regard to the hypothetical flight of Socrates:â€”â€˜We shall be angry with you while you live, and our brethren, the Laws in the world below, will receive you as an enemy; for they will know that you have done your best to destroy usâ€™?

Plato, it has been truly said, never intended to answer the question of casuistry, as to when, if ever, it is right to break the city's law. But at least there is one broad difference between the cases supposed in the Crito and the Antigone. Antigone had a positive religious duty, about which there was no doubt at all, and with which Creon's law conflicted. For Socrates to break prison might be justifiable, but could not be described as a positive religious duty; since, however much good he might feel confident of effecting by preserving his life, he was at least morally entitled to think that such good would be less than the evil of the example. Creon is doing what, in the case of Socrates, Athens did not do,â€”he is invading the acknowledged province of religion. Not that he forgets the existence of the gods: he reveres them in what he believes to be the orthodox waySee especially the note on 1044.. But he assumes that under no imaginable circumstances can the gods disapprove of penalties inflicted on a disloyal citizen. Meanwhile his characteristic tendency â€˜to do everything too muchâ€™ has led him into a step which renders this assumption disastrous. He punishes Polyneices in a manner which violates religion.

In Antigone, again, Creon's attitude towards Antigonehe sees anarchy personified, since, having disobeyed, she seems to glory therein (v. 482). Her defence is unmeaning to him, for her thoughts move in a different region from his own. Sophocles has brought this out with admirable skill in a short dialogue between Creon and Antigone (508-525): we see that he cannot get beyond his principle of State rewards and punishments; she is speaking foolishness to himâ€” as, indeed, from the first she had felt the hopelessness of their understanding each other (469 f., 499 f.). As this dialogue serves to show Creon's unconsciousness of the frontier between divine and human law, so his scene with Haemon brings out his incapacity to appreciate the other great motive of Antigone's conduct,â€”sisterly piety. Creon regards the Family almost exclusively in one aspect; for him it is an institution related to the State as the gymnasium to the stadium; it is a little State, in which a man may prove that he is fit to govern a larger one.

Creon's temper is hasty and vehement. He vows that Haemon â€˜shall not save those two girls from their doomâ€™; but, when the Chorus pleads for Ismene, he quickly adds that he will spare her,â€”â€˜thou sayest wellâ€™ (770 f.). We also notice his love of hyperbole (1039 ff.). But he is not malevolent. He represents the rigour of human law,â€”neither restricted by the sense of a higher law, nor intensified by a personal desire to hurt. He has the ill-regulated enthusiasm of a somewhat narrow understanding for the only principle which it has firmly grasped.

á¼Î½ Î½Ï…ÎºÏ„á½¶ Ï„á¿‡ Î½á¿¦Î½, Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Î¿á¼¶Î´â€™ á½‘Ï€á½³ÏÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 16

Such, then, are the general characteristics which mark the treatment of this subject by Sophocles. In a drama of rare poetical beauty, and of especially fine psychology, he has raised the question as to the limit of the State's authority over the individual conscience. It belongs to the essence of the tragic pathos that this question is one which can never be answered by a set formula. Enough for Antigone that she finds herself in a situation where conscience leaves her no choice but to break one of two laws, and to die.

These distinctive qualities of the play may be illustrated by a glance at the work of some other poets. The Antigone of Euripides is now represented only by a few small fragments,Euripides. and its plot is uncertain. It would seem, however, that, when Antigone was caught in the act of burial, Haemon was assisting her, and that the play ended, not with her death, but with her marriageAll that we know as to the plot is contained in the first Argument to this play: â€˜The story has been used also by Euripides in his Antigone; only there she is detected with Haemon, and is given in marriage, and bears a son Maion.â€™ In the scholia at the end of L we also read, â€˜this play differs from the Antigone of Euripides in the fact that, there, she was detected through the love of Haemon, and was given in marriage; while here the issue is the contraryâ€™ (i.e. her death). That this is the right rendering of the scholiast's wordsâ€” Ï†Ï‰ÏÎ±Î¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ± á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î· Î´Î¹á½° Ï„á½¸Î½ Î‘á¼µÎ¼Î¿Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼”ÏÏ‰Ï„Î± á¼Î¾ÎµÎ´á½¹Î¸Î· Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î³á½±Î¼Î¿Î½â€”seems probable from a comparison with the statement in the Argument; though others have understood, â€˜she was detected, and, owing to the love of Haemon, given in marriage.â€™ She was detected, not, as in the play of Sophocles, directly by Creon's guards, but (in some way not specified) through the fact that Haemon's love for her had drawn him to her side. Welcker (Griech. Trag. II. pp. 563 ff.) has sought to identify the Antigone of Euripides with the plot sketched by Hyginus in Fab. 72. Antigone having been detected, Haemon had been commissioned by Creon to slay her, but had saved her, conveying her to a shepherd's home. When Maion, the son of their secret marriage, had grown to man's estate, he visited Thebes at a festival. This was the moment (Welcker thinks) at which the Antigone of Euripides began. Creon noted in Maion a certain mark which all the offspring of the dragon's seed (ÏƒÏ€Î±ÏÏ„Î¿á½·) bore on their bodies. Haemon's disobedience was thus revealed; Heracles vainly interceded with Creon; Haemon slew his wife Antigone and then himself. But surely both the author of the Argument and the scholiast clearly imply that the marriage of Antigone was contained in the play of Euripides, and formed its conclusion. I therefore agree with Heydemann (Ãœber eine nacheuripideische Antigone, Berlin, 1868) that Hyginus was epitomising some otherwise unknown play. M. Patin (Ã‰tudes sur les Tragiques grecs, vol. II. p. 277) remarks that there is nothing to show whether the play of Euripides was produced before or after that of Sophocles. But he has overlooked a curious and decisive piece of evidence. Among the scanty fragments of the Euripidean Antigone are these lines (Eur. fr. 165, Nauck); â€”á¼„ÎºÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¿Î½Â· Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á¼± ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÏ€ÏÎ±Î³á½¹Ï„ÎµÏ‚ | Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏƒÎ±Î½. This evidently glances at the Antigone of Sophocles, vv. 563 f., where Ismene says, Î¿á½Î´â€™ á½ƒÏ‚ á¼‚Î½ Î²Î»á½±ÏƒÏ„Î· Î¼á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹ | Î½Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼Î¾á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î±Î¹. (For similar instances of covert criticism, see n. on O. C. 1116.). Some of the fragments confirm the belief that the Attius.love-motive was prominentEur. fr. 160, 161, 162 (Nauck). The most significant is fr. 161, probably spoken by Haemon:â€”á¼¤ÏÏ‰Î½Â· Ï„á½¸ Î¼Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î´â€™ á¼„Ïâ€™ á¼¦Î½ á¼”ÏÏ‰Ï‚ Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚.â€”Another very suggestive fragment is no. 176, where the speaker is evidently remonstrating with Creon:â€” â€˜Who shall pain a rock by thrusting at it with a spear? And who can pain the dead by dishonour, if we grant that they have no sense of suffering?â€™ This is characteristic of the difference between the poets. Sophocles never urges the futility of Creon's vengeance, though he does touch upon its ignobleness (v. 1030).. The Roman poet Attius (c. 140 B.C.) also wrote an Antigone. The few remaining versesâ€”some of which have lived only because Vergil imitated themâ€”indicate eloquence and spirit, but give no clue to the plotOnly six fragments remain, forming, in all, ten (partly incomplete) lines: Ribbeck, Trag. Rom. Frag. p. 153 (1871). The Ismene of Attius said to her sister (fr. 2), quanto magis te isti modi esse intellego, Tanto, Antigona, magis me par est tibi consulere et parcere: with which Macrobius (Sat. 6. 2. 17) compares Verg. Aen. 12. 19 quantum ipse feroci Virtute exsuperas, tanto me impensius aecum est Consulere atque omnes metuentem expendere casus. Again, he notes (Sat. 6. 1. 59) fr. 5, iam iam neque dÃ­ regunt NÃ©que profecto deÃºm supremus rÃ©x [res] curat hominibus, as having an echo in Aen. 4. 371 iamiam nec maxima Iuno Nec Saturnius haec oculis pater aspicit aequis. This latter fragment of Attius is well compared by Ribbeck with Ant. 921 ff.: the words were doubtless Antigone's.. Statius, inStatius. his epic Thebaid, departs widely from the Attic version of the story. Argeia, the widow of Polyneices, meets Antigone by night at the corpse. Each, unknown to the other, has come to do the same task; both are put to death by Creon,â€” ;ambae hilares et mortis amore superbaeStat. Theb. 12. 679.. This rapturous welcoming of death is, as we have seen, quite in the manner of Massinger and Alfieri, but not at all in that of Sophocles.

Alfieri's Antigone (published in 1783) follows Statius in Alfieri. associating Argeia with Antigone; besides whom there are only two other actors, Creon and Haemon. The Italian poet has not improved upon the Greek. There are here two heroines, with very similar parts, in performing which they naturally utter very similar sentiments. Then Alfieri's Creon is not merely a perverse despot of narrow vision, but a monster of wickedness, who, by a thought worthy of Count Cenci, has published the edict for the express purpose of enticing Antigone into a breach of it. Having doomed her to die, he then offers to pardon her, if she will marry his son (and so unite the royal line with his own); but Antigone, though she esteems Haemon, declines to marry the son of such a parent. So she is put to death, while Argeia is sent back to Argos; and Haemon kills himself. It is not altogether unprofitable to be reminded, by such examples, what the theme of Sophocles could become in other hands.

Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ Îµá½Ï„Ï…Ï‡Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ± Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½ Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï„Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î·. ğŸ—©
Line 17

A word may be added regarding treatments of the Vasepaintings. subject in works of art, which are not without some points of literary interest. Baumeister reproduces two vase-paintings, both curiousDenkmÃ¤ler, pp. 83 f.. The firstFrom Gerhard, Ant. Bildw. Taf. 73. represents a group of three figures,â€”the central figure being an old man who has just doffed the mask of a young maiden,â€”while a guard, spear in hand, seizes him by the neck. This is explained as a comic parody of Antigone's story; she has sent an old servant to perform the task in her stead, and he, when confronted with Creon, drops his disguise. The other vase-paintingMon. Inst. X. 27.,â€”of perhaps c. 380-300 B.C.,â€”represents Heracles interceding with Creon, who is on the hero's right hand, while Antigone and Haemon are on his left. EurydicÃ¨, Ismene, and a youth (perhaps Maion, the offspring of Antigone's marriage with Haemon) are also present. KlÃ¼gmannAnn. Inst. 176, 1876. refers this picture to the lost play of Euripides. HeydemannSee footnote above, p. xxxviii, note 1 (3rd paragraph). (with more probability, I think) supposes it to represent a scene from an otherwise unknown drama, of which he recognises the plot in Hyginus (Fab. 72). It is briefly this:â€”Haemon has disobeyed Creon by saving Antigone's life; Heracles intercedes with Creon for Haemon, but in vain; and the two lovers commit suicide. Professor Rhousopoulos, of Athens, in a letter to the French AcademyÎ ÎµÏá½¶ Îµá¼°Îºá½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ½Ï„Î¹Î³á½¹Î½Î·Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á¿–Î¿Î½ á½„ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±ÎºÎ¿Î½, Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ¹ÎºÎ¿Î½á½·ÏƒÎ¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚. I am indebted to the kindness of Professor D'Ooge, late Director of the American School at Athens, for an opportunity of seeing this letter. (1885), describes a small fragment of a ceramic vase or cup, which he believes to have been painted in Attica, about 400-350 B.C., by (or after) a good artist. The fragment shows the beautiful face of a maiden,â€”the eyes bent earnestly on some object which lies before her. This object has perished with the rest of the vase. But the letters Î•Î™ÎšÎ—Î£ remain; and it is certain that the body of Polyneices was the sight on which the maiden was gazing. As Prof. Rhousopoulos ingeniously shows, the body must have been depicted as resting on sloping ground,â€” the lowest slope, we may suppose, of the hill upon which the guards sat (v. 411). The moment imagined by the artist may have been that at which Antigone returned, to find that the body had been again stripped of dust (v. 426). The women of ancient Thebes are said to have been distinguished for stature no less than beauty; and the artist of the vase appears to have given Antigone both characteristics.

á¼ˆÎ½. á¾”Î´Î· ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚, ÎºÎ±á½· Ïƒâ€™ á¼ÎºÏ„á½¸Ï‚ Î±á½Î»Îµá½·Ï‰Î½ Ï€Ï…Î»á¿¶Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 18

It is not however, in the form of painting or of sculpture that Art has furnished the Antigone with its most famous and most delightful illustration. Two generations have now been so accustomed to associate this play with the music of Mendelssohn that at least a passing notice is due toMendelssohn. the circumstances under which that music was composed; circumstances which, at a distance of nearly half a century, possess a peculiar interest of their own for these later days of classical revivals. After Frederick William IV. had come to the Prussian throne in June, 1840, one of his first acts was to found at Berlin the Academy of Arts for Painting, Sculpture, Architecture, and Music; Mendelssohn, who was then thirty-two, became the first Director of the department of Music, in the spring of 1841. The King had conceived the wish to revive some of the masterpieces of Greek Tragedy,â€” a project which the versatile poet Tieck, then on the confines of old age, encouraged warmly; none the less so, it would seem, because his own youth had been so vigorously identified with the protests of the Romantic school against classical restraint. Donner had recently published his German translation of Sophocles, â€˜in the metres of the original,â€™ and the Antigone was chosen for the experiment. Mendelssohn accepted with enthusiasm the task of writing the music. The rapidity with which he worked may be estimated from the fact that Sept. 9, 1841, seems to have been about the date at which Tieck first broached the idea to him, and that the first full stage rehearsal took place some six weeks later,â€”on October 22nd. The success of the music in Germany seems to have been immediate and great; rather more than could be said of the first performance in London, when the Antigone, with the new music, was brought out at Covent Garden, on Jan. 2, 1845. The orchestra on that occasion, indeed, had a conductor no less able than the late Sir G Macfarren; but the Chorus was put on the stage in a manner of which a graphic memorial has been preserved to usOn March 25, 1845, Mendelssohn wrote to his sister:â€”â€˜See if you cannot find Punch for Jan. 18 [1845]. It contains an account of Antigone at Covent Garden, with illustrations,â€”especially a view of the Chorus which has made me laugh for three days.â€™ In his excellent article on Mendelssohn in the Dictionary of Music, Sir G. Grove has justly deemed this picture worthy of reproduction.. It may be added that the Covent Garden stage-manager improved the opportunity of the joyous â€˜dance-songâ€™ to Dionysus (vv. 1115-1154) by introducing a regular ballet.

To most lovers of music Mendelssohn's Antigone is too familiar to permit any word of comment here; but it may perhaps be less superfluous to remark a fact which has been brought under the writer's notice by an accomplished scholarMr George Wotherspoon, who has practically demonstrated the point by setting the Greek words to the music for the Parodos (vv. 100-161). It is only in the last antistrophe, he observes, that the â€˜phrasingâ€™ becomes distinctly modern, and less attentive to the Greek rhythms than to harmonic effects.. For the most part, the music admits of having the Greek words set to it in a way which shows that Mendelssohn, while writing for Donner's words, must have been guided by something more than Donner's imitation of the Greek metres; he must also have been attentive, as a general rule, to the Greek text.

Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ Î¿á½•Î½ÎµÎºâ€™ á¼Î¾á½³Ï€ÎµÎ¼Ï€Î¿Î½, á½¡Ï‚ Î¼á½¹Î½Î· ÎºÎ»á½»Î¿Î¹Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 19

The question as to the date Date of the play. of the Antigone has a biographical no less than a literary interest. It is probable that the play was first produced at the Great Dionysia towards the end of March, 441 B.C. This precise date is, indeed, by no means certain; but all the evidence indicates that, at any rate, the years 442 and 441 B.C. give the probable limits. According to the author of the first Argument to the play, the success of the Antigone had led to Sophocles obtaining the office of general, which he held in an expedition against Samos. Athens sent two expeditions to Samos in 440 B.C. (1) The occasion of the first expedition was as follows. Samos and Miletus had been at war for the possession of PrienÃ¨, a place on the mainland not far from Miletus. The Milesians, having been worsted, denounced the Samians to the Athenians; who required that both parties should submit their case at Athens. This the Samians refused to do. The Athenians then sent forty ships to Samos,â€”put down the oligarchy there,â€”and established a democracy in its placeThe Greek life of Sophocles says that he served as general â€˜in the war against the Anaeansâ€™ (á¼€Î½Î±á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚). Anaea was a place on the mainland, near PrienÃ¨. Boeckh supposes that the first expedition was known as â€˜the Anaean war,â€™ and that Sophocles took part in it as well as in the second expedition. To me, I confess, there seems to be far more probability in the simple supposition that á¼€Î½Î±á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ is a corruption of ÏƒÎ±Î¼á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚.. (2) The second expedition had to deal with Samos in open rebellion. The Samian oligarchs had come back,â€”overthrown the new democracy,â€”and proclaimed a revolt from Athens, in which Byzantium joined. Pericles was one of the ten generals for the year. He sailed at once to Samos, with sixty ships. All his nine colleagues went with him. When they reached Samos, sixteen of the sixty ships were detached on special service,â€”partly to watch the Carian coast, partly to summon aid from the two great islands to theThe strategia of Sophocles. north, Chios and Lesbos. Sophocles, who was one of the ten generals, was sent on the mission to these islands.

â€˜I met Sophocles, the poet, at Chios, when he was sailing as general to Lesbos.â€™ These are the words of Ion, the poet and prose-writerâ€”who was only some twelve years younger than Sophoclesâ€”in a fragment preserved by Athenaeusp. 603 E. Miller, Frag. Hist. II. 46.. The occasion of the meeting was a dinner given to Sophocles at Chios by Hermesilaus, a friend of his who acted as Athenian â€˜proxenusâ€™ there. Now, there is not the smallest real ground for questioning the genuineness of this fragmentArguments against the genuineness have been brought, indeed, by Ritter Fr.(Vorgebliche Strategie d. Sophokles gegen Samos: Rhein. Mus., 1843, pp. 187 ff.). (1) Ion represents Sophocles as saying,â€”Î ÎµÏÎ¹ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–Î½ Î¼Îµ á¼”Ï†Î·, ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î³Îµá¿–Î½ Î´â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. Sophocles (Ritter argues) would have said Ï†Î·Ïƒá½·, not á¼”Ï†Î·, if Pericles had been alive. The forger of the fragment intended it to refer to the revolt of Lesbos in 428 B.C.,â€”forgetting that Sophocles would then be 78. But we reply:â€”The tense, á¼”Ï†Î·, can obviously refer to the particular occasion on which the remark was made: â€˜Pericles said so [when I was appointed, or when we were at Samos together].â€™ (2) Ion says of Sophocles, Î¿á½ á¿¥ÎµÎºÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î½. This (says Ritter) implies that Sophocles was dead; who, however, long survived Ion. [Ion was dead in 421 B.C., Aristoph. Pax 835.] But here, again, the tense merely refers to the time at which the writer received the impression. We could say of a living person, â€˜he was an agreeable manâ€™â€”meaning that we found him so when we met him.. And its genuineness is confirmed by internal evidence. Sophocles said at the dinner-party,â€”alluding to a playful ruse by which he had amused the company,â€”that he was practising generalship, as Pericles had said that he was a better poet than general. The diplomatic mission to Chios and Lesbos was a service in which Pericles might very naturally utilize the abilities of his gifted, though unmilitary colleague. There is another trait which has not (to my knowledge) been noticed, but which seems worth remarking, as the coincidence is one which is not likely to have been contrived by a forger. It is casually mentioned that, at this dinner-party, an attendant was standing â€˜near the fire,â€™ and the couch of Sophocles, the chief guest, was also near it. The warm season, then, had not begun. Now we know that Pericles sailed for Samos early in 440 B.C., before the regular season for navigation had yet openedSee Curtius, Hist. Gr. II. 472 (Eng. tr.)..

If the fragment of Ion is authentic, then it is certain that Sophocles held the strategia, and certain also that he held it in 440 B.C.: for Ion's mention of Lesbos cannot possibly be referred to the revolt of that island from Athens in 428 B.C. Apart from the fragment of Ion, however, there is good Attic authority for the tradition. Androtion, whose Atthis was written about 280 B.C., gave the names of the ten generals at Samos on this occasion. His listThis fragment of Androtion has been preserved by the schol. on Aristeides, vol. 3, p. 485 (Dind.). MÃ¼ller, Frag. Hist. IV. 645. The names of two of the ten generals are wanting in the printed texts, but have since been restored, from the MS., by Wilamowitz, De Rhesi Scholiis, P. 13 (Greifswald, 1877). I have observed a remarkable fact in regard to Androtion's list, which ought to be mentioned, because it might be urged against the authenticity of the list, though (in my opinion) such an inference from it would be unfair. Androtion gives (1) the names, (2) the demes of the Generals, but not their tribes. The regular order of precedence for the ten Cleisthenean tribes was this:â€” 1. Erectheis. 2. Aegeis. 3. Pandionis. 4. Leontis. 5. Acamantis. 6. Oeneis. 7. Cecropis. 8. Hippothontis. 9. Aeantis. 10. Antiochis. Now take the demes named by Androtion. His list will be found to follow this order of the ten tribes,â€” with one exception, and it is in the case of Sophocles. His deme, Colonus, belonged to the Antiochis, and therefore his name ought to have come last. But Androtion puts it second. The explanation is simple. When the ten tribes were increased to twelve, by the addition of the Antigonis and Demetrias (in or about 307 B.C.), some of the demes were transferred from one tribe to another. Among these was the deme of Colonus. It was transferred from the Antiochis, the tenth on the roll, to the Aegeis, the second on the roll. Hence Androtion's order is correct for his own time (c. 280 B.C.), but not correct for 440 B.C. It is quite unnecessary, however, to infer that he invented or doctored the list. It is enough to suppose that he re-adjusted the order, so as to make it consistent in the eyes of his contemporaries. includes Pericles, and â€˜Sophocles, the poet, of Colonus.â€™

Later writers refer to the poet's strategia as if it were a generally accepted factThe Argument to this play, and the Î’á½·Î¿Ï‚ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á½³Î¿Ï…Ï‚, have already been cited. See also (1) Strabo 14. p. 638 á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Î¹ Î´á½²...Ï€á½³Î¼ÏˆÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î³á½¸Î½ Î ÎµÏÎ¹ÎºÎ»á½³Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î±á½Ï„á¿· Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á½³Î± Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Î¿Î¹Î·Ï„á½´Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚ Î´Î¹á½³Î¸Î·ÎºÎ±Î½ á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î¸Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î£Î±Î¼á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚. (2) Schol. on Aristoph. Pax 696 Î»á½³Î³ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î´á½² á½…Ï„Î¹ á¼Îº Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î³á½·Î±Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼Î½ Î£á½±Î¼á¿³ á¼ Î³Ï…Ïá½·ÏƒÎ±Ï„Î¿ (á½ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚). (3) Suidas s.v. Îœá½³Î»Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ [but referring to the Samian Îœá½³Î»Î¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï‚: cp. Diog. L. 9. 24] á½‘Ï€á½²Ï Î£Î±Î¼á½·Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î³á½µÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á¼Î½Î±Ï…Î¼á½±Ï‡Î·ÏƒÎµ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï„ÏÎ±Î³Î¹Îºá½¹Î½, á½€Î»Ï…Î¼Ï€Î¹á½±Î´Î¹ Ï€Î´/ (Ol. 84 = 444-441 B.C.).â€”The theory that Sophocles the poet was confused with Sophocles son of Sostratides, strategus in 425 B.C. (Thuc. 3.115), is quite incompatible with the ancient evidence..

á¼¸Ïƒ. 20 Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹; Î´Î·Î»Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î³á½±Ï Ï„Î¹ ÎºÎ±Î»Ï‡Î±á½·Î½Î¿Ï…Ïƒâ€™ á¼”Ï€Î¿Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 20

We have next to ask,â€”What ground is there for connectingHad the play any bearing upon the poet's appointment? this strategia of Sophocles with the production of his Antigone? The authority for such a connection is the first Argument to the play. This is ascribed to Aristophanes of Byzantium (c. 200 B.C.), but is more probably of later origin. It says;â€”â€˜They say (Ï†Î±Ïƒá½·) that Sophocles was appointed to the strategia which he held at Samos, because he had distinguished himself by the production of the Antigone.â€™ Here, as so often elsewhere, the phrase, â€˜they say,â€™ is not an expression of doubt, but an indication that the story was found in several writers. We know the names of at least two writers in whose works such a tradition would have been likely to occur. One of them is Satyrus (c. 200 B.C.), whose collection of biographies was used by the author of the Life of SophoclesSee Introduction to the Oed. Col., Â§ 18, p. xli. J. S. III.3; the otherâ€”also quoted in the Lifeâ€”is Carystius of Pergamum, who lived about 110 B.C., and wrote a book, Î ÎµÏá½¶ Î´Î¹Î´Î±ÏƒÎºÎ±Î»Î¹á¿¶Î½â€”â€˜Chronicles of the Stageâ€™â€”which Athenaeus cites. At the time when these works â€”and there were others of a similar kindâ€”were compiled, old and authentic lists of Athenian plays, with their dates, appear to have been extant in such libraries as those of Alexandria and Pergamum. When, therefore, we meet with a tradition,â€”dating at least from the second century B.C.,â€”which affirms that the strategia of Sophocles was due to his Antigone, one inference, at least, is fairly secure. We may believe that the Antigone was known to have been produced earlier than the summer of 441 B.C. For, if Sophocles was strategus in the early spring of 440 B.C., he must have been elected in May, 441 B.C. The election of the ten strategi was held annually, at the same time as the other official elections (á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±Î¹ÏÎµÏƒá½·Î±Î¹), in the month of Thargelion, at the beginning of the ninth prytany of the civic year. Further, we may conclude that the Antigone had not been produced at any long interval before May, 441 B.C. Otherwise the tradition that the play had influenced the electionâ€”whether it really did so or notâ€”would not have seemed probable.

Assuming, then, that the Antigone was brought out not long before Sophocles obtained the strategia, we have still to consider whether there is any likelihood in the story that his election was influenced by the success of the play. At first sight, a modern reader is apt to be reminded of the man of letters who, in the opinion of his admirer, would have been competent, at the shortest notice, to assume command of the Channel Fleet. It may appear grotesque that an important State should have rewarded poetical genius by a similar appointment. But here, as in other cases, we must endeavour to place ourselves at the old Athenian point of view. The word â€˜general,â€™ by which we render â€˜strategus,â€™ suggests functions purely military, requiring, for their proper discharge, an elaborate professional training. Such a conception of the Athenian strategia would not, however, be accurate. The ten strategi, chosen annually, formed a board of which the duties were primarily military, but also, in part, civil. And, for the majority of the ten, the military duties were usually restricted to the exercise of control and supervision at Athens. They resembled officials at the War Office, with some added functions from the province of the Home Office. The number of strategi sent out with an army or a fleet was, at this period, seldom more than three. It was only in grave emergencies that all the ten strategi went on active service together. In May, 441 B.C.,â€”the time, as it seems, when Sophocles was elected,â€”no one could have foreseen the great crisis at Samos. In an ordinary year Sophocles, as one of the strategi, would not necessarily have been required to leave Athens. Among his nine colleagues there were doubtless, besides Pericles, one or two more possessed of military aptitudes, who would have sufficed to perform any ordinary service in the field. Demosthenesâ€”in whose day only one of the ten strategi was ordinarily commissioned for warâ€”describes the other nine as occupied, among other things, with arranging the processions for the great religious festivals at AthensDem. or. 4 Â§ 26.. He deplores, indeed, that they should be so employed; but it is certain that it had long been one duty of these high officials to help in organising the great ceremonies. We are reminded how suitable such a sphere of duty would have been for Sophocles,â€”who is said to have led in his boyhood the Chorus that celebrated the victory of Salamis,â€”and we seem to win a new light on the meaning of his appointment to the strategia. In so far as a strategus had to do with public ceremonies and festivals, a man with the personal gifts of Sophocles could hardly have strengthened his claim better than by a brilliant success at the Dionysia. The mode of election was favourable to such a man. It was by show of hands in the Ecclesia. If the Antigone was produced at the Great Dionysia, late in March, 441 B.C., it is perfectly intelligible that the poet's splendid dramatic triumph should have contributed to his election in the following May. It is needless to suppose that his special fitness for the office was suggested to his fellow-citizens by the special maxims of administration which he ascribes to Creon,â€”a notion which would give an air of unreality,â€”verging, indeed, on comedy,â€”to a result which appears entirely natural when it is considered in a larger wayOne of Aelian's anecdotes (Var. Hist. 3. 8) is entitled, á½…Ï„Î¹ á½ Î¦Ïá½»Î½Î¹Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ Î´Î¹á½± Ï„Î¹ Ï€Î¿á½·Î·Î¼Î± ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î³á½¸Ï‚ á¾‘Ïá½³Î¸Î·. Phrynichus, he says, â€˜having composed suitable songs for the performers of the war-dance (Ï€Ï…ÏÏÎ¹Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î±á¿–Ï‚) in a tragedy, so captivated and enraptured the (Athenian) spectators, that they immediately elected him to a military command.â€™ Nothing else is known concerning this alleged strategia. It is possible that Phrynichus, the tragic poet of c. 500 B.C., was confounded by some later anecdote-monger with the son of Stratonides, general in 412 B.C. (Thuc. 8.25), and that the story was suggested by the authentic strategia of Sophocles. At any rate, the vague and dubious testimony of Aelian certainly does not warrant us in using the case of Phrynichus as an illustration..

á¼ˆÎ½. Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Ï„á½±Ï†Î¿Ï… Î½á¿·Î½ Ï„á½¼ ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î³Î½á½µÏ„Ï‰ ÎšÏá½³Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 21

The internal evidence of the Antigone confirms theInternal evidence for an early date. belief that it is the earliest of the extant seven. Certain traits of composition distinguish it. (1) The division of an iambic trimeter between two or more speakersâ€”technically called á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Î»Î±Î²á½µâ€”is avoided, as it is by Aeschylus. It is admitted in the other six plays. (2) An anapaest nowhere holds the first place of the trimeter. It may further be noticed that the resolution of any foot of the trimeter is comparatively rare in the Antigone. Including the proper names, there are less than 40 instances. A considerably higher proportion is found in later plays. (3) The use made of anapaestic verse is archaistic in three points. (a) The Parodos contains regular anapaestic systems (see note on vv. 100-161). (b) The Chorus uses anapaests in announcing the entrance of Creon, Antigone, Ismene, Haemon. In the case of Ismene, these anapaests do not follow the stasimon, but occur in the midst of the epeisodion (see vv. 526-530). (c) Anapaests are also admitted, for purposes of dialogue, within an epeisodion (vv. 929-943, where the Chorus, Creon, and Antigone are the speakers). Aeschylus allowed this; but elsewhere it occurs only in the Ajax of Sophocles (another comparatively early play), and in the Medea of Euripides (431 B.C.).

Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½·ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, Ï„á½¸Î½ Î´â€™ á¼€Ï„Î¹Î¼á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹; ğŸ—©
Line 22

The first Argument Place of the play in the series of the poet's works. ends by saying that the play â€˜has been reckoned as the thirty-secondÎ»á½³Î»ÎµÎºÏ„Î±Î¹ Î´á½² Ï„á½¸ Î´Ïá¾¶Î¼Î± Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Ï„ÏÎ¹Î±ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÏ„á½¸Î½ Î´Îµá½»Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½. Bergk (Hist. Gr. Lit. III. p. 414) proposes to read, Î´ÎµÎ´á½·Î´Î±ÎºÏ„Î±Î¹ Î´á½² Ï„á½¸ Î´Ïá¾¶Î¼Î± Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Ï„ÏÎ¹Î±ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î½Â· Î´Îµá½»Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î½. He assumes that Sophocles gained the second prize, because, according to the Parian Chronicle (60), the first prize was gained by Euripides in the archonship of Diphilus (442/1 B.C.). He adds that the word Îµá½Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¹Î¼á½µÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î±, applied to Sophocles in the Argument, would suit the winner of the second prize,â€”as Aristophanes says of his own Î”Î±Î¹Ï„Î±Î»Îµá¿–Ï‚, which gained the second prize, á¼„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼ ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ïƒá½±Ï„Î·Î½ ï¼ˆNub. 529). But two things are wanting to the probability of Bergk's conjecture, viz., (1) some independent reason for thinking that the Antigone was the 30th, rather than the 32nd, of its author's works; and (2) some better ground for assuming that it gained the second prize..â€™ This statement was doubtless taken from authentic Î´Î¹Î´Î±ÏƒÎºÎ±Î»á½·Î±Î¹â€”lists of performances, with their datesâ€”which had come down from the 5th century B.C. to the Alexandrian age. The notice has a larger biographical interest than can often be claimed for such details. In 441 B.C. Sophocles was fifty-five: he died in 406/5 B.C., at ninety or ninety-one. More than 100 lost plays of his are known by name: the total number of his works might be roughly estimated at 110. It appears warrantable to assume that Sophocles had produced his works by tetralogies,â€”i.e., three tragedies and one satyric drama on each occasion. If the number 32 includes the satyric dramas, then the Antigone was the fourth play of the eighth tetralogy, and Sophocles would have competed on seven occasions before 441 B.C. He is recorded to have gained the first prize at his first appearance, in 468 B.C., when he was twenty-eight. The production of 28 plays in the next 27 years would certainly argue a fair measure of poetical activity. If, on the other hand, this 32 is exclusive of satyric dramas, then the Antigone was the second play of the eleventh trilogy, and the whole number of plays written by the poet from 468 to 441 B.C. (both years included) was 44.

On either view, then, we have this interesting result,â€”that the years of the poet's life from fifty-five to ninety were decidedly more productive than the years from twenty-eight to fifty-five. And if we suppose that the number 32 includes the satyric dramasâ€”which seems the more natural viewâ€”then the ratio of increased fertility after the age of fifty-five becomes still more remarkable. We have excellent reason, moreover, for believing that this increase in amount of production was not attended by any deterioration of quality. The Philoctetes and the Coloneus are probably among the latest works of all. These facts entitle Sophocles to be reckoned among the most memorable instances of poetical genius prolonging its fullest vigour to extreme old age, andâ€”what is perhaps rarer stillâ€”actually increasing its activity after middle life had been left behind.

á¼˜Ï„ÎµÎ¿ÎºÎ»á½³Î± Î¼á½³Î½, á½¡Ï‚ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹, Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î´á½·ÎºÎ·Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 23

Nothing is known as to the plays which SophoclesThe Theban playsâ€”not a connected trilogy. may have produced along with the Antigone. Two forms of trilogy were in concurrent use down at least to the end of the fifth century,â€”that in which the three tragedies were parts of one story,â€”and that in which no such link existed. The former was usually (though doubtless not always) employed by Aeschylus; the latter was preferred by his younger rival. Thus it is possible,â€”nay, probable,â€”that the two tragedies which accompanied the Antigone were unrelated to it in subject. Even when the Theban plays of Sophocles are read in the order of the fable, they do not form a linked trilogy in the Aeschylean sense. This is not due merely to discrepancy of detail or incompleteness of juncture. The perversely rigorous Creon of the Antigone is, indeed, an essentially distinct character from the ruthless villain of the Coloneus; the Coloneus describes the end of Oedipus in a manner irreconcileable with the allusion in the Antigone (v. 50). But, if such differences existed between the Choephori and the Eumenides, they would not affect the solidarity of the â€˜Oresteia.â€™ On the other hand, it does not suffice to make the triad a compact trilogy that the Tyrannus is, in certain aspects, supplemented by the ColoneusSee Introd. to Oed. Col. p. xxi. Â§ 3., and that the latter is connected with the Antigone by finely-wrought links of allusionSee Oed. Col. 1405-1413, and 1770-1772.. In nothing is the art of Sophocles more characteristically seen than in the fact that each of these three masterpiecesâ€”with their common thread of fable, and with all their particular affinitiesâ€”is still, dramatically and morally, an independent whole.

For the sensual use of Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Ï‚ cp. Phaedr. 254 A Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼€Ï†ÏÎ¿Î´Î¹Ïƒá½·Ï‰Î½ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚.

Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ is used either adverbially or with a genitive. Med. 538 Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Ï‡Ïá¿†ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î¼á½´ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î¿Ï‚ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½, â€˜not at the pleasure of force,â€™â€” i.e. not so that force can do what it pleases. Ï„Î¿Î¹Î±á¿¦Ï„á½± Ï†Î±ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î³Î±Î¸á½¸Î½ ÎšÏá½³Î¿Î½Ï„Î± ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ ğŸ—©
Line 31

ÏƒÎ¿á½·, like Îºá¼€Î¼Î¿á½·, depends on ÎºÎ·Ïá½»Î¾Î±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ (for which see 22). Creon's edict, addressed to all Thebans, touches the sisters first, since, as the nearest relatives of the dead, they were most concerned to see that he received burial. Antigone speaks with burning indignation. She says, in effect:â€”â€˜Thus hath Creon forbidden thee and me to render the last offices to our brother.â€™ The parenthesis Î»á½³Î³Ï‰ Î³á½°Ï Îºá¼€Î¼á½³ is prompted by the intense consciousness of a resolve. To her, who knows her own heart, it seems wonderful that Creon should even have imagined her capable of obeying such an edict. It is a fine psychological touch, and one of the most pathetic in the play.

Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î³Î±Î¸á½¹Î½, ironical, as O. T. 385 ÎšÏá½³Ï‰Î½ á½ Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½¹Ï‚, Ph. 873á¼Î³Î±Î¸Î¿á½¶ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î»á½±Ï„Î±Î¹.

In Ai. 569 where L has á¼˜ÏÎ¹Î²Î¿á½·Î± (sic) Î»á½³Î³Ï‰, most edd. now give the dat.

Two other explanations may be noticed. Both make ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ enclitic. (1) Taking ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ as ethic dat. with Ï„Î¿Î¹Î±á¿¦Ï„Î±: â€˜There is the good Creon's proclamation for you,â€”aye, and for me too, for I count myself also amongst those forbiddenâ€™ (Campbell). (2) Taking ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ as ethic dat. with á¼€Î³Î±Î¸á½¹Î½: â€˜your good Creon, aye and mine, for I own I too thought him soâ€™ (Kennedy). But Antigone is too much occupied with the edict itself to dwell with such emphasis at such a moment on the disappointment which she has experienced as to Creon's amiability.

That such a relative clause was felt as practically equivalent to a noun-case may be seen from Thuc. 2.62, where it is co-ordinated with a dative: Î±á½”Ï‡Î·Î¼Î± Î¼á½²Î½...ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î»á¿· Ï„Î¹Î½á½¶ á¼Î³Î³á½·Î³Î½ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Ï†Ïá½¹Î½Î·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ Î´á½³, á½ƒÏ‚ á¼‚Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³Î½á½½Î¼á¿ƒ Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½»á¿ƒ. Thuc. uses this constr. esp. in definitions, as 6. 14, Ï„á½¸ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ á¼„ÏÎ¾Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹, á½ƒÏ‚ á¼‚Î½ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½·Î´Î± á½ Ï†ÎµÎ»á½µÏƒá¿ƒ.

Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î´Î·Î¼á½¹Î»ÎµÏ…ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ á¼Î½ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¹. ğŸ—©

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹: cp. 481: O. T. 865 Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï€Ïá½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Î½Ï„Î±Î¹.

Î´Î·Î¼á½¹Î»ÎµÏ…ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ = Î»ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± á½‘Ï€á½¸ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î´á½µÎ¼Î¿Ï…, the epith. of the victim being transferred to the doom: Tr. 357 á½ á¿¥Î¹Ï€Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á¼¸Ï†á½·Ï„Î¿Ï… Î¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚. Cp. Aesch. Î»á½»Î¿Ï…Ïƒâ€™ â€¦ á¼¢ â€™Ï†á½±Ï€Ï„Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±, â€˜by seeking to loose or to tighten the knot,â€™â€”a phrase, perhaps proverbial, for â€˜meddling in any way.â€™ She can do no good by touching the tangled skein. ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ï†Î¹Îµá¿–Ï‚, take up for burial: cp. Ai. 1410 Ï€Î»ÎµÏ…Ïá½°Ï‚ Ïƒá½ºÎ½ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ | Ï„á½±ÏƒÎ´â€™ á¼Ï€Î¹ÎºÎ¿á½»Ï†Î¹Î¶' (the dead Ajax): and the common phrase á¼€Î½Î±Î¹ÏÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î½ÎµÎºÏÎ¿á½»Ï‚.

á¼¦ Î³á½°Ï marks surprise (O. C. 64). The absence of caesura in the first three feet allows each of the two important words (Î½Î¿Îµá¿–Ï‚ Î¸á½±Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½) to fall slowly from the astonished speaker's lips.

Line 45

Ï„á½¸Î½ Î³Î¿á¿¦Î½ á¼Î¼á½¸Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». To the questionâ€”â€˜Do you really mean to bury him?â€™â€”the simple answer would have been, Ï„á½¸Î½ Î³Î¿á¿¦Î½ á¼Î¼á½¸Î½ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¹Î½, â€˜I certainly mean to bury my own brother.â€™ But the word á¼Î¼á½¹Î½â€”reminding her that he is equally Ismene's brotherâ€”prompts the insertion of the reproachful clause, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¸Î½ Ïƒá½¹Î½, á¼¢Î½ Ïƒá½º Î¼á½´ Î¸á½³Î»á¿ƒÏ‚. Thus the contrast between Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î¼á½¹Î½ and Ï„á½¸Î½ Ïƒá½¹Î½ anticipates the emphasis on the word á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¹Î½. The whole thought is,â€”â€˜I will certainly do my duty,â€”and thine, if thou wilt not,â€”to a brother.â€™ Since á½ á¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚ is the same person as á½ Ïƒá½¹Ï‚, this thought can be poetically expressed by saying, â€˜I will certainly bury my brother,â€”and thine, if thou wilt notâ€™: for the tribute rendered to him by one sister represents the tribute due from both. Remark that Î³Î¿á¿¦Î½ often emphasises a pers. or possessive pron. (as here á¼Î¼á½¹Î½): 565 ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ Î³Î¿á¿¦Î½: Ai. 527 Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î³Î¿á¿¦Î½ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦: O. (1) Taking Ï„á½¸Î½ â€¦ á¼Î¼á½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¸Î½ Ïƒá½¹Î½ as=â€˜him who is my brother and thine,â€™ and á¼¢Î½ as=â€˜even if.â€™ But for this we should expect Ï„á½¸Î½ Î³Î¿á¿¦Î½ á¼Î¼á½¹Î½ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒá½¹Î½, and Îºá¼„Î½. (2) Taking ÎºÎ±á½¶ with á¼¤Î½, â€˜I will bury my brother, even if thou wilt not bury thine.â€™ But (i) the separation of ÎºÎ±á½· from á¼¤Î½ is abnormal: (ii) the mode of expression would be scarcely natural unless á½ á¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚ and á½ Ïƒá½¹Ï‚ were different persons.

á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¹Î½Â· Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Î´á½´ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î´Î¿á¿¦Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î»á½½ÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹. ğŸ—©
Line 46

á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¸Î½ â€¦ á¼Î»á½½ÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹. Didymus (circ. 30 B.C.) said this verse was condemned as spurious â€˜by the commentatorsâ€™ (á½‘Ï€á½¸ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î¼Î½Î·Î¼Î±Ï„Î¹ÏƒÏ„á¿¶Î½). I believe it to be undoubtedly genuine. One modern argument against it is that Antigone should here speak only one verse. But these two verses express the resolve on which the action of the play turns: it is an important moment in the dialogue. And, at such a moment, Soph. often allows a stichomuthia to be broken by two or more verses for the same speaker. See the stichomuthia in 401â€”406, broken by 404 f.: O. T. 356-369, broken by 366 f.: ib. 1000â€”1046, broken by 1002 f. and 1005 f.: O. C. 579-606, broken by 583 f. and 599 ff. Further, verse 46 is Sophoclean in three traits: (a) á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¹Î½ emphasised by position as first word, with a pause after it: cp. 72, 525: O. T. 278 Î´Îµá¿–Î¾Î±Î¹: O. C. 1628 Ï‡Ï‰ÏÎµá¿–Î½. (b) Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Î´á½µ in rejecting an alternative: O. T. 576 á¼ÎºÎ¼á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½â€™Â· Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Î´á½´ Ï†Î¿Î½Îµá½ºÏ‚ á¼Î»á½½ÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹. Cp. O. C. 110 n. (c) The phrase with the aor. part.: Ai. 1267 Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î±ÏÏÎµá¿– ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î´Î¿á¿¦Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î»á½·ÏƒÎºÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. Lastly, v. 45, if alone, would be too bald and curt.

á¼¸Ïƒ. á½¦ ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î»á½·Î±, ÎšÏá½³Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½Ï„ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ·Îºá½¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚; ğŸ—©
Line 47

á½¦ ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î»á½·Î±, â€˜over-bold.â€™ The word primarily means â€˜enduringâ€™ (&\sqrt;ÏƒÏ‡Îµ, ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ¸Îµá¿–Î½). Hence: (1) Of persons, (a) â€˜unflinching,â€™ in audacity or cruelty,â€”the usu. ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î»á½·Î± Ï„á½¹Î»Î¼Î·Ï‚. (b) â€˜Suffering,â€™=Ï„Î»á½µÎ¼Ï‰Î½, as Aesch. PV 644 (of Io), Eur. Hec. 783. Neither Homer nor Soph. has this use. (2) Of things, â€˜cruel,â€™ â€˜wretched,â€™â€”a use common to all the poets: so Ai. 887 ÏƒÏ‡á½³Ï„Î»Î¹Î± Î³á½±Ï (â€˜'tis cruelâ€™), Tr. 879.

á¼ˆÎ½. á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Î±á½Ï„á¿· Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼Î¼á¿¶Î½ Î¼â€™ Îµá¼´ÏÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¼á½³Ï„Î±. ğŸ—©

Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½, adv.: Î¼á½³Ï„Î± = Î¼á½³Ï„ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹: Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼Î¼á¿¶Î½ (masc.) with Îµá¼´ÏÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î½ only: cp. El. 536 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½ Î¼ÎµÏ„á¿†Î½ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„á½µÎ½ Î³â€™ á¼Î¼á½´Î½ ÎºÏ„Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½. á¼¸Ïƒ. Î¿á¼´Î¼Î¿Î¹. Ï†Ïá½¹Î½Î·ÏƒÎ¿Î½, á½¦ ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î³Î½á½µÏ„Î·, Ï€Î±Ï„á½´Ï
50 á½¡Ï‚ Î½á¿·Î½ á¼€Ï€ÎµÏ‡Î¸á½´Ï‚ Î´Ï…ÏƒÎºÎ»Îµá½µÏ‚ Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿, ğŸ—©
Line 50

Î½á¿·Î½ ethic dat. with á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿ (cp. O. C. 81 Î²á½³Î²Î·ÎºÎµÎ½ á¼¡Î¼á½·Î½). á¼€Ï€ÎµÏ‡Î¸á½µÏ‚, hateful to mankind for his involuntary crimes. á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿, â€˜died,â€™ not merely â€˜was disgracedâ€™ (cp. 59 á½€Î»Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ¸â€™): she is speaking of the deaths which had left them alone. But á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï„Î± in 53 is merely â€˜then,â€™ â€˜in the next place,â€™ and need not mean that Oedipus died before Iocasta. Here Soph. follows the outline of the epic version, acc. to which Oed. died at Thebes: see Introd. to Oed. Tyr. pp. xvi ff. The poet of the Odyssey (11. 275) makes him survive his consort's suicide, and no version appears to have assumed the contrary. The Antigone knows nothing of his exile from Thebes, or of the sacred honour which surrounded the close of his life, as the story is told in the later Oedipus at Colonus.

Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÎºÏ„Î¿Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Îµ is not literally, â€˜slaying themselves,â€™ or â€˜slaying each other,â€™ but, â€˜slaying with their own handsâ€™: the context explains that the person whom each so slew was his own brother. So either (1) suicide, or (2) slaying of kinsfolk, can be expressed by Î±á½Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Î·Ï‚, Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÎºÏ„á½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚, Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³á½µÏ‚, Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚, etc. The compound merely expresses that the deed is done with one's own hand, implying that such a use of one's own hand is unnatural. The object of the deed may be one's own life, or another's. This ambiguity of the compound is illustrated by 1175 f. Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï Î´â€™ Î±á¼±Î¼á½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹.â€”XO. ÎºÎ±Ï„ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³á½±ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„â€™, plur. verb with dual subject, as oft., even when another verb with the same subject is dual, as Xen. Cyr. 6.1.47 á½¡Ï‚ Îµá¼°Î´á½³Ï„Î·Î½...á¼ ÏƒÏ€á½±ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¿: Plat. Euthyd. 294E á½…Ï„Îµ Ï€Î±Î¹Î´á½·Î± á¼¤ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½ ...á¼ Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±ÏƒÎ¸Îµ: see O. C. 343 n.

á¼Ï€Î±Î»Î»á½µÎ»Î¿Î¹Î½ Ï‡ÎµÏÎ¿á¿–Î½, â€˜with mutual hands,â€™â€”each brother lifting his hands against the other. All the difficulty has arisen from failing to distinguish between (1) Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ á¼¡Î´á½³Ï‰Ï‚ Î´Ïá¿´Î·Ï‚, and (2) Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ á¼¡Î´á½³Ï‰Ï‚ Î´Ïá¿´Î·Ï‚. Î¼á½´ â€™Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½±ÏÎ²ÎµÎ¹ (or, as some write it, Î¼á½´ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦) is clearly right. If we read Î¼á½µ Î¼Î¿Ï… Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½±ÏÎ²ÎµÎ¹, then the emphasis is solely on the verbal notion. â€˜I fear for thee.â€™â€”â€˜Fear not so: make thine own fate prosperous.â€™ But the stress on Ï„á½¸Î½ Ïƒá½¹Î½ renders it certain that the poet intended a corresponding stress on the preceding pronoun: â€˜Fear not for meâ€” make thine own fate prosperous.â€™ And Î¼á½´ â€™Î¼Î¿á¿¦ is no more objectionable than Î¼á½´ â€™Î³á½½ in El. 472. Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½±ÏÎ²ÎµÎ¹, as Tr. 89 (with gen. Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚). Distinguish Ï€ÏÎ¿Î´Îµá½·ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, â€˜afraid beforehand,â€™ O. T. 90 (n.).

á¼Î¾á½¹ÏÎ¸Î¿Ï… here=â€˜straighten out,â€™ i.e. guide in a straight or prosperous course: cp. 167 á½¤ÏÎ¸Î¿Ï… Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½, 675 á½€ÏÎ¸Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½. In the figurative uses of á½€ÏÎ¸á½¹Ï‚ and its derivatives the context must always guide our choice between the notion of â€˜uprightâ€™ and that of â€˜straight.â€™

á¼ˆÎ½. Î¼á½´ â€™Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½±ÏÎ²ÎµÎ¹Â· Ï„á½¸Î½ Ïƒá½¸Î½ á¼Î¾á½¹ÏÎ¸Î¿Ï… Ï€á½¹Ï„Î¼Î¿Î½.

Line 84

á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½–Î½ â€¦ Î³Îµ. In this combination á¼€Î»Î»á½± is like our â€˜wellâ€™; Î¿á½–Î½=â€˜at any rateâ€™ (i.e. if you must do it); and Î³Îµ emphasises the word which it follows. Cp. á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá½° Î´á½² Ï„á¿· Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎµá½·ÏƒÎµÎ¹ Î´á½·Îºá¿ƒ. ğŸ—©
Line 94

á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá½°...Ï„á¿· Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎµá½·ÏƒÎµÎ¹ Î´á½·Îºá¿ƒ, â€˜thou wilt be subject to the lasting enmity of the dead.â€™ The word Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎµá½·ÏƒÎµÎ¹ means literally, â€˜wilt be attached to...,â€™ i.e., â€˜wilt be brought into a lasting relation withâ€™; and á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá½± defines the nature of that relation. The sense is thus virtually the same as if we had, á½ Î¸Î±Î½á½¼Î½ á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá½¹Ï‚ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎµá½·ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, â€˜the enmity of the dead will cleave to thee.â€™ The convertible use of Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎµÎ¸Î±Î¹ is illustrated by 1243 á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¶ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Ï„Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½, as compared with El. 1040 á¾§ Ïƒá½º Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎ±Î¹ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿·, and ib. 240 Îµá¼´ Ï„á¿³ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÏ„á¿·. Here, Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎµá½·ÏƒÎµÎ¹ expresses merely the establishment of the permanent relation between the two persons. It does not mean, â€˜you will be brought, as his foe, into dependence on himâ€™ (i.e. under the power of his curse); as in Eur. Tro. 185 Ï„á¿· Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Î¼Î±Î¹ Î´Î¿á½»Î»Î± Ï„Î»á½±Î¼Ï‰Î½; â€˜to whom have I been assigned as a slave?â€™ (i.e. by the casting of lots:â€” the answer is, á¼Î³Î³á½»Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Ï… ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ±Î¹ ÎºÎ»á½µÏÎ¿Ï…). Nor, again, â€˜you will press upon the dead as his foe,â€™ i.e. be hostile and grievous to him: for, as Î´á½·Îºá¿ƒ shows, the punishment is to be hers, not his. The idea might have been expressed in a converse form by Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Î± á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá½¸Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹ (cf. Xen. Cyr. 2.4.12).

Lehrs proposed Î”á½·Îºá¿ƒ, i.e. â€˜you will fall under the chastisement of justice.â€™ Donaldson, following Emper, reads á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá¾·... Î´á½·Îºá¿ƒ, as iure inimicorum apud mortuum eris: i.e. on the part of the dead you will be deemed to have only the rights of a foe. This is impossible. The ordinary reading is sound.

Ï„á½¸ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿, ironical: cp. El. 376 (ÎµÎ»ÎµÎ¾Ï„ÏÎ± Î¹Î½ Î±Î½ÏƒÏ‰ÎµÏ Ï„Î¿ Î·ÎµÏ ÏƒÎ¹ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏâ€™Ï‚ Ï‰Î±ÏÎ½Î¹Î½Î³Ï‚) Ï†á½³Ïâ€™ Îµá¼°Ï€á½² Î´á½´ Ï„á½¸ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¹Î½.

Î¼á½´ Î¿á½, not Î¼á½µ, because the principal verb Ï€Îµá½·ÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ is negatived: O.T. 283 n. Line 99

Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î´â€™ á½€ÏÎ¸á¿¶Ï‚ Ï†á½·Î»Î·, â€˜but truly dear to thy friends,â€™â€”i.e. both to the dead brother and to the living sister. á¼€ÎµÎ»á½·Î¿Ï…, Dor. for the epic á¼ ÎµÎ»á½·Î¿Ï…, with Î±â€” as usu. (808, O. C. 1245), though it is sometimes used with Äƒ, as Tr. 835, Eur. Med. 1252.

Ï„á½¸ Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ ...Ï†á½±Î¿Ï‚. Two constructions are possible; I prefer the first. (1) Î˜á½µÎ²á¾³ Ï†Î±Î½á½²Î½ Ï„á½¸ Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ Ï†á½±Î¿Ï‚, the art. going with the superlative, which it emphasises,â€”â€˜the very fairest,â€™â€”a common use, as Hipp. 289B Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼¡ ÎºÎ±Î»Î»á½·ÏƒÏ„Î· Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡Ïá½° Ï†Î±Î½Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹; Od. 17.415 Î¿á½ Î¼á½³Î½ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Î´Î¿Îºá½³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á½ Îºá½±ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ á¼ˆÏ‡Î±Î¹á¿¶Î½. (2) Ï„á½¸ Î˜á½µÎ²á¾³ Ï†Î±Î½á½²Î½ Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ Ï†á½±Î¿Ï‚, the art. going with Ï†Î±Î½á½³Î½. This seems awkward. When a voc. is followed by a noun or partic. with art., this is normally in direct agreement with the voc., as á½¦ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎµÏ‚...Î¿á¼± Ï€Î±Ïá½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ (Plat. Prot. 337C), as if here we had á¼¡ Ï†Î±Î½Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ±. The Schol., who prefers this constr., shirks the difficulty by his paraphrase, á½¦ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼€ÎºÏ„á¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼¡Î»á½·Î¿Ï… Ï†á¿¶Ï‚, Ï„á½¸ Ï†Î±Î½á½²Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î».

á¼‘Ï€Ï„Î±Ï€á½»Î»á¿³: epithet of Î˜á½µÎ²Î· in Od. 11.263, Hes. Op. 161, as á¼‘ÎºÎ±Ï„á½¹Î¼Ï€Ï…Î»Î¿Î¹ in Il. 9.383 of Î˜á¿†Î²Î±Î¹ Î‘á¼°Î³á½»Ï€Ï„Î¹Î±Î¹.

Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½³ÏÏ‰Î½: cp. 1212f.: Thuc. 1.10 ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Îµá½·Î±Î½...Î¼ÎµÎ³á½·ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½...Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€Ïá½¸ Î±á½Ï„á¿†Ï‚. Tacitus Hist. 1. 50 solus omnium ante se principum. Milton P. Line 103

á¼Ï†á½±Î½Î¸Î·Ï‚ with an echo of Ï†Î±Î½á½³Î½ (Ï€Î±Ïá½µÏ‡Î·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚): cp. O.C. 794 ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î± | ...ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹Î½.

Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½³Î±Ï‚, with Ï…^ as O.T. 157, 188. So Pind. Pyth. 4.4 á¼”Î½Î¸Î± Ï€Î¿Ï„á½² Ï‡ÏÏ…^Ïƒá½³Ï‰Î½ Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ Î±á¼°Î·Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€á½±ÏÎµÎ´ÏÎ¿Ï‚. The Ï…^ was admitted by the lyrists, and from them borrowed by the dramatists, though only in lyrics, and even there only occasionally. Homer never shortens the Ï…: for, as Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½³á¿³ á¼€Î½á½° ÏƒÎºá½µÏ€Ï„Ïá¿³ (Il. 1.15) shows, the Homeric Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½³Î·Ï‚ (etc.) must be treated as disyll. by synizesis.

The words Ï„á½¸Î½ Î»Îµá½»ÎºÎ±ÏƒÏ€Î¹Î½ á¼ˆÏÎ³á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ answer metrically to 123 Ï€ÎµÏ…Îºá½±ÎµÎ½Î¸â€™ á¼­Ï†Î±Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ á¼‘Î»Îµá¿–Î½. Instead of á¼ˆÏÎ³á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ (Â¯Ë˜Â¯) we therefore require Â¯Ë˜Ë˜Â¯. The short final of Î»Îµá½»ÎºÎ±ÏƒÏ€Î¹Î½ is legitimate, the metre being Glyconic (see Analysis Metr.). In the antistrophic verse, the H of á¼­Ï†Î±Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ is â€˜irrational,â€™ i.e. is a long syllable doing duty for a short: and Nauck is incorrect in saying that the metre â€˜requiresâ€™ (though it admits) a choriambus beginning with a consonant. The simplest remedy is to read á¼ˆÏÎ³á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼Îº | Î²á½±Î½Ï„Î± Ï†á¿¶Ï„Î±, and to suppose that, after the loss of á¼Îº, Î²á½±Î½Ï„Î± and Ï†á¿¶Ï„Î± were accidentally transposed. Cp. O. Dindorf reads á¼Îº Ï†á¿¶Ï„Î± Î²á½±Î½Ï„Î±, assuming tmesis: but tmesis of á¼Îº in Soph. occurs elsewhere only before Î¼á½³Î½ (Tr. 1053) or Î´á½³, and there was no motive here for interposing Ï†á¿¶Ï„Î±. Hermann reads á¼ˆÏÎ³á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼”Îº as=á¼Î¾ á¼ˆÏÎ³á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½: but elsewhere á¼Îº comes before, not after, such forms (á¼Î¾ Î‘á¼°Ïƒá½»Î¼Î·Î¸ÎµÎ½, Il. 8.304: á¼Î¾ á¼Î»á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½, á¼Î¾ Î¿á½ÏÎ±Î½á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½, etc.). If á¼ˆÏÎ³á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ is not genuine, then it was probably a gloss on some other form in â€Î¸ÎµÎ½. Had Î³á¾¶Ï‚ Î á½³Î»Î¿Ï€Î¿Ï‚ (or Î”Î±Î½Î±Î¿á¿¦) been in the text, a scholiast would have been more apt to paraphrase with á¼€Ï€â€™ or á¼Î¾ á¼ŒÏÎ³Î¿Ï…Ï‚. I had thought of á¼¸Î½Î±Ï‡á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½, which Mekler, too, has suggested, though he has not supported it by argument. Ï€Ïá½¹Î´ÏÎ¿Î¼Î¿Î½, â€˜running forward,â€™ i.e. â€˜in headlong hasteâ€™: Aesch. Th. 211á¼Ï€á½¶ Î´Î±Î¹Î¼á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ Ï€Ïá½¹Î´ÏÎ¿Î¼Î¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î»Î¸Î¿Î½ á¼€Ï|Ï‡Î±á¿–Î± Î²Ïá½³Ï„Î·. In prose, always of precursors (as heralds, or an advanced guard).

á½€Î¾Ï…Ï„á½³Ïá¿³...Ï‡Î±Î»Î¹Î½á¿·, â€˜in swifter career,â€™ dat. of manner with Ï†Ï…Î³á½±Î´Î± Ï€Ïá½¹Î´ÏÎ¿Î¼Î¿Î½. Cp. O. The phrase seems happy in this context. The Argives began their retreat in the darkness (16): when the sun rises, the flashing steel of their bridles shows them in headlong flight.

á½€Î¾Ï…Ï„á½³Ïá¿³ does not mean (1) â€˜in flight swifter than their former approachâ€™; nor (2) that the reins are shaken ever faster on the horses' necks. á½€Î¾Ï…Ï„á½¹Ïá¿³ (L) was a mere blunder: it could only mean â€˜piercingâ€™ (the horse's mouth), not, â€˜giving a sharp sound,â€™ when the reins are shaken.â€”Cp. Line 110

The MSS. have á½ƒÎ½...Î Î¿Î»Ï…Î½Îµá½·ÎºÎ·Ï‚. If this were sound, it would be necessary to suppose that after á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½ a dipodia has been lost, such as Nauck supplies by <á¼¤Î³Î±Î³ÎµÎ½Â· á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î´â€™> á½€Î¾á½³Î± ÎºÎ»á½±Î¶Ï‰Î½. For (1) a verb is wanted to govern á½…Î½, and (2) the description of the eagle, beginning with á½€Î¾á½³Î± ÎºÎ»á½±Î¶Ï‰Î½, clearly refers to the Argive host, not to Polyneices only. But if, with Scaliger, we read á½ƒÏ‚ ...Î Î¿Î»Ï…Î½Îµá½·ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ï‚, no such loss need be assumed. The correspondence between anapaestic systems is not always strict, and the monometer á½€Î¾á½³Î± ÎºÎ»á½±Î¶Ï‰Î½ could stand here, though the anti-system has a dimeter in the same place (129). The MS. reading á½ƒÎ½...Î Î¿Î»Ï…Î½Îµá½·ÎºÎ·Ï‚ probably arose from a misunderstanding of the scholium:â€”á½…Î½Ï„Î¹Î½Î± ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼ˆÏÎ³Îµá½·Ï‰Î½, á¼Î¾ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½ Î½ÎµÎ¹Îºá½³Ï‰Î½ á¼€ÏÎ¸Îµá½·Ï‚, á¼¤Î³Î±Î³ÎµÎ½ á½ Î Î¿Î»Ï…Î½Îµá½·ÎºÎ·Ï‚, Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿Î³á½·á¾³ Ï‡ÏÎ·Ïƒá½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¹Î½Â· Î´Î¹á½° Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡á½³Ï‰Î½ Î´á½² Îµá¼¶Ï€ÎµÎ½ Î±á½Ï„á½¹, á½¡Ï‚ Î³Î½Ï‰Ïá½·Î¼Î¿Ï… Î¿á½”ÏƒÎ·Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î¸á½³ÏƒÎµÏ‰Ï‚. The Schol. wrote á¼€ÏÎ¸Îµá½·Ï‚, to agree with Î Î¿Î»Ï…Î½Îµá½·ÎºÎ·Ï‚, and not á¼€ÏÎ¸á½³Î½Ï„Î±, to agree with ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„á½¹Î½, because it suited the form of his paraphrase, Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿Î³á½·á¾³ Ï‡ÏÎ·Ïƒá½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¹Î½. á½€Î¾á½³Î± ÎºÎ»á½±Î¶Ï‰Î½: Homeric, Il. 17.88 (of Hector) á½€Î¾á½³Î± ÎºÎµÎºÎ»Î·Î³á½½Ï‚: Il. 16.429 Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Î± ÎºÎ»á½±Î¶Î¿Î½Ï„Îµ (of vultures fighting): so Aesch. Ag. 48 (the Atreidae) Î¼á½³Î³Î±Î½ á¼Îº Î¸Ï…Î¼Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ»á½±Î¶Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼ŒÏÎ·.

Î±á¼°ÎµÏ„á½¸Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î³á¾¶Î½ á½£Ï‚ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏá½³Ï€Ï„Î± seems clearly right. If á½¥Ï‚ is omitted, we have a metaphor instead of a simile, with harsh effect. Line 117

In ÏƒÏ„á½°Ï‚ Î´â€™ á½‘Ï€á½²Ï Î¼ÎµÎ»á½±Î¸ÏÏ‰Î½ there is a momentary return to the image of the flying eagle,â€”â€˜having stayed his flight above my dwellings,â€™â€”before swooping. The words do not mean that the Argive army was posted on hills around Thebes: the only hills available were to the N. of the town. The á¼¸ÏƒÎ¼á½µÎ½Î¹Î¿Ï‚ Î»á½¹Ï†Î¿Ï‚ (Paus. 9.10.2), on which Donaldson places the Argives, was merely a low eminence close to one of the city gates. Thebes stood on a low spur of ground projecting southward, and overlooking the plain. Sophocles has elsewhere described the Argive besiegers, with topographical correctness, as having â€˜set their leaguer round the plain of Thebesâ€™ (O. C. 1312 Ï„á½¸ Î˜á½µÎ²Î·Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÎ´á½·Î¿Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï†ÎµÏƒÏ„á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€á¾¶Î½). Struve's Ï€Ï„á½±Ï‚ (a participle not found elsewhere except in composition with a preposition) seems improbable, and also less forcible.

The words Ï†Î¿Î½á½½ÏƒÎ±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Ï‡Î±Î½á½¼Î½... Î»á½¹Î³Ï‡Î±Î¹Ï‚ once more merge the image of the eagle,â€”as at v. 115,â€”in literal description of a besieging army, save in so far as the figurative á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Ï‡Î±Î½á½½Î½ suggests a monster opening its jaws. The word was perh. suggested by Il. 23.79 á¼Î¼á½² Î¼á½²Î½ Îºá½´Ï | á¼€Î¼Ï†á½³Ï‡Î±Î½Îµ ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î³ÎµÏá½µ (hath gaped for meâ€”i.e. â€˜devoured meâ€™). These transitions from clear imagery to language in which the figure is blurred by the thought of the object for which it stands, are thoroughly Sophoclean: cp. n. on O. T. 866.

Ï†Î¿Î½á½½ÏƒÎ±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½: the word is not rare in later writers, but in classical Greek occurs only here and Ph. 1209Ï†Î¿Î½á¾·, Ï†Î¿Î½á¾· Î½á½¹Î¿Ï‚ á¼¤Î´Î·. Cp. Ï„Î¿Î¼á½±Ï‰ (Ai. 582).

á¼‘Ï€Ï„á½±Ï€Ï…Î»Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î±, prop. the access afforded by seven gates: fr. 701 Î˜á½µÎ²Î±Ï‚ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Ï€á½»Î»Î±Ï‚ á¼‘Ï€Ï„Î±ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ (sevenmouthed as to its gates). Ï€Î±Î»Ï„á¿· Ï€Ï…Ïá½·, i.e. with the thunderbolt which Zeus brandishes in his hand before hurling it: Aristoph. Av. 1714 Ï€á½±Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎµÏÎ±Ï…Î½á½¹Î½, Ï€Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï†á½¹ÏÎ¿Î½ Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ Î²á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚.

á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ï„á½»Ï€á¾³, restored by Porson (Aav. p. 169) for á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï„Ï…Ï€Î±, is certainly right. Adjectives in Î¿Ï‚, compounded with a prep., are oft. of three terminations in epic poetry, as á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÎµÎ»á½·ÏƒÏƒÎ·, á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Ïá½»Ï„Î·, á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Î¸á½³Î· (Od. 13.378), á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Î²Ïá½¹Ï„Î· (Il. 2.389), á½‘Ï€Î¿Î´ÎµÎ¾á½·Î· (Il. 9.73), etc. The dramatists could admit some such forms, esp. in lyrics; thus they have á¼¡ á¼Î½Î±Î»á½·Î± as well as á¼¡ á¼Î½á½±Î»Î¹Î¿Ï‚, á¼¡ á¼Î½Î½Ï…Ï‡á½·Î± as well as á¼¡ á¼Î½Î½á½»Ï‡Î¹Î¿Ï‚.

As regards the sense, á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï„Ï…Ï€Î¿Ï‚ was regularly used of hard surfaces, which, as it were, repel that which strikes them (for the accent á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï„Ï…Ï€Î¿Ï‚, not á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ï„á½»Ï€Î¿Ï‚, though the sense is act., see on O. T. 460). Probl. 5. 40 Î¿á¼±...á¼Î½ á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ï„á½»Ï€Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÏá½·Ï€Î±Ï„Î¿Î¹. Lucian Amor. 13 Ï„á½´Î½ á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï„Ï…Ï€Î¿Î½ Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±ÏÏ„ÎµÏá½°Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î»á½·Î¸Î¿Ï… Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½. So, fig., Plat. Crat. 420D Ï„á½¸...á¼€Î½Î±Î³ÎºÎ±á¿–Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï„Ï…Ï€Î¿Î½, what is necessary, and what resists us.

Ï„Î±Î½Ï„Î±Î»Ï‰Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚, â€˜swung,â€™ that is, sent flying through the air from the edge of the wall on which he was just setting foot. The word expresses the force with which the thunderbolt struck him, just as á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ï„á½»Ï€á¾³ expresses the crash when he struck earth. This form of the verb occurs only here. Arist. uses both Ï„Î±Î»Î±Î½Ï„Îµá½»Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ (pass.) and Ï„Î±Î»Î±Î½Ï„Îµá½»Ï‰ (act. intr.) as â€˜to sway to and fro.â€™ The Schol., explaining by Î´Î¹Î±ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎ¸Îµá½·Ï‚ (i.e. â€˜with a rude shock,â€™ which is substantially right) quotes Anacreon 78 [á¼Î½] Î¼ÎµÎ»Î±Î¼Ï†á½»Î»Î»á¿³ Î´á½±Ï†Î½á¾³ Ï‡Î»Ï‰Ïá¾· Ï„â€™ á¼Î»Î±á½·á¾³ Ï„Î±Î½Ï„Î±Î»á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹ (where the subject was perh. a god, or the wind).

Ï€Ï…ÏÏ†á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚, â€˜torch in handâ€™: so of Prometheus (O. C. 55, where see n.) and Artemis (O. T. 207). Aesch. Th. 433Ï†Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹ Î´á½² Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½°Ï‚ Î´Î¹á½° Ï‡ÎµÏá¿¶Î½ á½¡Ï€Î»Î¹ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î·Â· | Ï‡ÏÏ…ÏƒÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ Î´á½² Ï†Ï‰Î½Îµá¿– Î³Ïá½±Î¼Î¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½, Ï€Ïá½µÏƒÏ‰ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½.

Î²Î±ÎºÏ‡Îµá½»Ï‰Î½: so oft. Eur. as H. F. 898 Î›á½»ÏƒÏƒÎ± Î²Î±ÎºÏ‡Îµá½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹: but this is the only place where Soph. connects evil frenzy with the name of a god whom this same Ode invokes (154).

á¿¥Î¹Ï€Î±á¿–Ï‚...á¼€Î½á½³Î¼Ï‰Î½. Capaneus, breathing fury and slaughter, is likened to a deadly tempest. For á¿¥Î¹Ï€Î±á½·, â€˜blasts,â€™ cp. 929 and O. C. 1248 n. So Aesch. Th. 63Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î¹Î³á½·ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï€Î½Î¿á½°Ï‚ | á¼ŒÏÎµÏ‰Ï‚.

Î²Î±ÎºÏ‡Îµá½»Ï‰Î½ á¼Ï€á½³Ï€Î½ÎµÎ¹
á¿¥Î¹Ï€Î±á¿–Ï‚ á¼Ï‡Î¸á½·ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½ á¼€Î½á½³Î¼Ï‰Î½.
Îµá¼¶Ï‡Îµ Î´â€™ á¼„Î»Î»á¾³ Ï„á½° Î¼á½³Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 138

Îµá¼¶Ï‡Îµ Î´â€™ á¼„Î»Î»á¾³ Ï„á½° Î¼á½³Î½, â€˜but those things indeedâ€™ (the threats of Capaneus) â€˜went otherwiseâ€™ (than he had expected): á¼„Î»Î»Î± Î´â€™ á¼Ï€â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î¼á½³Î³Î±Ï‚ á¼ŒÏÎ·Ï‚ á¼Ï€ÎµÎ½á½½Î¼Î±, â€˜while to others great Ares assigned various dooms,â€™ etc. The poet has described how Zeus smote the most formidable foe. As to the other Argive chiefs, he briefly adds that Ares struck them down by various deaths: i.e. they perished, not by a stroke from heaven, but in the course of battle. In L's reading, Îµá¼¶Ï‡Îµ Î´â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î±Î¹ Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ á¼„Î»Î»Î±Î¹ Ï„á½° Î´â€™ á¼Ï€â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î¹Ï‚, one cause of corruption has evidently been a confusion between alternative modes of expressing â€˜someâ€™ and â€˜other,â€™ viz. (1) by doubled á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚, (2) by Ï„á½° Î¼á½³Î½, Ï„á½° Î´á½³. It is in favour of our reading (Erfurdt's) that it helps to account for this, since it supposes that Ï„á½° Î¼á½³Î½ was answered by á¼„Î»Î»Î± Î´á½³. Cp. O. C. 1671 Î¿á½ Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³Î½, á¼„Î»Î»Î¿ Î´á½² Î¼á½µ: Il. 6.147 Ï„á½° Î¼á½³Î½ Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½ÎµÎ¼Î¿Ï‚ Ï‡Î±Î¼á½±Î´Î¹Ï‚ Ï‡á½³ÎµÎ¹, á¼„Î»Î»Î± Î´á½³ Î¸â€™ á½•Î»Î· | Ï„Î·Î»ÎµÎ¸á½¹Ï‰ÏƒÎ± Ï†á½»ÎµÎ¹. It is immaterial that, here, Ï„á½° Î¼á½³Î½ means, not, â€˜some things,â€™ but, â€˜those thingsâ€™; since the latter is its first sense also where we render it by â€˜some.â€™ Further, with regard to á¼„Î»Î»á¾³, remark that this form of adverb is used elsewhere also in ref. to the course ordained by gods or fate: O. PV 511 Î¿á½ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Ï„Î±á½»Ï„á¿ƒ Î¼Î¿á¿–Ïá½± Ï€Ï‰ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏƒÏ†á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚ | ÎºÏá¾¶Î½Î±Î¹ Ï€á½³Ï€ÏÏ‰Ï„Î±Î¹. For other proposed readings, see Appendix.

á¼Ï€ÎµÎ½á½½Î¼Î±: Aesch. Eum. 310 Î»á½±Ï‡Î· Ï„á½° ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼€Î½Î¸Ïá½½Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ | á½¡Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹Î½Ï‰Î¼á¾· ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ á¼Î¼á½±, apportions.â€” ÏƒÏ„Ï…Ï†ÎµÎ»á½·Î¶Ï‰Î½ (ÏƒÏ„Ï…^Ï†ÎµÎ»á½¹Ï‚, â€˜firm,â€™ ÏƒÏ„Ï…â€”/Ï†Ï‰, to compress), â€˜striking heavilyâ€™: Il. 1.581 á¼Î¾ á¼‘Î´á½³Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÏ„Ï…Ï†ÎµÎ»á½·Î¾Î±Î¹.

Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¹ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚, â€˜right-hand trace-horse,â€™ here means a vigorous ally, who does more than his own share of the work. Ares has brought the Theban chariot victoriously through the crisis of the race against its Argive rival. In the fourhorse chariot-race the four horses were harnessed abreast: the two in the middle were under the yoke (Î¶á½»Î³Î¹Î¿Î¹), being called á½ Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¹Ï‚ and á½ Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½¹Ï‚ (schol. Aristoph. Nub. 122): the two outside horses drew in traces (ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏÎ±á¿–Î¿Î¹). The chariot went down the right-hand side of the course, turned sharply from right to left at the distance-post (ÎºÎ±Î¼Ï€Ï„á½µÏ, Î½á½»ÏƒÏƒÎ±), and came back down the left side. Hence, at the turning-point, the right-hand tracehorse had most work to do; and the best horse was put in that place. Cp. El. 721 (at the turning-post) Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¹Î½ Ï„â€™ á¼€Î½Îµá½¶Ï‚ | ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏÎ±á¿–Î¿Î½ á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Î½ Îµá¼¶ÏÎ³Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎµá½·Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½. Plat. Symp. 4. 6á¼ÏÎ¼Î±Ï„Î·Î»Î±Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± Î´Îµá¿– á¼Î³Î³á½ºÏ‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„á½µÎ»Î·Ï‚ Îºá½±Î¼ÏˆÎ±Î¹, quoting from Il. 23.336 the precept Ï„á½¸Î½ Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¸Î½ á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Î½ | Îºá½³Î½ÏƒÎ±Î¹ á½Î¼Î¿ÎºÎ»á½µÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„â€™, Îµá¼¶Î¾Î±á½· Ï„á½³ Î¿á¼± á¼¡Î½á½·Î± Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½·Î½. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 842 Î¶ÎµÏ…Ï‡Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ á¼•Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏÎ±Ï†á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (said by Agam. of Odysseus): and cp. ib. 1640.

The old v.l. Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚, explained by the schol. Î³ÎµÎ½Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Î´á½³Î¾Î¹Î¿Ï‚, is read by Musgrave, Hartung, and Pallis. Hartung A. renders it â€˜der Starke,â€™â€”understanding it as â€˜the strong and deft striker.â€™ Neither Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚ nor Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï seems to occur, though á¼€ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï (left-handed) is found in late Greek.

Î§Î¿. á¼‘Ï€Ï„á½° Î»Î¿Ï‡Î±Î³Î¿á½¶ Î³á½°Ï á¼Ï†â€™ á¼‘Ï€Ï„á½° Ï€á½»Î»Î±Î¹Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 141

á¼‘Ï€Ï„á½° Î»Î¿Ï‡Î±Î³Î¿á½·. In O. C. 1313 ff. the list agrees with that of Aesch. ,â€” Amphiaraus, Tydeus, Eteoclus, Hippomedon, Capaneus, Parthenopaeus, Polyneices. (Adrastus, who escaped, is not counted as one of the seven.) Capaneus, though not slain by human hand, is included, since he was vanquished. Amphiaraus, according to the legend which Soph. recognises in El. 837, was swallowed up by the earth, but seems here to be reckoned among those who fell in fight (cp. n. on O. C. 1313).

Pers. 47 Î´á½·ÏÏÏ…Î¼á½± Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Ïá½·ÏÏÏ…Î¼Î± Ï„á½³Î»Î·.

It was the ordinary practice to set up a Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î±Î¹Î¿Î½ (old Î±Ï„Ï„.Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï€Î±á¿–Î¿Î½) after a victory, on the spot where it had been won, or, in the case of a sea-fight, on the nearest land (Thuc. 2.92). Such a trophy ordinarily consisted of shields, helmets, and weapons, conspicuously displayed on wooden supports, and dedicated, with an inscription, to a deity. Cp. Eur. Phoen. 1473 (of the Thebans after the victory) Î¿á¼± Î¼á½²Î½ Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï€Î±á¿–Î¿Î½ á¼µÏƒÏ„Î±ÏƒÎ±Î½ Î²Ïá½³Ï„Î±Ï‚ (i.e. a wooden image of Î–Îµá½ºÏ‚ Î¤ÏÎ¿Ï€Î±á¿–Î¿Ï‚), | Î¿á¼± Î´â€™ á¼€ÏƒÏ€á½·Î´Î±Ï‚ ÏƒÏ…Î»á¿¶Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼ˆÏÎ³Îµá½·Ï‰Î½ Î½ÎµÎºÏá¿¶Î½ | ÏƒÎºÏ…Î»Îµá½»Î¼Î±Ï„â€™ Îµá¼´ÏƒÏ‰ Ï„ÎµÎ¹Ï‡á½³Ï‰Î½ á¼Ï€á½³Î¼Ï€Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½. Ï€Î»á½´Î½ Ï„. ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î³ÎµÏÎ¿á¿–Î½, â€˜wretchedâ€™ (as Ph. 166): not, â€˜hateful,â€™ nor, â€˜filled with hate.â€™ Of the seven Argive leaders, Polyneices was the only one who could not properly be said to have been vanquished, since he was not more vanquished than victorious. But, in excepting him, the poet associates him with the brother who was his victim as well as his conqueror. á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ï‡Î±ÏÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ±, with gladness responsive to that of ThebÃ¨. The goddess NikÃ¨ has come to meet the victors, and their joy is reflected in her radiant smile. á¼€Î»Î»á½° â€¦ Î³á½±Ï: see on 148.â€” ÎšÏá½³Ï‰Î½, monosyll. by synizesis, as Ï€Î»á½³Ï‰Î½ Od. 1.183; in Aesch. Ag. 1493 á¼ÎºÏ€Î½á½³Ï‰Î½ is a spondee. Cp. O. C. 1073 *(Ï€á½³Î±Ï‚, a monosyll.

ÎœÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹Îºá½³Ï‰Ï‚,=Ë˜Â¯Â¯, as O. C. 1003 Î˜Î·Ïƒá½³Ï‰Ï‚ (Â¯Â¯), and so oft.

Î½ÎµÎ¿Ï‡Î¼á½¸Ï‚ Î½ÎµÎ±ÏÎ±á¿–ÏƒÎ¹. Neither adj. is suspicious; new events have made a new ruler; and the doubled adj. is quite in the poet's manner. Three views of the metre have been taken. (1) That v. 156 should be enlarged to a dimeter by supplying one anapaest or its equivalent. (2) That v. 156 should be reduced to a monometer by omitting Î½ÎµÎ¿Ï‡Î¼á½¹Ï‚ or ÎœÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹Îºá½³Ï‰Ï‚. (3) That both v. 156 and v. 160 should be made dimeters by supplying three anapaests or

their equivalents. See Appendix I prefer the first of these views. An anapaest or spondee, meaning â€˜ruler,â€™ has probably dropped out before Î½ÎµÎ¿Ï‡Î¼á½¹Ï‚. Seyffert's ÎºÏÎµá½·Ï‰Î½ is at first sight attractive, as accounting for its own disappearance; but, since it is the same word as ÎšÏá½³Ï‰Î½â€” which had an epic form ÎšÏÎµá½·Ï‰Î½, as conversely Pind. and Aesch. use ÎºÏá½³Ï‰Î½â€”this would be rather a feeble pun than a strong Ï€Î±Ïá½µÏ‡Î·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚. Either á¼„ÏÏ‡Ï‰Î½ or Ï„Î±Î³á½¹Ï‚ is possible.

ÎšÎ¡á¿‰Î©Î
á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎµÏ‚, Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Î´á½´ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€ÏƒÏ†Î±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½¶ ğŸ—©
Line 162162-210

There is a general dramatic analogy between this speech and that of Oedipus in O. T. 216â€”275. In each case a Theban king addresses Theban elders, announcing a stern decree, adopted in reliance on his own wisdom, and promulgated with haughty consciousness of power; the elders receive the decree with a submissive deference under which we can perceive traces of misgiving; and as the drama proceeds, the elders become spectators of calamities occasioned by the decree, while its author turns to them for comfort.

Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Î´á½´ Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ . . á½‘Î¼á¾¶Ï‚ Î´â€™. The perils of the war are now over; the affairs of civil government claim my next care; and I have therefore sent for you, the nearest supporters of my throne.

Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ occurs only here in Soph. , but twice in the trimeters of Aesch. ( Aesch. Th. 218, Suppl. 344), and thrice in those of Eur. ( Eur. Or. 897, El. 412, Ion 595). Eur. has also in trimeters á½„Ï†ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ ( Eur. Bacch. 1027, Eur. Bacch. 1331, Suppl. 703), and Îºá½¹Î½ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ ( Cycl. 641). In Comedy we find á½•Î²ÏÎµÎ¿Ï‚ ( Ar. Th. 465, Plut. 1044), and Ï†á½»ÏƒÎµÎ¿Ï‚ (Vesp. 1282, 1458). Such forms, which metrical convenience recommended to Attic poets, must not be confounded with the Ionic genitives in Î¹, such as Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î¿Ï‚. The gen. Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÏ…Ï‚, contracted from Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¿Ï‚, is used by Theogn. 776 etc.â€” Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿· Ïƒá½±Î»á¿³ ÏƒÎµá½·ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚. Cp. O. T. 22.

The image of the State as a ship dates in Greek literature from Alcaeus (whom Horace copied, Carm. 1. 14), fr. 18. The ship of Alcaeus is labouring in the trough of a wild sea,â€”water is coming in,â€”the sail is torn,â€”the anchor will not hold: Î½á¾¶ÏŠ Ï†Î¿Ïá½µÎ¼ÎµÎ¸Î± Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î±á½·Î½á¾³ | Ï‡Îµá½·Î¼Ï‰Î½Î¹ Î¼Î¿Ï‡Î¸Îµá¿¦Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»á¿³ Î¼á½±Î»Î±, Îº.Ï„.Î». It is only through Heracleides Alleg. Homer. 5 that we know the meaning of Alcaeus to have been figurative and political. Aesch. often uses the image ( Aesch. Th. 2, Aesch. Th. 62, Aesch. Th. 208 etc.). Creon returns to it at 189. It is peculiarly well suited to his point,â€”the unity of the public interest.

á¼¡Î½á½·Îºâ€™ ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». The only obscurity arises from the use of the plur. ÎºÎµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½ in 168. ÎºÎµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½ Ï€Î±á¿–Î´Î±Ï‚ ought to mean, â€˜the descendants of LaÃ¯us and Oedipus,â€™ viz. Eteocles and Polyneices. The relative clause, á¼¡Î½á½·Îºâ€™ . . á½¤ÏÎ¸Î¿Ï… Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½, induced the poet to add immediately the other relative clause to which the same person is subject, viz. á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ Î´Î¹á½½Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿, instead of inserting, after á½¤ÏÎ¸Î¿Ï… Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½, words expressing their loyalty to Oedipus. ÎºÎ±á½· (in Îºá¼€Ï€Îµá½¶) would scarcely have been thus used to introduce a distinct third clause. Evidently ÎºÎ±á½· links á¼¡Î½á½·ÎºÎ± á½¤ÏÎ¸Î¿Ï… to á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ Î´Î¹á½½Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿.

á¼Î¼Ï€á½³Î´Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á½µÎ¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½, with steadfast sentiments (of loyalty), modal dat., as oft. á½…Ï„Îµ causal, O. T. 918 n.

Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á¿†Ï‚ Î¼.: cp. 14 n.: for Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚, 51 n.: for Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á¿†Ï‚ . . Î¼á½·Î±Î½, 13 n.

Ï€Î±á½·ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ . . Ï€Î»Î·Î³á½³Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚. In Attic prose the verb â€˜to strikeâ€™ usu. had as pres. Ï„á½»Ï€Ï„Ï‰ (or Ï€Î±á½·Ï‰), fut. Ï„Ï…Ï€Ï„á½µÏƒÏ‰ (or Ï€Î±Ï„á½±Î¾Ï‰), aor. á¼Ï€á½±Ï„Î±Î¾Î±, aor. pass. á¼Ï€Î»á½µÎ³Î·Î½. The aor. of Ï€Î±á½·Ï‰ is mainly a poetical word, used in tragedy, more rarely in comedy, and by Xenophon. In Attic prose á¼”Ï€Î±Î¹ÏƒÎ± is usu. the aor. of Ï€Î±á½·Î¶Ï‰. Meineke proposed Ï€Î»á½µÎ¾Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ here, but that aor. (except in comp. with a prep.) is almost unknown to classical Î±Ï„Ï„Î¹Î¾. Ï€Î±Î¹ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, again, though that aor. pass. occurs twice in Aesch. , is very rare.

Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¹ â€¦ Î¼Î¹á½±ÏƒÎ¼Î±Ï„Î¹, the stain of a kinsman's murder (see on 51, and cp. 1176): cp. Aesch. Th. 849ÎºÎ±Îºá½° | Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï†á½¹Î½Î±. Ïƒá½»Î½, as 1266 Î½á½³á¿³ Î¾á½ºÎ½ Î¼á½¹Ïá¿³: O. C. 1663, Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î¹Ï‚: Pind. O. 2. 42Ïƒá½ºÎ½ á¼€Î»Î»Î±Î»Î¿Ï†Î¿Î½á½·á¾³.

ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±Î½ á½¤Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿ Ï€Î±á½·ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„á½³Ï‚ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶

á¼Î³á½¼ . . Î´á½µ, I now: where Î´á½µ nearly=á¼¤Î´Î·, O. T. 968 n. Aesch. Eum. 3 (after Gaia came Themis) á¼£ Î´á½´ Ï„á½¸ Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î´ÎµÏ…Ï„á½³ÏÎ± Ï„á½¹Î´â€™ á¼•Î¶ÎµÏ„Î¿ | Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Îµá¿–Î¿Î½.

ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·: cp. 166.

Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá¿–Î± Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½€Î»., by nearness of kinship to the dead, Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá¿–Î± forming one notion, on which the genit. Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½€Î». depends, as on words meaning â€˜near.â€™ The neut. plur. á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá¿–Î± (only here) would most properly mean â€˜rightsâ€™ or â€˜privilegesâ€™ of such nearness (cp. á¼€ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá¿–Î±, Ï€ÏÏ‰Ï„Îµá¿–Î±, etc.), but seems here to be merely a poetical equiv. for the abstract á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Î±. In Attic law á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Î± was any degree of relationship on which a claim to an inheritance could be founded in the absence of a will otherwise disposing of it. To claim an inheritance under a will was á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÏƒÎ²Î·Ï„Îµá¿–Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î´Î¹Î±Î¸á½µÎºÎ·Î½: to claim on the ground of relationship, á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÏƒÎ²Î·Ï„Îµá¿–Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Î±Î½. ÏƒÏ…Î³Î³á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹Î±, consanguinity, might, or might not, constitute á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Î±: e.g. Isaeus says of the relationship of mother to son that it is ÏƒÏ…Î³Î³ÎµÎ½á½³ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î¿Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï„á¿‡ Ï†á½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½, á¼Î½ Î´á½² Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Î±Î¹Ï‚ á½Î¼Î¿Î»Î¿Î³Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Ï‚ Î¿á½Îº á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ (or. 11 Â§ 17), since a mother could not inherit from her son. (See Selections from the Attic Orators, pp. 331, 344.) Creon succeeds as the nearest male relative. Aesch. , Soph. , and Eur. ignore the Boeotian legend which gave a son, Laodamas, to Eteocles (Her. 5.61), and a son, Thersander, to Polyneices (id. 4. 147, etc.). The sisters represent the á¼ÏƒÏ‡á½±Ï„Î· á¿¥á½·Î¶Î± (599).

Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá¿–Î± Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½€Î»Ï‰Î»á½¹Ï„Ï‰Î½.
175 á¼€Î¼á½µÏ‡Î±Î½Î¿Î½ Î´á½² Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼ÎºÎ¼Î±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 175

á¼€Î¼á½µÏ‡Î±Î½Î¿Î½ Î´á½³. â€˜You were loyal to the kings whose successor I am. Now (Î´á½³) a man cannot be really known until he has been tried in office. (I do not, therefore, ask you to pledge your loyalty to me until I have been so tested.) I will, however, tell you the principles which I intend to observe.â€™ Thus Î´á½³ merely marks the transition to a new topic. It is not directly adversative, as if he meant: â€˜You were loyal to my predecessors, but I do not yet ask you to be loyal to me.â€™ On that view, however, the general connection of thoughts would remain the same.

Demosthenes, in his speech on the Embassy (343 B.C.), quotes this passage (vv. 175â€”190) as illustrating maxims

which Aeschines had violated, though, accustomed as he had been to play tritagonists' parts, he ought to have known them by heart (or. 19 Â§ 247).

á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±á¿–Ï‚, duties of administration. Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ has a general sense: the king is concerned with Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹ both as Î½Î¿Î¼Î¿Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ and as Î½Î¿Î¼Î¿Î¸á½³Ï„Î·Ï‚: but, as the context suggests, it is of law-giving that Creon is more particularly thinking. á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ Î³á½±Ï. á¼Î³á½¼ Î³á½±Ï. Here, as in á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ Î³á½±Ï above (178), Î³á½±Ï introduces a reason; but here, again, the connection is obscured by the form of the sentence. The reason is contained in Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Î³Î¹Î³Î½á½½ÏƒÎºÏ‰Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». (188). â€˜I have no esteem for a man who prefers popularity or private friendship to the good of the State (178â€” 183); for (184) I well know that all private welfare depends on the welfare of the State; and so I should never commit the faults which I have just condemned in others.â€™â€”á¼´ÏƒÏ„Ï‰ is confirmed against the conjecture á¼´ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Ï (or á¼µÏƒÏ„Ï‰Ï) by those passages in which it is joined with an accus., as Il. 7.411 á½…ÏÎºÎ¹Î± Î´á½² Î–Îµá½ºÏ‚ á¼´ÏƒÏ„Ï‰, 15. 36 á¼´ÏƒÏ„Ï‰ Î½á¿¦Î½ Ï„Î¿Î´Îµ Î“Î±á¿–Î±, etc.

185 Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼‚Î½ ÏƒÎ¹Ï‰Ï€á½µÏƒÎ±Î¹Î¼Î¹ Ï„á½´Î½ á¼„Ï„Î·Î½ á½Ïá¿¶Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 185

Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼‚Î½ ÏƒÎ¹Ï‰Ï€á½µÏƒÎ±Î¹Î¼Î¹. Applied to the actual case, Creon's words mean, â€˜I should never be deterred by fear of popular murmurs (cp. 692 ff.) from publishing such an edict as this against burying Polyneices, when I clearly saw that otherwise a disastrous precedent would be set. And though Polyneices was my nephew, I should never allow myself to recognise as friend or kinsman a man who had borne arms against the country.â€™

ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼€ÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼€Î½Ï„á½¶ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÏƒÏ‰Ï„Î·Ïá½·Î±Ï‚, ğŸ—©
Line 186

ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼€ÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿–Ï‚. Demosthenes paraphrases this by ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ (or. 19 Â§ 248); whence Dobree and Shilleto surmised that he read á¼†ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½ (cp. O. C. 312 ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½ á¼†ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½). Now I think that I can explain why Demosthenes so paraphrased. He is applying the verses to Aeschines (see above, n. on 182): Ï„á½´Î½ Î´á½² á¼„Ï„Î·Î½ á½Ïá¿¶Î½ ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦, Ï„á½´Î½ á¼Ï€á½¶ Î¦Ï‰Îºá½³Î±Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Îµá½·Î±Î½, Î¿á½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Îµá¿–Ï€ÎµÎ½ Î¿á½Î´á½² Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎµÎ¾á½µÎ³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î»ÎµÎ½. The á¼„Ï„Î· which Aeschines saw approaching was the interference of Philip in the Sacred War,â€”his action against the Phocians. If Demosthenes had said ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼€ÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿–Ï‚, this must have seemed to refer to the fellow-citizens of Aeschines, â€”the Athenians. The orator therefore modified the poet's phrase by substituting á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦,â€”a word vague enough to suggest the concern of other Greek states besides Phocis in the peril.

á¼€Î½Ï„á½¶ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÏƒÏ‰Ï„Î·Ïá½·Î±Ï‚, added for emphasis; â€˜ruin, and not welfare, which a king is bound to promote.â€™ (The art. Ï„á¿†Ï‚ is merely generic, as in Ï„á½´Î½ á¼„Ï„Î·Î½.) So Tr. 267 Ï†Î±Î½Îµá½¶Ï‚ Î´á½² Î´Î¿á¿¦Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼€Î½Ï„â€™ á¼Î»ÎµÏ…Î¸á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…, a slave, and not a free man (as he ought to be): O. á¼¡ Ïƒá¿´Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±, â€˜who bears us safe.â€™ Ïƒá¿´Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ was esp. said of a ship or its captain: cp. Plat. Gorg. 511D á¼á½°Î½.. á¼Î¾ Î‘á¼°Î³á½·Î½Î·Ï‚ Î´Îµá¿¦ÏÎ¿ Ïƒá½½Ïƒá¿ƒ, if she (á¼¡ ÎºÏ…Î²ÎµÏÎ½Î·Ï„Î¹Îºá½µ) has carried us safely from Aegina to Athens.

Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î·Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». It is only while she remains upright, as we sail on board of her, that we can make real friends. á½€ÏÎ¸á¿†Ï‚ (like á½¤ÏÎ¸Ï‰ÏƒÎ±Î½ in 163) refers to the ship maintaining a safe stability, as opposed to capsizing: the contrast is given by á½‘Ï€Ï„á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚..Ïƒá½³Î»Î¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½..Î½Î±Ï…Ï„á½·Î»Î»ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ in 716 (where see n.). Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ¸Î±, we make the friends (whom we really make): since friends made at the cost of endangering or wrecking the ship of the State cannot properly be considered friends at all: they are Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹ á¼„Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿Î¹.
