Line 198

L has Î Î¿Î»Ï…Î½Îµá½·ÎºÎ·Î½ here, but Î Î¿Î»Ï…Î½Îµá½·ÎºÎ· in O. C. 375. Both forms are sound. From about 400 B.C. the Attic tendency of proper names in â€Î·Ï‚ was to pass from the 3rd to the 1st declension. Attic inscriptions of circ. 410â€”350 B.C. give the acc. in -Î·Î½ more often than that in -Î·. From c. 350 to 30 B.C. the gen. in -Î¿Ï… is far more frequent than that in -Î¿Ï…Ï‚. Even proper names in -ÎºÎ»á½³Î·Ï‚, which kept the acc. in -ÎºÎ»á½³Î± to c. 300 B.C., afterwards formed it in -ÎºÎ»á¿†Î½. (No Attic inscript. gives -ÎºÎ»á¿†.)

Î³)Î¸á½³Î»Î·ÏƒÎµ Î¼á½³Î½ â€¦ á¼ Î¸á½³Î». Î´á½³, rhetor. epanaphora (O. C. 610 Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î¼á½³Î½ . . Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î´á½³). Since Ï€á½±ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ cannot govern Î³á¿†Î½ . . ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½»Ï‚, á¼ Î¸á½³Î»Î·ÏƒÎµ Î¼á½²Î½ should in strictness have preceded Î³á¿†Î½.

The traditional á¼ÎºÎºÎµÎºÎ·Ïá¿¦Ï‡Î¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á½±Ï†á¿³ can be explained only by supplying Î»á½³Î³Ï‰ or the like. Î´á½³Î¼Î±Ï‚ of a corpse, as 903, El. 756, Eur. Or. 40 etc.: in Hom. always of the living, who has Ïƒá¿¶Î¼Î± only of the dead: in Attic Ïƒá¿¶Î¼Î± is said of either.

In Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½· Ï€Î¿á½» Î³â€™ the enclitic Ï€Î¿Ï… closely adheres to Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½·, and Î³Îµ emphasises the whole expression; as in El. 1506, á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ Ï€á½³ÏÎ± Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ Î³Îµ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î½á½¹Î¼Ï‰Î½ Î¸á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹, the Î³Îµ emphasises the whole phrase Ï€á½³ÏÎ± Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½. á½¡Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ â€¦ á¼¦Ï„Îµ can be explained only by an ellipse of á¼Ï€Î¹Î¼ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Îµ or the like. ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Î¿á½·, Ï†á½»Î»Î±ÎºÎµÏ‚, who watch to see that no one breaks the edict.

ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á¿‡ Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Ï‚, reluctantly and slowly; the opposite of Ïƒá½ºÎ½ ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ï…Î´á¿‡ Ï„Î±Ï‡á½»Ï‚ ( Ph. 1223), with eagerness and speed. ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á¿‡ oft.=â€˜at a slow paceâ€™ (Ï€Î¿ÏÎµá½»ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, Xen. Anab. 4.1.16; á½‘Ï€Î¿Ï‡Ï‰ÏÎµá¿–Î½, Thuc. 3.78). As Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Ï‚ could mean â€˜sluggishâ€™ (O. Such a messenger ought to have come ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ï…Î´á¿‡ Ï„Î±Ï‡á½»Ï‚.â€”The conjecture ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ï…Î´á¿‡ Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Ï‚ is (I think) not only wrong but bad. It would mean, â€˜slow in my hasteâ€™; eager to arrive, yet moving slowly. ÏƒÏ€Îµá¿¦Î´Îµ Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½³Ï‰Ï‚, to which it is supposed to allude, meant, â€˜never remit your efforts, but advance circumspectly towards your aimâ€™: festina lente (on which see Erasmus in the Adagia); Eile mit Weile; Goethe's Ohne Hast, ohne Rast. (ÏƒÏ€Îµá¿¦Î´Îµ Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½³Ï‰Ï‚ was a favourite maxim of Augustus, Suet. Aug. 25; Gellius 10. 11 Â§ 5, on whom, as often, Macrobius has drawn, Sat. 6. 8. 9.) The frightened and irresolute Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾, â€”sent, sorely against his will, on a hateful errand,â€”had no more ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ï…Î´á½µ than Mr Facing-both-ways. Wecklein, keeping ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á¿‡, supposes the Guard to mean, â€˜this was a case of ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á¿‡ Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Ï‚, not ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ï…Î´á¿‡ Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Ï‚,â€™â€”an improbably obscure and feeble jest at such a critical moment. The variant given by the schol., ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á¿‡ Ï„Î±Ï‡á½»Ï‚, would be an oxymoron, designedly comic; â€˜I took my time about hurrying,â€™ â€˜'twas but a laggard haste that I made.â€™ A cheerful epigram of this sort would better suit a mind more at ease.

ÏƒÎ¿á½· with Î¼Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Î½. In Attic prose a dat. of the person after á¼”ÏÏ‡Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ is freq., and oft. can be rendered (as here) only by â€˜to,â€™ though it is properly rather a dat. of interest. Thus Thuc. 1.13 á¼ˆÎ¼ÎµÎ¹Î½Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚ Î£Î±Î¼á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ=â€˜ A. came to the Samians,â€™ though the primary notion is, â€˜the Samians enjoyed the advantage of A. In poetry this dat. is freely used after verbs of motion, but the idea of interest is always traceable; cp. 186 n. Aesch. PV 358 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼¦Î»Î¸ÎµÎ½ Î±á½Ï„á¿· Î–Î·Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼„Î³ÏÏ…Ï€Î½Î¿Î½ Î²á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚. Îµá½– Î³Îµ ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‡á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹ Îº.Ï„.Î».: â€˜yes, you take your aim well, and seek to fence yourself round against the charge.â€™ The mark at which the man aims is his own safety; and this is explained by the next phrase. Commentators have made difficulties by assuming that the metaphors of ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‡á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹ and á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï†Ïá½±Î³Î½Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î¹ must be harmonised into a single picture,â€”as of an archer shooting from covert. But in fact there is a rapid transition from one to the other; the second interprets the first; and all that is common to them is their military source. ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‡á½±Î¶Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ was familiar in a sense akin to that which it has here: cp. Plat. Lach. 178B ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‡Î±Î¶á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½ Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î²Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÏ…Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï… á¼„Î»Î»Î± Î»á½³Î³Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€Î±Ïá½° Ï„á½´Î½ Î±á½‘Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î´á½¹Î¾Î±Î½ (trying to hit the thought of the person who consults them): Polyb. 6. 16 á½€Ï†Îµá½·Î»Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ Î´á½² á¼€Îµá½¶ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–Î½ Î¿á¼± Î´á½µÎ¼Î±ÏÏ‡Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½¸ Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¿á¿¦Î½ Ï„á¿· Î´á½µÎ¼á¿³ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‡á½±Î¶ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Ï… Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½µÏƒÎµÏ‰Ï‚. So here the verb suggests a designing person, whose elaborate preamble covers a secret aim. Creon is quick to suspect bribery (221). á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½: he does not think of women.

Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Ï„Î¿Ï… Î³ÎµÎ½á¿‡Î´Î¿Ï‚ â€¦ Î¿á½ Î´Î¹Îºá½³Î»Î»Î·Ï‚. For the enclitic Ï„Î¿Ï… so placed, cp. 20 n.: for Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ â€¦ Î¿á½, O. C. 972 n. Î³ÎµÎ½á¿‡Î´Î±Â· á¼€Î¾á½·Î½Î·Î½, Ï€á½³Î»ÎµÎºÏ…Î½ (referring, as the acc. shows, to some other passage): and here the Î³ÎµÎ½á¿„Ï‚ is prob. the same as the á¼€Î¾á½·Î½Î· below (1109), which was to be used in raising the mound (1203). We may render â€˜pickaxe,â€™ since this properly has a blade as well as a point. The Î³ÎµÎ½á¿„Ï‚ would break the hard surface. Then the earth would be thrown up (á¼ÎºÎ²Î¿Î»á½µ) with the Î´á½·ÎºÎµÎ»Î»Î±, which was a sort of heavy two-pronged hoe, used, like the Roman ligo or bidens, in hoeing up soil: the Î¼á½±ÎºÎµÎ»Î»Î± (Î¼á½·Î±, Îºá½³Î»Î»Ï‰ to drive forward) being a like tool with one prong. The ÏƒÎ¼Î¹Î½á½»Î· was like the Î´á½·ÎºÎµÎ»Î»Î±, a two-pronged hoe. â€˜Mattockâ€™ is the nearest word for it. â€˜Spadeâ€™ would better suit á¼„Î¼Î· (or the Homeric Î»á½·ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Î½), though this was prop. rather a shovel. For the combination cp. Shaks. Tit. Andr. 5. 3. 11 'Tis you must dig with mattock and with spade.

Î´Î¹Îº. á¼ÎºÎ²Î¿Î»á½µ, throwing up of earth by mattock (possessive gen. denoting the subject, Î³á¿† á¼£Î½ á¼¡ Î´. á¼ÎºÎ²á½±Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹): á¼ÎºÎ²., abstract for concrete, like Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†á½µ for Î¸Ïá½³Î¼Î¼Î± (O. In Greek Î¼Î¿Î´. á¼ÎºÎ²Î¿Î»á½±Î´ÎµÏ‚ is a mining term, â€˜out-put.â€™â€” The epithets ÏƒÏ„á½»Ï†Î»Î¿Ï‚ (â€˜hard,â€™ cp. 139), and Ï‡á½³ÏÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ â€˜dry,â€™ tell something which the preceding words, and the following á¼€ÏÏá½½Î¾, would not alone have told; viz. why no foot-prints were traceable.

á¼Ï€Î·Î¼Î±Î¾ÎµÏ…Î¼á½³Î½Î·, lit. â€˜traversed (i.e. furrowed) by a carriageâ€™ with its (four) wheels, =Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï‡Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼Î¼á½±Î¾Î·Ï‚ ÎºÎµÏ‡Î±ÏÎ±Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î·: á¼Ï€â€, not á¼Ï†â€, since as Eusth. says (on Il. 18.485) Ï„á½¸...á¼…Î¼Î±Î¾Î± Î¿á¼± Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹Î¿á½¶ ÏˆÎ¹Î»Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹, Î¿á¼± Î¼á½³Î½Ï„Î¿Î¹ Î½Îµá½½Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î¹ á¼ˆÏ„Ï„Î¹ÎºÎ¿á½¶ á¼Î´á½±ÏƒÏ…Î½Î±Î½. á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Î´â€™ á½ Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á½¶Î½ á¼¡Î¼ÎµÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºá½¹Ï€Î¿Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 253

It is still the early morning of the day on which the drama opens. The Argives having fled in the night, Creon had published his edict shortly before dawn. Antigone had done her deed in the short interval between the publication of the edict and the beginning of the watch over the corpse. á½ Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼ÎµÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºá½¹Ï€Î¿Ï‚, the man who took the first watch of this day, was the first who had watched at all. If a sentinel had been near the body, Ant. must have been seen. The other men were somewhere near. (Afterwards, they all watched, Ant. 413.) á¼¡Î¼ÎµÏÎ¿ÏƒÎº., in prose á¼¡Î¼ÎµÏÎ¿Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ (Xen. Hellen. 7.2.6), as opp. to Î½Ï…ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ (id. An. 7. 2. 18).

Î´Îµá½·ÎºÎ½Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ â€¦ Ï€Î±Ïá¿†Î½: historic pres. combined with past tense; cp. Lys. or. 1 Â§ 6 á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î´á½´ Î´á½³ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï€Î±Î¹Î´á½·Î¿Î½ Î³á½·Î³Î½ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, á¼Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏ…Î¿Î½ á¼¤Î´Î· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Ï„á½° á¼Î¼Î±Ï…Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½á¿ƒ Ï€Î±Ïá½³Î´Ï‰ÎºÎ±.

Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÏá½³Ï‚, not merely â€˜perplexing,â€™ but â€˜distressingâ€™ (Ai. 1395), since they foreboded punishment. So Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ‡á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î±, molestia ( Ph. 473).

Î´Îµá½·ÎºÎ½Ï…ÏƒÎ¹, Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ Î¸Î±á¿¦Î¼Î± Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÏá½²Ï‚ Ï€Î±Ïá¿†Î½.

Ï„Ï…Î¼Î²á½µÏÎ·Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½” (cp. on 96), not entombed: i.e. there was no Ï„á½»Î¼Î²Î¿Ï‚, indicating that the ashes had been buried beneath it (1203): the body itself lay there, though covered over with dust. Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹ Î´â€™ â€¦ Ï†á½»Î»Î±ÎºÎ±. The regular form would be, Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼ÏÏÎ¿Î¸Î¿á¿¦Î¼ÎµÎ½ á¼Î½ á¼€Î»Î»á½µÎ»Î¿Î¹Ï‚, á¼Î»á½³Î³Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ Ï†á½»Î»Î±ÎºÎ± (or á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î½), Ï†á½»Î»Î±Î¾ being the part in apposition with the whole (á¼¡Î¼Îµá¿–Ï‚). The irregularity of the form in the text is threefold. Î¼á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚, lumps of red-hot iron. Î¼á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Ï‚=a molten mass, from rt Î¼Ï…Î´, whence Î¼á½»Î´Î¿Ï‚, â€˜moisture,â€™ Î¼Ï…Î´á½±Ï‰, etc. Cyril Adv. Iulian. 359 quotes this verse, after referring to a Chaldean custom of making an oath more solemn by causing those who took it to pass between the severed portions of a victim (Î´Î¹á½° Î¼á½³ÏƒÏ‰Î½... Î´Î¹Ï‡Î¿Ï„Î¿Î¼Î·Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½). It is probably the oldest trace in Greek of ordeals analogous to the medieval â€˜judgments of God.â€™ The word Î¼á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Ï‚ occurs elsewhere in connection with a solemn sanction for an oath. In Her. 1.165 the Phocaeans Î¼á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Î½ ÏƒÎ¹Î´á½µÏÎµÎ¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„ÎµÏ€á½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰ÏƒÎ±Î½, swearing not to return till it should float. Aristid. 25 á½ Î´â€™ á¼ˆÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Î´Î·Ï‚ á½¥ÏÎºÎ¹ÏƒÎµ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼Î»Î»Î·Î½Î±Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½¤Î¼Î¿ÏƒÎµÎ½ á½‘Ï€á½²Ï Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Ï‰Î½ (to observe the defensive league against Persia, 479 B.C., Grote 5. 257), Î¼á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼Î¼Î²Î±Î»á½¼Î½ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ á¼€ÏÎ±á¿–Ï‚ (in sanction of the curses on traitors) Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½´Î½ Î¸á½±Î»Î±Ï„Ï„Î±Î½. I conceive that in these passages, as elsewhere, Î¼á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Ï‚ has its proper sense,

a red-hot mass of metal, and that the custom was symbolical of an older use of the Î¼á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Ï‚ in ordeals by fire. This would explain how the Alexandrian poets of the 3rd cent. B.C. (Lycophron, Callimachus) came to use the word Î¼á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Ï‚, in defiance of its etymology, as simply â€˜a lumpâ€™ (or even â€˜a stoneâ€™). They supposed that the Î¼á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Î¹ had been cold masses.

265 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€á¿¦Ï Î´Î¹á½³ÏÏ€ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ á½ÏÎºÏ‰Î¼Î¿Ï„Îµá¿–Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 265

Ï€á¿¦Ï Î´Î¹á½³ÏÏ€ÎµÎ¹Î½ must here refer to a definite ordeal, by walking through a fire. The idea, at least, of such an ordeal appears in the familiar Attic phrase Î´Î¹á½° Ï€Ï…Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼°á½³Î½Î±Î¹ (â€˜to go through fire and waterâ€™); Plat. Symp. 4. 16á¼”Î³Ï‰Î³â€™ Î¿á½–Î½ Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° ÎšÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î½á½·Î¿Ï… Îºá¼‚Î½ Î´Î¹á½° Ï€Ï…Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼°Î¿á½·Î·Î½, Aristoph. Lys. 133 Î´Î¹á½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Ï…Ïá½¸Ï‚ | á¼Î¸á½³Î»Ï‰ Î²Î±Î´á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½. But it is doubtful whether the actual use of any such ordeal in the historical age can be inferred from Dem. or. 54 Â§ 40 á¼€Î¾Î¹Î¿Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€Î±á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ (by the lives of one's children, cp. or. 29 Â§ 26) á½€Î¼Î½á½»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´Î¹á½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Ï…Ïá½¹Ï‚, i. e. swearing that one is ready to undergo the test by fire. It has been suggested that á¼°á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ has fallen out after Ï€Ï…Ïá½¹Ï‚, which seems improbable. But the phrase may be rhetorical. Cp. Verg. Aen. 11. 787 (the Hirpi): medium freti pietate per ignem Cultores multa premimus vestigia pruna.â€”Becker Char. 183 notices some other ordeals. There was a temple in Achaia, the priestess of which, before election, was proved by drinking ball's blood; if impure, she died (Paus. 7.25.13). Perjury, and some other crimes, were assayed by the accused mounting the steps of an altar for burnt sacrifice (á¼ÏƒÏ‡á½±ÏÎ±): if he was guilty, flames appeared ( Aeth. 10. 8). Incontinence was tried by the test of entering a grotto of Pan at Ephesus (Achilles Tatius 8. 6).

Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ á½ÏÎº., to swear by the gods; the acc. is cognate (the god being identified with the oath), like á½…ÏÎºÎ¿Î½ á½€Î¼Î½á½»Î½Î±Î¹: Xen. Cyr. 5.4.31 Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î±...á½„Î¼Î½Ï…Î¼á½· ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½»Ï‚.

Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ Î´Ï.: for the art., cp. 236.

Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Îµá¼´Ï‡Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ Îº.Ï„.Î».: â€˜for we did not know how to gainsay him, nor how, if we did the thing (advised by him), we could prosper.â€™

As á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ï†Ï‰Î½Îµá¿–Î½ means opposing his suggestion, so Î´Ïá¿¶Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ means acting on it. Others join á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Î´Ïá¿¶Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, â€˜by what course of action.â€™ Since, however, a definite proposal was before themâ€”viz., reference to Creonâ€”we must then understand, â€˜by what other courseâ€™ (than the proposed one). Î¸Îµá½µÎ»Î±Ï„Î¿Î½, sent by gods (O. Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ á½€ÏÎ³á¿†Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½· Î¼Îµ Î¼ÎµÏƒÏ„á¿¶ÏƒÎ±Î¹, â€˜before thou hast actually filled me with angerâ€™: ÎºÎ±á½· has nothing to do with Ï€Ïá½·Î½, but belongs solely to Î¼ÎµÏƒÏ„á¿¶ÏƒÎ±Î¹, a strong word, the stress on which makes it easier for the force of ÎºÎ±á½· to pass over the enclitic Î¼Îµ. Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». Did they think him good? Or, thinking him bad, did they yet honour him?â€”á¼”ÎºÏÏ…Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½ (sc. á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Îºá½·Î¿Î½Î±Ï‚ Î½Î±Î¿á½»Ï‚, temples surrounded by columns, an epith. marking their stateliness and splendour, as Eur. Andr. 1099 á¼Î½ Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„á½»Î»Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚ (of a temple), I. The Î½Î±á½¸Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÏá½·ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î»Î¿Ï‚ or Ï€ÎµÏá½·Ï€Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚ (so called because the ceiling of the colonnade projected like a wing, from the cella) had a colonnade on each of its four sides: the Î½Î±á½¸Ï‚ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î»Î¿Ï‚, only on two (front and back): but, though the latter would satisfy the word á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Îºá½·Î¿Î½Î±Ï‚, the poet doubtless meant the former.

Îºá¼€Î½Î±Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±, votive offerings, such as gold and silver vessels of all kinds; statues; bronze tripods, etc. (Cp.

Her. 1.50; Thuc. 6.46; Isae. or. 7 Â§ 41.) The wealth of Delphi in á¼€Î½Î±Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± is already proverbial in Il. 9.404; at Thebes the á¼¸ÏƒÎ¼á½µÎ½Î¹Î¿Î½ (O. Î³á¿†Î½ á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½ (depending on Ï€Ï…Ïá½½ÏƒÏ‰Î½), i.e. the territory of Thebes (cp. on 199), since the land belongs to the Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½¶ á¼Î³Ï‡á½½ÏÎ¹Î¿Î¹ and Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Î¿á¿¦Ï‡Î¿Î¹: not merely the Ï„ÎµÎ¼á½³Î½Î· attached to their shrines.

Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÎ´á¿¶Î½, to scatter the laws abroad, i.e. to shatter the fabric of civil order: cp. Tennyson, Red ruin, and the breaking up of laws. Cic. Agr. 2. 37disturbare... legem. So Î´Î¹Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÎ´. of breaking up a treaty (O. C. 620), or a king's power (ib. 1341).

Î´Î¹Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÎ´á¿¶Î½ would suit á¼€Î½Î±Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±, but could not possibly be joined with Î³á¿†Î½ (as if the latter meant â€˜Stateâ€™): hence it must be taken with Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ only.

285 á¼”ÎºÏÏ…Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½, á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Îºá½·Î¿Î½Î±Ï‚

á¼¢ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ Ï„Î¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¾·Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½»Ï‚; ğŸ—©
Line 288

Î½á½¹Î¼Î¹ÏƒÎ¼â€™, institutum. This primary and general sense of the word was almost confined to poetry ( Aesch. á¼¦ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¹Î½. Creon has pronounced the Guard guilty on mere Î´á½¹Î¾Î±, without proof. The Guard says, â€˜It is grievous that, when a man does harbour suspicions (á¾§ Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿– Î³Îµ), those suspicions should at the same time (ÎºÎ±á½¶) be false.â€™ Î³Îµ means that, in such a matter, hasty Î´á½¹Î¾Î± should be avoided altogether. Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½± (L) is defended by Seyffert as=â€˜flagitious,â€™ by Whitelaw as=â€˜cleverâ€™ (iron.), â€˜your wondrous winnings.â€™ In some forms of minuscule writing Î» and Î½ could easily be confused: cp. á¼±Ï€Ï€Îµá½·á¿³ Î³á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹, the â€˜offspring of horses,â€™ meaning â€˜mulesâ€™; which are â€˜far better than oxen to drag the jointed plough through the deep fallowâ€™ (Il. 10.352). Arist. As this story suggests, the very fact that the ordinary Attic word for â€˜muleâ€™ was á¼¡Î¼á½·Î¿Î½Î¿Ï‚ (adj. á½€ÏÎ¹Îºá½¹Ï‚) might lead an Attic poet to prefer such a periphrasis as á¼µÏ€Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚. The objections to taking á¼±Ï€Ï€Îµá½·á¿³ Î³á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹ as simply =á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Î¹Ï‚are,that (1) Greek ploughmen used oxen or mules more than horses, and (2) the achievement of taming the horse (350) is thus anticipated. Some understand both horses and mules, giving Î³á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹ a double senseâ€”rather awkwardly, I think.

Ï€Î¿Î»Îµá½»Ï‰Î½, ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Ïƒá½»Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¹Î½ after Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿. Cp. 345 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¸Î·Ïá¿¶Î½ á¼€Î³Ïá½·Ï‰Î½ á¼”Î¸Î½Î· Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï… Ï„â€™ Îµá¼°Î½Î±Î»á½·Î±Î½ Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 345

Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï… â€¦ Îµá¼°Î½Î±Î»á½·Î±Î½ Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½, a brood living in the waters of the sea, the tautology being only of the same order as in Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î»á½¹Ï‚, á¼Î»á½¸Ï‚ á¼Î½ Ï€ÎµÎ»á½±Î³ÎµÏƒÏƒÎ¹Î½, Ï€á½³Î»Î±Î³Î¿Ï‚ Î¸Î±Î»á½±ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚, etc.â€”ÏƒÏ€Îµá½·ÏÎ±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Î´Î¹ÎºÏ„Ï…Î¿ÎºÎ»., instr. dat. with á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Î²Î±Î»á½½Î½, in the coils of woven nets: for the adj. compounded with a subst. C. 716 Îµá½á½µÏÎµÏ„Î¼Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î»á½±Ï„Î±.â€” Au. 528 mentions á¼•ÏÎºÎ·, Î½ÎµÏ†á½³Î»Î±Ï‚, Î´á½·ÎºÏ„Ï…Î±, Ï€Î·ÎºÏ„á½±Ï‚ as nets used by the fowler (á½€ÏÎ½Î¹Î¸ÎµÏ…Ï„á½µÏ‚). In hunting the lion, bear, boar, deer, hare, etc., various nets were used; the Î´á½·ÎºÏ„Ï…Î¿Î½, to enclose large spaces; the á¼Î½á½¹Î´Î¹Î¿Î½, to close passages; the á¼„ÏÎºÏ…Ï‚ (cassis) or tunnel-net. The chief fishing-nets were the á¼€Î¼Ï†á½·Î²Î»Î·ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Î½ (castingnet), and the ÏƒÎ±Î³á½µÎ½Î· (drag-net, whence seine, sean).

ÏƒÏ€Îµá½·ÏÎ±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Î´Î¹ÎºÏ„Ï…Î¿ÎºÎ»á½½ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¹Ï‚,

Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Ï†ÏÎ±Î´á½µÏ‚. Eustath. p. 135, 25 Ï†ÏÎ±Î´á½µÏ‚...á½…Î¸ÎµÎ½ Ïƒá½»Î½Î¸ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½ á½ Ï€Î±Ïá½° Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»Îµá¿– á¼€ÏÎ¹Ï†ÏÎ±Î´á½´Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½µÏ. This was evidently a mere slip of memory. The midd. voice does not occur elsewhere; but this cannot be regarded as an objection, when we remember how many rare middle forms occur in the dramatists. Thus Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¿ÏÏ‰Î¼á½³Î½Î± in O. Line 365365-375

The ode closes with a more direct reference to the incident which suggested its theme. The daring ingenuity shown by the unknown breaker of Creon's edict is an instance of the subtlety which leads to ruin. The implied contrast with Creonâ€”á½‘Ïˆá½·Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Ï‚ by his care for the lawsâ€”is effective in view of the destined Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Ï€á½³Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î±.

á¼„Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Ï‚. Where the typical citizen is a law-breaker, the city is ruined, and the evil-doer is left citiless. So Creon had described law-breaking as á¼„Ï„Î·Î½...á¼€ÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ (185). á¼„Î³Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹. It is far more probable that the final Î¹Î½ of Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»Îµá½·Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ should have dropped out in L (see cr. n.) than that Soph. should have written á¼€Ï€á½±Î³Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹. At Athens á¼€Ï€á½±Î³Ï‰ and á¼€Ï€Î±Î³Ï‰Î³á½µ were technical terms for a process of summary arrest by which any citizen could bring before the magistrates a person taken in a criminal act (á¼Ï€â€™ Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï†á½½Ïá¿³). Second á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïƒá½¹Î´Î¹Î¿Î½. Antigone, brought before Creon, avows and justifies her deed. Creon declares that she shall die. Ismene, when led in (531), associates herself with the act, but is not permitted by her sister to claim any part in it. Creon orders that both sisters shall be kept prisoners.

á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼¡ Î³á½°Ï á¼ÎºÏ„á½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Î±Ï‚ Ï‡Î±Ïá½° ğŸ—©

á¼¡...á¼ÎºÏ„á½¸Ï‚ (Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½) ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Ïá½° á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Î±Ï‚. I cannot parallel this zeugma of preps. with a case suited only to the second (in Il. 17.760 Ï€ÎµÏá½· Ï„â€™ á¼€Î¼Ï†á½· Ï„Îµ Ï„á½±Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½ both preps. take acc.): and yet it seems to be genuine, the phrase being so energetic and compact. á¼ÎºÏ„á½¹Ï‚ is certainly supported by 330, while á¼„Ï„Î¿Ï€Î¿Ï‚, á¼„Î»Î¿Î³Î¿Ï‚, and Îµá¼°Îºá½¹Ï‚ are all very improbable substitutes. Nor can I think, with SchÃ¼tz, that á¼ÎºÏ„á½¹Ï‚ is here adverb: â€˜the outside joyâ€™ (i.e. outside of one's calculations).

á¼”Î¿Î¹ÎºÎµÎ½ á¼„Î»Î»á¿ƒ Î¼á¿†ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á¼¡Î´Î¿Î½á¿‡, ğŸ—©

Line 407

á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½. The occupation of the guards was temporarily gone when they perceived that the burial, which they had been set to prevent, had been effected (255). Creon, speaking to their deputy, sent them back to their post, with orders to discover the culprit (306). á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ (imperf.) simply refers to their taking up their station again near the body. It need not imply that they had escorted their comrade on his way to Creon. We could not take á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½...á¼Ï€Î·Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î»Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹ as merely plur. for sing., and then refer Ïƒá½µÏÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, etc., to the guards collectively. Nor is the conject. á¼±Îºá½¹Î¼Î·Î½ needed.

Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ Ï„á½° Î´Îµá½·Î½â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½â€™ á¼Ï€Î·Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î»Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹, ğŸ—©
Line 408

Ï„á½° Î´Îµá½·Î½â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½â€™. Creon's threats were addressed to all the guards: cp. 305 ff.

Ï„á½¸Î½ | Î½á½³ÎºÏ…Î½: so O. C. 351 Ï„á½° Ï„á¿†Ï‚ | Î¿á¼´ÎºÎ¿Î¹ Î´Î¹Î±á½·Ï„Î·Ï‚: Ph. 263á½ƒÎ½ Î¿á¼± | Î´Î¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿á½¶ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î³Î¿á½·: El. 879 Îºá¼€Ï€á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ | ÏƒÎ±Ï…Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹. In Eur. no instance seems to occur.

Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ±Î½ Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Î½ Ïƒá½µÏÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, á¼£ ÎºÎ±Ï„Îµá¿–Ï‡Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½
410 Î½á½³ÎºÏ…Î½, Î¼Ï…Î´á¿¶Î½ Ï„Îµ Ïƒá¿¶Î¼Î± Î³Ï…Î¼Î½á½½ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Îµá½–,
ÎºÎ±Î¸á½µÎ¼ÎµÎ¸â€™ á¼„ÎºÏÏ‰Î½ á¼Îº Ï€á½±Î³Ï‰Î½ á½‘Ï€á½µÎ½ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î¹, ğŸ—©
Line 411

ÎºÎ±Î¸á½µÎ¼ÎµÎ¸â€™ is better taken as plpf. than pf., for, though á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ is ambiguous, we have a series of historical tenses in 415â€”421. Ar. sometimes uses and sometimes omits the augment, as Ar. Ach. 638á¼Îºá½±Î¸Î·ÏƒÎ¸Îµ, Ar. Eccl. 304ÎºÎ±Î¸á¿†Î½Ï„Î¿ (both proved by metre); and if our MSS. can be trusted, classical prose, too, admitted both forms, as Aeschin. or. 2 Â§ 89 á¼ÎºÎ±Î¸á½µÎ¼Î·Î½, Dem. or. 18 Â§ 169 ÎºÎ±Î¸á¿†Ï„Î¿. In the five pluperfects furnished by Attic inscriptions of 428â€” 325 B.C. the syllabic augment is always added, but there is no epigraphic evidence in the particular case of á¼ÎºÎ±Î¸á½µÎ¼Î·Î½ (see Meisterhans, p. 77).

á¼„ÎºÏÏ‰Î½ á¼Îº Ï€á½±Î³Ï‰Î½, with ÎºÎ±Î¸á½µÎ¼ÎµÎ¸Î±, â€˜on the hill-top.â€™ The corpse lay on the highest part of the Theban plain (1110, 1197), with rising ground (Ï€á½±Î³Î¿Î¹) behind or around it. The guards post themselves on this rising ground, facing the corpse, and with their backs to the wind. The use of á¼Îº (or á¼€Ï€á½¹), with a verb denoting position, occurs only in a few places of poetry; but it is certainly genuine, and deserves attention, for its true force has not (I think) been observed. (1) Il. 14.153 á¼­ÏÎ· Î´â€™ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎµá¿–Î´Îµ Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½¹Î¸ÏÎ¿Î½Î¿Ï‚ á½€Ï†Î¸Î±Î»Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½ | ÏƒÏ„á¾¶Ï‚'

á¼Î¾ ÎŸá½Î»á½»Î¼Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿ á¼€Ï€á½¸ á¿¥á½·Î¿Ï…. Here, á¼€Ï€á½¸ á¿¥á½·Î¿Ï… goes with Îµá¼°ÏƒÎµá¿–Î´Îµ: but á¼Î¾ ÎŸá½Î»á½»Î¼Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿, however much Îµá¼°ÏƒÎµá¿–Î´Îµ may have influenced it, at least cannot be disjoined from ÏƒÏ„á¾¶Ïƒâ€™. (2) Eur. Phoen. 1009 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Îµá¼¶Î¼Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÏ„á½°Ï‚ á¼Î¾ á¼Ï€á½±Î»Î¾ÎµÏ‰Î½ á¼„ÎºÏÏ‰Î½ | ÏƒÏ†á½±Î¾Î±Ï‚ á¼Î¼Î±Ï…Ï„á½¸Î½ ÏƒÎ·Îºá½¸Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î±Î¼Î²Î±Î¸á¿† | Î´Ïá½±ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚, á¼”Î½Î¸â€™ á½ Î¼á½±Î½Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼Î¾Î·Î³á½µÏƒÎ±Ï„Î¿, | á¼Î»ÎµÏ…Î¸ÎµÏá½½ÏƒÏ‰ Î³Î±á¿–Î±Î½. It is impossible to sever ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï‚ from á¼Î¾ á¼Ï€., even if we partly explain á¼Î¾ by ÏƒÏ†á½±Î¾Î±Ï‚. (3) ib. 1224 á¼˜Ï„ÎµÎ¿ÎºÎ»á½³Î·Ï‚ Î´â€™ á½‘Ï€á¿†ÏÎ¾â€™ á¼€Ï€â€™ á½€ÏÎ¸á½·Î¿Ï… ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ | Ï€á½»ÏÎ³Î¿Ï… ÎºÎµÎ»Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ïƒá¿–Î³Î± ÎºÎ·Ïá¿¦Î¾Î±Î¹ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„á¿·. The position of ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚ forbids us to sever it from á¼€Ï€â€™ á½€ÏÎ¸. Ï€., even though á½‘Ï€á¿†ÏÎ¾Îµ or ÎºÎµÎ»Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ is used to explain á¼€Ï€á½¹. (4) Eur. Tro. 522 á¼€Î½á½° Î´â€™ á¼Î²á½¹Î±ÏƒÎµÎ½ Î»Îµá½¼Ï‚ | Î¤Ïá¿³á½±Î´Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï€á½³Ï„ÏÎ±Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚. A similar case. In all these passages, a picture is presented, and we have to glance from a remoter to a nearer object. The mental eye is required to measure the space between Hera on the peak of Olympus, and Poseidon on the plain of Troy; between Megareus on the walls of Thebes, and the cavern into which his corpse is to fall. And, in each case, á¼Îº or á¼€Ï€á½¹ denotes the quarter in which the remoter object is to be looked for. This, which might be called the â€˜surveyingâ€™ use, is distinct from that in which the prep. has a pregnant force, as being directly suggestive of motion (Î¿á¼± á¼Îº Î£Î¹ÎºÎµÎ»á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼¥Î¾Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹); but it springs from the same mental tendency,â€”viz., to take a rapid glance over the dividing interval. Cp. á¼µÏƒÏ„Î±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï€Ïá½¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ (â€˜on his sideâ€™). So here: in the foreground of the picture is the corpse, which they have just laid bare. Now look to the hillocks behind it; in that quarter you will see the guards at their post.â€”I have not cited Od. 21.419 Ï„á½¹Î½ á¿¥â€™ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€á½µÏ‡ÎµÎ¹ á¼‘Î»á½¼Î½ á¼•Î»ÎºÎµÎ½ Î½ÎµÏ…Ïá½´Î½ Î³Î»Ï…Ï†á½·Î´Î±Ï‚ Ï„Îµ | Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼Îº Î´á½·Ï†ÏÎ¿Î¹Î¿ ÎºÎ±Î¸á½µÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚, because there á¼Îº Î´á½·Ï†ÏÎ¿Î¹Î¿ goes with á¼•Î»ÎºÎµÎ½, not with ÎºÎ±Î¸á½µÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ (he drew the bow, just from the chair, where he sat).

á½‘Ï€á½µÎ½ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î¹, under the wind, i.e., so that it blew from behind them, not in their faces, as the next v. explains. (At v. 421 the dust is blown in their faces, but that is by the sudden, gusty ÏƒÎºÎ·Ï€Ï„á½¹Ï‚.) The idea of â€˜sheltered,â€™ which á½‘Ï€á½µÎ½ÎµÎ¼Î¿Ï‚ usu. implies, is less prominent here, yet quite admissible, if we suppose them to sit just below the summits of the Ï€á½±Î³Î¿Î¹. Cp. Xen. Oec. 18. 6á¼Îº Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ·Î½á½³Î¼Î¿Ï… Î¼á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚, on the side towards which the wind blows, opp. to á¼Îº Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á½‘Ï€Î·Î½á½³Î¼Î¿Ï…, to windward. Theophr. Causs. The incident of the storm was a dramatic necessity, to account for Antigone reaching the corpse unobserved. A powerful picture is compressed into seven lines. (Cp. O. C. 1315 ff. for a like instance of self-restraint in description.)

Ï„á½¸ Î»Ï…Ï€Î¿á¿¦Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î±á¼°Î¸á½³ÏÎ±, ÎºÎ±Î¸á½¸ Ï„Î±Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½: only á¼„Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ is rather what annoys us than what annoys the (personified) Î¿á½ÏÎ±Î½á½¹Ï‚. In these lines the poet describes the actual physical effects produced by the storm. He mentions the destruction of foliage; and we need some reference also to the main point of allâ€”the obscuring of the air. Therefore I should not take Î¿á½Ïá½±Î½Î¹Î¿Î½ á¼„Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ as=â€˜a heaven-sent plagueâ€™; that is presently said by Î¸Îµá½·Î±Î½ Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î½ (421). Ï€Î¹ÎºÏá¾¶Ï‚, in its bitterness. Elsewhere Ï€Î¹ÎºÏá½¹Ï‚, said of persons, means â€˜embittered,â€™ and so â€˜hostile,â€™ etc. (as Ai. 1359). ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½¶Î½ Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ Î´Î¹Ïˆá½·Î±Î½ Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹ Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 429

Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹ Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Î½. A difficulty presents itself. The essence of the symbolical rite was the sprinkling of dust. She had done that (245). Was it not, then, done once for all? In Horace (C. 1. 28. 35) the passer-by is free when the dust has been thrown; he can go his way. I have never seen this question put or answered. The only answer which I can suggest is that, at her first visit, she had not brought the Ï‡Î¿Î±á½·. (Cp. on 245 ff.) Perhaps the rite was considered complete only if the Ï‡Î¿Î±á½· were poured while the dust still covered the corpse.

Ï‡Î¿Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¹. In Od. 10.519 the three Ï‡Î¿Î±á½· to the dead are of (1) hydromel, (2) wine, (3) water: see O. C. 479 n.

Ï„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ€á½¹Î½Î´., instead of the simple Ï„ÏÎ¹Ïƒá½·Î½: cp. on 346 ÏƒÏ€. Î´Î¹ÎºÏ„Ï…Î¿ÎºÎ»á½½ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¹Ï‚. á¾”Î´Î·ÏƒÎ¸Î±, not á¾”Î´Î·Ï‚ Ï„á½°, is certainly right. This 2nd pers. occurs in seven places of drama, two of which require it (Eur. Aristoph. Lys. 132 has á¼”Ï†Î·ÏƒÎ¸Î±, and á¼”Ï†Î·Ï‚ nowhere: but the case for á¼”Ï†Î·ÏƒÎ¸Î± as the sole classical form seems less strong than for á¾”Î´Î·ÏƒÎ¸Î± and á¼¦ÏƒÎ¸Î±. á¼”Ï†Î·ÏƒÎ¸Î± is required in four Homeric passages (Il. 1.397, 16. 830: Od. 3.357, 23. 71), but á¼”Ï†Î·Ï‚ in one, Il. 22.331 á¼ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï, á¼€Ï„á½±Ï Ï€Î¿Ï… á¼”Ï†Î·Ï‚ Î Î±Ï„ÏÎ¿ÎºÎ»á¿†â€™ á¼Î¾ÎµÎ½Î±Ïá½·Î¶Ï‰Î½, and in another it is traditional, 22. 280 á¼¦Ï„Î¿Î¹ á¼”Ï†Î·Ï‚ Î³Îµ (where á¼”Ï†Î·ÏƒÎ¸Î± is unlikely). The ending is -ÏƒÎ¸Î±, not -Î¸Î±, Ï‚ being an integral part of it: Curtius compares Lat. -sti (dedi-sti), and Gothic -st (saisÃ´-st, thou sowedst), Gk Verb pp. 34 ff. Ï„á¿¶Î½ Îºá½±Ï„Ï‰ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½. For this rare gen. (instead of the regular dat.) with Î¾á½»Î½Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚, cp. Lycurgus In Leocr. Â§ 145 Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î½ Ï„Î±á½»Ï„á¿ƒ Ï„á¿‡ Ï‡á½½Ïá¾³ Ïƒá½»Î½Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ á½‘Î¼á¿¶Î½ Î³ÎµÎ½á½µÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. So O. C. 1382 Î”á½·ÎºÎ· Î¾á½»Î½ÎµÎ´ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î–Î·Î½á½¹Ï‚. â€˜The Justice that dwells with the gods belowâ€™ is their personified right to claim from the living those religious observances which devote the dead to them. A person who omits such observances is defrauding Hades of his own: see 1070. This Justice, then, â€˜has not ordained such lawsâ€™ as Creon's; it has not forbidden kinsfolk to bury their dead; on the contrary, it has bound them to do so. Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´â€™ â€¦ á½¥ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎµÎ½ is a certainly true correction of the MS. Î¿á¼³ Ï„Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´â€™ â€¦ á½¥ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎ±Î½. With the latter, Î¿á¼³ are either Zeus and Î”á½·ÎºÎ·,â€”which would be the natural sense,â€”or Î¿á¼± Îºá½±Ï„Ï‰ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½·: and Ï„Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´Îµ Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ are the laws of sepulture. But, after Ï„á½±Î´Îµ in 450, referring to Creon's edicts, the demonstrative pronoun here also should refer to them. Creon has just called his own laws Ï„Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´Îµ Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ (449). If Antigone, immediately afterwards, used Ï„Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´Îµ Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ to describe the divine laws, the stress on Ï„Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´Îµ would be extremely awkward. Line 465465-468

KviÄala and Wecklein reject these four verses, despairing of the difficulties found in vv. 466, 467, which have been variously amended; see Appendix. The alleged difficulties are, (1) Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á¼„Î»Î³Î¿Ï‚: (2) the mention of the mother only: (3) the position of Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„â€™, which might suggest the sense, â€˜slain by my motherâ€™: (4) Î·á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ (as L has it). Before dealing with these points, I would call attention to a trait which the impugners of these verses have overlooked, and which speaks strongly for the genuineness of the passage as a whole, corrupt though it be in certain words. That trait is the clause Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ Î´â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼€Î»Î³á½»Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ in 468, returning upon the thought Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á¼„Î»Î³Î¿Ï‚ in 466. This series of three clauses, in which the second is opposed to the first, and the third re-iterates the sense of the first, is peculiarly Sophoclean: cp. Ai. 1111 Î¿á½ Î³á½±Ï Ï„Î¹ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ïƒá¿†Ï‚ Î¿á½•Î½ÎµÎºâ€™ á¼ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±Ï„Î¿ | Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá½¹Ï‚,... | á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½•Î½ÎµÏ‡â€™ á½…ÏÎºÏ‰Î½ Î¿á¼·ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼¦Î½ á¼Î½á½½Î¼Î¿Ï„Î¿Ï‚, | ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ Î´â€™ Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½: similar instances are O. T. 337 f., Tr. 431 ff. This touch would hardly have come from an interpolator.

Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á¼„Î»Î³Î¿Ï‚Â· á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼„Î½, Îµá¼° Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î¾ á¼Î¼á¿†Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 466

á¼„Î»Î³Î¿Ï‚, nom., sc. á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·: Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½,

adv.: â€˜is a pain in no appreciable degree,â€™ is a pain not worth a thought: as he might have said, Î¿á½Î´Î±Î¼Î¿á¿¦ á¼„Î»Î³Î¿Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·. The normal use of Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½, â€˜of no account,â€™ is either (a) with the verb Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹, as O. The only peculiarity here is that, instead of a word in the general sense, â€˜is esteemedâ€™ (á¼„Î³ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹), we have a virtual equivalent, tinged with the special thought of the moment, viz., â€˜is a pain.â€™ Exactly so in El. 1327 we have Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ± Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î²á½·Î¿Ï… Îºá½µÎ´ÎµÏƒÎ¸â€™ á¼”Ï„Î¹, instead of Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ± Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î²á½·Î¿Î½ á¼„Î³ÎµÏ„Îµ. á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼„Î½. For the position of á¼„Î½ (to which objection has been taken) cp. El. 333 á¼€Î»Î³á¿¶ â€™Ï€á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½Â· á½¥ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼„Î½, Îµá¼° ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ | Î»á½±Î²Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¹, Î´Î·Î»á½½ÏƒÎ±Î¹Î¼â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¿á¼·â€™ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á¿¶: ib. 439 á¼€ÏÏ‡á½´Î½ Î´â€™ á¼„Î½, Îµá¼° Î¼á½´ Ï„Î»Î·Î¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î· Î³Ï…Î½á½´ | Ï€Î±Ïƒá¿¶Î½ á¼”Î²Î»Î±ÏƒÏ„Îµ, Ï„á½±ÏƒÎ´Îµ Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ¼ÎµÎ½Îµá¿–Ï‚ Ï‡Î¿á½°Ï‚ | Î¿á½Îº á¼„Î½ Ï€Î¿Î¸â€™, á½…Î½ Î³â€™ á¼”ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ¹Î½Îµ, Ï„á¿·Î´â€™ á¼Ï€á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏ†Îµ.

á¼„Î¸Î±Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼ Î½ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ Î½á½³ÎºÏ…Î½, had allowed him to be an unburied corpse. For á¼„Î¸Î±Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½ without á½„Î½Ï„Î±, cp. Hist. An. 8. 8 Î´á½»Î½Î±Ï„Î±Î¹ Î´â€™ á¼„Ï€Î¿Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½³Ï‡ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ (sc. á½¤Î½): and O. T. 412 n. L has Î·á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½, and á¼ Î½ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ appears only as one of several readings in the later MSS.,â€”the other readings being manifestly impossible. The first question is, Could an Attic poet have used á¼ Î½ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ for á¼ Î½ÎµÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½? We can only say that we find nothing really like it, and that no support for it can be drawn from the Homeric forms in which á¼€Î½á½± suffers apocope, viz., á¼„Î½ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ¿ = á¼€Î½Î±ÏƒÏ‡Î¿á¿¦ (Il. 23.587 etc.), á¼€Î½ÏƒÏ‡á½µÏƒÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ (Il. 5.104), á¼€Î½ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÏ„á½± (Od. 2.63), á¼€Î½ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ¸á½³ÎµÎ¹Î½ (Od. 5.320). Still, there is force in Prof. Tyrrell's remark (Classical Review, vol. 11. p. 140) that â€˜á¼ Î½ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ is just the form in which an Attic poet would have applied apocope of á¼€Î½á½±, inasmuch as he would have felt that he was only sacrificing the redundant augment.â€™

In my first edition I placed in the text the emendation of Semitelos (1887) á¾”ÏƒÏ‡Ï…Î½Î±Î½ Îºá½»Î½ÎµÏ‚. Cp. Il. 22.74 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½…Ï„Îµ Î´á½´ Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹á½¹Î½ Ï„Îµ Îºá½±ÏÎ· Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹á½¹Î½ Ï„Îµ Î³á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½ | Î±á¼°Î´á¿¶ Ï„â€™ Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î½Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹ Îºá½»Î½ÎµÏ‚ ÎºÏ„Î±Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Î¿ Î³á½³ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚. If the ÎµÏ‚ of Îºá½»Î½ÎµÏ‚ had been obliterated, Î½á½³ÎºÏ…Î½ would easily have arisen (esp. after Î½); and a change of Ï… into Î¿ would have taken á¾”ÏƒÏ‡Ï…Î½Î±Î½ far towards Î·á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½. But, while I still hold that this brilliant conjecture has no small degree of probability, I also recognise the justice of the criticism that the context here decidedly favours a verb in the first person.

Other emendations will be found in the Appendix. Most of them assume that we must have á¼ Î½ÎµÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½ (or á¼€Î½ÎµÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î¼Î·Î½), and therefore alter the words Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„â€™ á¼„Î¸Î±Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½ and Î½á½³ÎºÏ…Î½ in various ways, â€”usu. omitting Î½á½³ÎºÏ…Î½. The verses produced by these processes are wretched, while, from a palaeographical point of view, they are pure conjectures, which do not attempt to account for the tradition in L.â€”Two points remain. (1) Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î¾ á¼Î¼á¿†Ï‚ | Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚. This is like saying, â€˜the son of the same womb.â€™ Cp. Eur. I. T. 497 Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¼ Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ á¼Îº Î¼Î¹á¾¶Ï‚; Yet it has been seriously urged by many critics, as a ground for change, that a mention of the father was indispensable. á¼Î¼á¿†Ï‚ need not be altered to á½Î¼á¿†Ï‚ (Seyffert)

It is quite true that, when written, these words have an awkward ambiguity; but they would have had none when spoken, since a slight pause after Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚ would have been required to bring out Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„â€™. This is the right test to apply in the case of a play written to be acted.

These two verses give a moment of stillness before the storm breaks forth. So at O. T. 404 four verses of the chorus divide the angry speech of Oedipus from the retort of Teiresias.

Î¸ÏÎ±Ï…ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¿¥Î±Î³á½³Î½Ï„Î±, â€˜broken and shivered.â€™ á¿¥Î±Î³á½³Î½Ï„Î± is here the stronger word, in so far as it pictures the fragments of the ruptured iron flying asunder, while Î¸ÏÎ±Ï…ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± merely says that the iron is broken into pieces. As Heinrich Schmidt observes, the foremost idea in á¿¥Î·Î³Î½á½»Î½Î±Î¹ is that of the separation of the parts,â€”the rent or rift being brought before us; in Î¸ÏÎ±á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½, that of a whole being broken into small pieces (Synonymik der Gr. Sprache, vol. 111. pp. 304 ff.).

ÎºÎ±Ï„Î·ÏÏ„Ï…Îºá½¼Ï‚ (á¼±Îºá½³Ï„Î·Ï‚) is said to be a term applied to a horse whose mouth was â€˜fully furnishedâ€™ with teeth (i.e. which had shed its foal's teeth), and hence, â€˜broken in,â€™ â€˜tamedâ€™: at any rate, it must be kept distinct from the passive ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏÏ„Ï…Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚ as used here.

Suspicion has fallen on á¼ÎºÏ€á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹, which occurs only here: Hesych. explains it by á¼”Î¾ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹, and á¼Î¾á½³Ï€ÎµÎ»ÎµÎ½ by á¼Î¾ÎµÎ³á½³Î½ÎµÏ„Î¿. Î±á½•Ï„Î· Î´â€™. Creon began by addressing Antigone (473). He now denounces her to the Chorus. Cp. O. T. 1078 Î±á½•Ï„Î· Î´â€™ á¼´ÏƒÏ‰Ï‚, Îº.Ï„.Î». (of Iocasta).â€” á½‘Î²Ïá½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ â€¦ á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Ï‚ Î´â€™: epanaphora (O. T. 25 n.). Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹Ï‚, neut., these deeds: cp. 468 ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ ...Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ.

Î´ÎµÎ´ÏÎ±ÎºÏ…á¿–Î±Î½ Î³ÎµÎ»á¾¶Î½=to exult in having done it. For the partic., cp. Aristoph. Vesp. 1007 ÎºÎ¿á½Îº á¼Î³Ï‡Î±Î½Îµá¿–Ï„Î±á½· Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î¾Î±Ï€Î±Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½™Ï€á½³ÏÎ²Î¿Î»Î¿Ï‚.

Î½á¿¦Î½, â€˜now,â€™ i.e. â€˜under these circumstances,â€™ is better than Î½Ï…Î½ or Ï„á¼„Ïâ€™ here.

Îµá¼° Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± â€¦ ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·, if this victory shall remain on record for her, without bringing her any punishment. For ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·, deeds of might, and so prevalence, victory, cp. I. 4. 17Ï„á½¶Î½ Î´â€™ á¼Î½ á¼¸ÏƒÎ¸Î¼á¿· Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á½¹Î± Î¸á½±Î»Î»Î¿Î¹Ïƒâ€™ á¼€ÏÎµÏ„á½±, | Î¦Ï…Î»Î±Îºá½·Î´Î±, ÎºÎµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹, â€˜for thee, Phylacidas, a double glory of valour is laid up at the Isthmus.â€™ So, here, ÎºÎµá½·ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ means, â€˜placed to her credit,â€™ â€˜permanently secured to herâ€™; cp. the colloquialism, â€˜to score a success.â€™ Other interpretations are:â€”(1) â€˜If this royal power of mine shall have been instituted without penalty for her.â€™ For the word ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·, this sense is tenable (cp. 60, 166, 173, O. T. 237): it is the whole phrase that appears strained. And Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™ (said with bitter emphasis) evidently refers to Antigone's acts; cp. 483 Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹Ï‚. Semitelos reads Ï€Îµá½·ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹: â€˜If this sovereignty of mineâ€™ (here Creon lifts his sceptre) â€˜shall yield to her without punishing her.â€™ The verb would, however, be strange, and somewhat weak. Ran. 1126 ff. illustrates the poetical ambiguity of ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·, the debate there being whether, by Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿·Î± ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·, Aesch. meant, â€˜a victory over a father,â€™ or â€˜power derived from a father.â€™â€”For the form of á¼€Î½Î±Ï„á½·, cp. á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á¿†Ï‚ Îµá¼´Î¸â€™ á½Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ± ğŸ—©
Line 486

á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á¿†Ï‚, (child of) a sister, á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†Î¹Î´á¿†: for the gen., cp. 380, 825.

Îµá¼´Î¸â€™ á½Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ±, â€˜or nearer in blood to me than any member of my family.â€™ The gen. á½Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ±Ï‚ (see cr. n.) would mean, â€˜or (child of) one nearer in blood to me,â€™ etc. She could be the child of no one nearer than a sister, unless it were of a mother or of a daughter; and it is far-fetched to suppose that Creon means, â€˜my niece,â€”aye, my sister, or my granddaughter.â€™ All that he means is, â€˜my niece,â€”aye, or the nearest relation possible.â€™ This is more simply and clearly said by the nom. á½Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ±. If the comparative were here restricted to the regular Sophoclean sense of the positive á½…Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ and á½Î¼Î±á½·Î¼Ï‰Î½, as meaning brother or sister (see on O. C. 330), then the gen. could be explained in another way, viz., as a rhetorical hyperbole: â€˜sister's child, or child of one who was thrice my sister,â€™ â€”like Plato Lysis 210C á½ Ï€Î±Ï„á½´Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼¡ Î¼á½µÏ„Î·Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá¼´ Ï„Î¹ Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ Î¿á¼°ÎºÎµÎ¹á½¹Ï„ÎµÏá½¹Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹.

Hyperbole is congenial to Creon's excitement; cp. 1040. But the addition, Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Î–. á¼‘ÏÎºÎµá½·Î¿Ï…, ill suits this, while, on the other hand, it agrees well with the nom. á½Î¼Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ±. On the whole, then, I incline to prefer the nom.; but the point is a nice one, and the gen. is quite tenable.

á¼Ï€á½µÎ²Î¿Î»Î¿Î½, â€˜in possession ofâ€™ (compos), a word used by Aesch. ( Aesch. P. V. 444Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á¿¶Î½, Aesch. Ag. 542Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Ï…), but not by Eur. á½ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¸Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ â€¦ Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½, the mind of those who are planning nothing aright (planning utter mischief) in the dark, Ï†Î¹Î»Îµá¿– ÎºÎ»Î¿Ï€Îµá½ºÏ‚ á¾‘Ïá¿†ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, is apt to stand convicted of its treason, Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸ÎµÎ½, beforehand,â€”i.e. before the treasonable deed has been done. For the order of words (á½ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¹Ï‚ being divided from the attributive gen. by the predicate), cp. Thuc. 2.8 á¼¡ Î´á½² Îµá½”Î½Î¿Î¹Î± Ï€Î±Ïá½° Ï€Î¿Î»á½º á¼Ï€Î¿á½·ÎµÎ¹ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼€Î½Î¸Ïá½½Ï€Ï‰Î½ Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î›Î±ÎºÎµÎ´Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚. Ismene has not yet been caught in a disloyal act; but her guilty conscience has already shown itself. ÎºÎ»Î¿Ï€Îµá½»Ï‚ here answers to ÎºÎ»á½³Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½ as=â€˜to do by stealth or fraud,â€™ Ai. 1137 Ï€á½¹Î»Î»â€™ á¼‚Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚ Î»á½±Î¸Ïá¾³ Ïƒá½º ÎºÎ»á½³ÏˆÎµÎ¹Î±Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Îºá½±. Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½ midd., as usual; cp. Ph. 80Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½á¾¶ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±Îºá½±. Line 506

á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼¡ Ï„Ï…ÏÎ±Î½Î½á½·Ï‚. â€˜(If these men dared to say what they think, they would applaud me.) But royalty has the advantage of being able to do and say what it pleases, without being opposed in word or deedâ€™:â€”and so these men are silent. These are two excellent and vigorous lines,â€”not only free from the slightest internal mark of spuriousness, but admirably suited to their place, both by thought and by expression. It was an extraordinary freak of arbitrary criticism to reject them. The reasons assigned for doing so deserve mention only for their curious weakness; as (a) á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼¡ ought to be á¼¡ Î³á½±Ïâ€”Dindorf: (b) Antigone should not mention the advantages of the Ï„Ï…ÏÎ±Î½Î½á½·Ï‚â€” JacobA. : (c) Creon could not be reproached with Î´Ïá¾¶Î½ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¸â€™ á¼‚ Î²Î¿á½»Î»ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹â€”Nauck: of which last objection Bellermann, in his simple and triumphant vindication of these verses, justly says that it is â€˜wholly unintelligible.â€™ (d) Wecklein, too, has effectively defended them. We may add that Creon's reply in v. 508, which refers primarily to vv. 504 f., does not therefore ignore vv. 506 f., since these two vv. cohere closely with the former: vv. 504â€”507 express a single thought. For similar references in tragedy to the Ï„Ï…ÏÎ±Î½Î½á½·Ï‚, as it was viewed by Greeks in the historical age, cp. Aesch. PV 224 f., Eur. Ion 621â€”632.

Ïƒá½º Î´â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼Ï€Î±Î¹Î´Îµá¿–; And art thou not ashamed of it (cp. á¼Ï€Î±Î¹ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹), if thou thinkest otherwise than they do?â€” thinkest, namely, that thou art free to act on thy own views, regardless of thy king. Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î´á¿†Ï„â€™: why, then, dost thou render (to Polyneices) a tribute impious in the sight of Eteocles?â€”i.e., which places the latter on the same level with the former.

á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½á¿³, ethic dat., â€˜in his judgmentâ€™: cp. 904, O. C. 1446 á¼€Î½á½±Î¾Î¹Î±Î¹... Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹Î½, and ib. 810 n., O. T. 40. Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ is usu. explained as acc. of the inner object, like Ï„Î¹Î¼á¾·Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Î¼á½µÎ½. But it would evidently be awkward to have an objective acc. added, as Ï„Î¹Î¼á¿¶ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½. Tro. 1210 Î¿á½“Ï‚ Î¦Ïá½»Î³ÎµÏ‚ Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ | Ï„Î¹Î¼á¿¶ÏƒÎ¹Î½, Ion 1045Ï„á½´Î½ Îµá½Ïƒá½³Î²ÎµÎ¹Î±Î½...Ï„Î¹Î¼á¾¶Î½, and means, â€˜to render duly,â€™ as religious observance requires. So I should take it also in the parallel phrase, Eur. Or. 828 Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î±Î½ | Ï„Î¹Î¼á¿¶Î½ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½, duly rendering grace to thy sire.â€” á½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¸Î±Î½á½¼Î½ Î½á½³ÎºÏ…Ï‚: cp. 26.

Line 517

Î¿á½ Î³á½±Ï Ï„Î¹ Î´Î¿á¿¦Î»Î¿Ï‚. No, Eteocles

cannot complain, for Polyneices was not his slaveâ€”his natural inferiorâ€”but his brother, and had the same claim on me that he had. Creon insists on the difference between the loyal man and the disloyal. Antigone dwells on the fact that both men had the same claim on her natural piety, and (519) on her sense of religious duty.

Î»á½µÎ¸Î¿Ï…Ïƒá½± Î¼â€™ á¼Î¾á½³Ï€Î¹Î½ÎµÏ‚, Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼Î¼á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½Î¿Î½ ğŸ—©

Î»á½µÎ¸Î¿Ï…Ïƒá½± Î¼â€™ á¼Î¾á½³Ï€Î¹Î½ÎµÏ‚. It seems unnecessary to suppose a confusion of images. The venom from the echidna's bite is here described as working insidiously, and, at first, almost insensibly. So Heracles says of the poison, which he has already (Tr. 770) compared to the echidna's, á¼Îº Î´á½² Ï‡Î»Ï‰Ïá½¸Î½ Î±á¼·Î¼á½± Î¼Î¿Ï… | Ï€á½³Ï€Ï‰ÎºÎµÎ½ á¼¤Î´Î·, Tr. 1055. Cp. Line 533

á¼„Ï„Î± Îºá¼€Ï€Î±Î½Î±ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚. The dual is commended, as against á¼„Ï„Î±Ï‚, by a certain scornful vigour; just as at 58 the dual has an emphasis of its own. Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î±á¼°Ï„á½·Î±Ï‚ depends on both verbs. Î¾Ï…Î¼Î¼ÎµÏ„á½·ÏƒÏ‡Ï‰ having prepared the ear for a partitive gen., no harshness is felt in the reference of that gen. to Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰ also. We cannot take the gen. with the first verb only, and regard ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰ as parenthetic. Î¸á½±ÏÏƒÎµÎ¹ is not said with bitterness (that could hardly be, after 551): rather it means, â€˜Take heart to live,â€™ as Whitelaw renders it. These two verses quietly express her feeling that their lots are irrevocably sundered, and exhort Ismene to accept the severance.

To show that the art. was not always required in such quotation, it is enough to cite Aristoph. Eq. 21 Î»á½³Î³Îµ Î´á½´ Î¼á½¹Î»Ï‰Î¼ÎµÎ½, by the side of Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½¹Î»Ï‰Î¼ÎµÎ½ ib. 26. á¼€Ïá½½ÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Î¹, a poet. form (only here), analogous to the epic forms of adjectives in which a short vowel is lengthened for metre's sake (cp. on 492). Line 571

Ï…á¼±á½³ÏƒÎ¹, the regular Attic dat. plur. (as Plat. Rep. 362E, Aristoph. Nub. 1001, etc.), from the stem Ï…á¼±Ï…-, which furnished also the Attic nom. and gen. plur., Ï…á¼±Îµá¿–Ï‚, Ï…á¼±á½³Ï‰Î½; and the dual Ï…á¼±á¿† (or rather Ï…á¼±Îµá¿–, Meisterhans p. 63), Ï…á¼±á½³Î¿Î¹Î½. The Attic forms of the sing. and the acc. plur. were taken from Ï…á¼±Î¿-, except that Ï…á¼±á½³Î¿Ï‚, Ï…á¼±Îµá¿– were alternative forms for the gen. and dat. sing. Here L has the epic Ï…á¼±á½±ÏƒÎ¹Î½, from a third stem, Ï…á¼±-, whence the Homeric forms Ï…á¼·Î¿Ï‚, Ï…á¼·Î¹,

Ï…á¼·Î±, Ï…á¼·Îµ, Ï…á¼·ÎµÏ‚, Ï…á¼·Î±Ï‚: cp. Monro Hom. Gr. Â§ 107.â€”The dat. of interest goes with ÎºÎ±Îºá½°Ï‚ Î³Ï…Î½Î±á¿–ÎºÎ±Ï‚, not with ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î³á¿¶: cp. Aristoph. Nub. 1161 Ï€Ïá½¹Î²Î¿Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚, ÏƒÏ‰Ï„á½´Ï Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚, á¼Ï‡Î¸ÏÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ Î²Î»á½±Î²Î·.

á¼ˆÎ½. á½¦ Ï†á½·Î»Ï„Î±Î¸â€™ Î‘á¼·Î¼Î¿Î½, á½¥Ï‚ Ïƒâ€™ á¼€Ï„Î¹Î¼á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹ Ï€Î±Ï„á½µÏ. ğŸ—©
Line 572

It is not of much moment that L, like the later MSS., gives this verse to Ismene. Errors as to the persons occur not seldom in L (see, e.g., cr. n. to O. C. 837, and cp. ib. 1737); and here a mistake would have been peculiarly easy, as the dialogue from v. 561 onwards has been between Creon and Ismene. To me it seems certain that the verse is Antigone's, and that one of the finest touches in the play is effaced by giving it to Ismene. The taunt, ÎºÎ±Îºá½°Ï‚ Î³Ï…Î½Î±á¿–ÎºÎ±Ï‚ Ï…á¼±á½³ÏƒÎ¹, moves Antigone to break the silence which she has kept since v. 560: in all this scene she has not spoken to Creon, nor does she now address him: she is thinking of Haemon,â€”of the dishonour to him implied in the charge of having made such a choice, â€”á½¡Ï‚ Î±á¼°Îµá½¶ Ï„á½¸Î½ á½Î¼Î¿á¿–Î¿Î½ á¼„Î³ÎµÎ¹ Î¸Îµá½¸Ï‚ á½¡Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ á½Î¼Î¿á¿–Î¿Î½. How little does his father know the heart which was in sympathy with her own. This solitary reference to her love heightens in a wonderful degree our sense of her unselfish devotion to a sacred duty. If Ismene speaks this verse, then Ï„á½¸ Ïƒá½¸Î½ Î»á½³Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ in 573 must be, â€˜the marriage of which you talkâ€™ (like El. 1110 Î¿á½Îº Î¿á¼¶Î´Î± Ï„á½´Î½ Ïƒá½´Î½ ÎºÎ»á¿„Î´Î¿Î½'), which certainly is not its natural sense.

Î‘á¼·Î¼Î¿Î½. L has Î±á¼µÎ¼Ï‰Î½. Soph. would have written AIMON: hence the tradition is subject to the same ambiguity as in KPEON. The analogy of Î´Î±á¿–Î¼Î¿Î½ would probably have recommended the form in Î¿.

ÎšÏ. á¼„Î³Î±Î½ Î³Îµ Î»Ï…Ï€Îµá¿–Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒá½º ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¸ Ïƒá½¸Î½ Î»á½³Ï‡Î¿Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 573

á¼„Î³Î±Î½ Î³Îµ Î»Ï…Ï€Îµá¿–Ï‚, â€˜Nay, thou art too troublesome,â€™â€”the impatient phrase of one who would silence another, as Ai. 589 (Ajax to Tecmessa) á¼„Î³Î±Î½ Î³Îµ Î»Ï…Ï€Îµá¿–Ï‚Â· Î¿á½ Îºá½±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¸â€™, etc.: so ib. 592 Ï€á½¹Î»Î»â€™ á¼„Î³Î±Î½ á¼¤Î´Î· Î¸ÏÎ¿Îµá¿–Ï‚.

Î§Î¿. á¼¦ Î³á½°Ï ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½ ÏƒÎ±Ï…Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î³á½¹Î½Î¿Î½; ğŸ—©
Line 574

The MSS. give this verse to Ismene; but Boeckh is clearly right in giving it to the Chorus. Ismene asked this question in 568, and Creon answered: she rejoined to this answer (570), and Creon replied still more bitterly. She could not now ask her former question over again. But there is no unfitness in the question being repeated by a new intercessor, since to ask it thus is a form of mild remonstrance.

ÎšÏ. 575 á¼Î¹Î´Î·Ï‚ á½ Ï€Î±á½»ÏƒÏ‰Î½ Ï„Î¿á½»ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î³á½±Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼”Ï†Ï…. ğŸ—©
Line 575

á¼Î¼Î¿á½·, L's reading, is right. Creon has been asked,â€”â€˜Can you indeed mean to deprive your son of his bride?â€™ He grimly replies, â€˜I look to the Death-god to break off this match.â€™ The á¼”Ï†Ï… in the later MSS. was obviously a mere conjecture,â€”and a weak one.

Î§Î¿. Î´ÎµÎ´Î¿Î³Î¼á½³Î½â€™, á½¡Ï‚ á¼”Î¿Î¹ÎºÎµ, Ï„á½µÎ½Î´Îµ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 576

This verse clearly belongs to the Chorus, to whom L assigns it. The first words of the next verse show this. Hermann objected that in similar situations the Chorus usually has two verses. It is true that this is usually the case. But O. T. 1312 is enough to show that there was no rigid rule; why, indeed, should there be? And, here, surely, Ï€Î»á½³Î¿Î½ á¼¥Î¼Î¹ÏƒÏ… Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¹Ï‚.

Î´ÎµÎ´Î¿Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î± (á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·), = Î´á½³Î´Î¿ÎºÏ„Î±Î¹: cp. on 570 á¼¡ÏÎ¼Î¿ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î±, 447 ÎºÎ·ÏÏ…Ï‡Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Î±. Cp. Menander á¼ˆÏÏÎ·Ï†á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚ 1. 3 Î´ÎµÎ´Î¿Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î½ Ï„á½¸ Ï€Ïá¾¶Î³Î¼â€™Â· á¼€Î½ÎµÏÏá½·Ï†Î¸Ï‰ Îºá½»Î²Î¿Ï‚.

Line 577

ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÎ¿á½· Î³Îµ Îºá¼€Î¼Î¿á½·, sc. Î´ÎµÎ´Î¿Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î±. It is settled, for both of us: i.e., I shall not change my mind, and it is vain for thee to plead. The datives are ethic. Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá¾¶Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€Î»á¿†Î¸Î¿Ï‚. The phrase is bold, and somewhat strange; but I do not think that it is corrupt. Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá¾¶Ï‚ here is the whole race, not (as in 596) a generation of the race. The words mean literally, â€˜over a multitude of the raceâ€™; i.e., the á¼„Ï„Î· does not cease with the person who first brought it into the family, or with his generation, but continues to afflict succeeding genera tions. The collective noun Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá¾¶Ï‚ justifies the use of Ï€Î»á¿†Î¸Î¿Ï‚: as he might have said, á¼€Ï€Î¿Î³á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ Ï€Î»á¿†Î¸Î¿Ï‚. It is needless, then, to write Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá¾¶Î½. We cannot understand, â€˜to the fulness of the race,â€™ i.e. till the race has been exhausted.

á½…Î¼Î¿Î¹Î¿Î½, adv.: Plat. Legg. 628D á½…Î¼Î¿Î¹Î¿Î½ á½¡Ï‚ Îµá¼°...á¼¡Î³Î¿á¿–Ï„á½¹ Ï„Î¹Ï‚.

Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„á½·Î±Î¹Ï‚ (see cr. n.) is far the most probable reading. The loss of the second Î¹, leaving Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„á½·Î±Ï‚, would easily have brought in á¼Î»á½¹Ï‚, which the metre shows to be superfluous. ÎºÎµÎ»Î±Î¹Î½á½°Î½ Î¸á¿–Î½Î±, the dark-coloured mud or sand that the storm stirs up from the bottom of the sea. Î¸á½·Ï‚ is masc. in Homer, Ar. , and Arist. , and that was prob. its usual gender. Vesp. 696 á½¥Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Ï… Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¸á¿–Î½Î± Ï„Î±Ïá½±Ï„Ï„ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ (my very depths). Verg. G. 3. 240 at ima exaestuat unda Vorticibus, nigramque alte subiectat arenam.

á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ï€Î»á¿†Î³ÎµÏ‚ (only here) á¼€ÎºÏ„Î±á½·, headlands which are struck in front, struck full, by the waves; in contrast with Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï€Î»á¿†Î³ÎµÏ‚, â€˜struck obliquelyâ€™: see Od. 5.417 (Odysseus seeking a place to land) á¼¤Î½ Ï€Î¿Ï… á¼Ï†Îµá½»ÏÏ‰ | á¼ Ï„Î¿Î½á½±Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï€Î»á¿†Î³Î±Ï‚ Î»Î¹Î¼á½³Î½Î±Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Î¸Î±Î»á½±ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚ (â€˜shores where the waves strike aslantâ€™). Soph. was doubtless thinking of the Homeric phrase.â€”Not (1) â€˜beating back the waves,â€™ á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï„Ï…Ï€Î¿Î¹: nor (2) â€˜beaten again,â€™â€”i.e. by the everreturning waves. 595 Ï€á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± Ï†Î¸Î¹Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€á½µÎ¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€á½·Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½Ï„â€™,

Line 596

Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá½°Î½ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚: cp. 1067 Î½á½³ÎºÏ…Î½ Î½ÎµÎºÏá¿¶Î½: Ai. 475 Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼¦Î¼Î±Ï á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±.â€”The subject to á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ (á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼ÏÎµá½·Ï€ÎµÎ¹ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ being parenthetical) is â€˜the Labdacid house,â€™ i.e. Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá½± in the larger sense (585), supplied from Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá½±Î½ just before. This is simpler than to supply Ï€á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± as subject.

Î»á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½, deliverance from trouble, as O. T. 921, Tr. 1171.

Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚, Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ Î»á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î½. Î½á¿¦Î½ Î³á½°Ï á¼ÏƒÏ‡á½±Ï„Î±Ï‚ á½•Ï€ÎµÏ
600 á¿¥á½·Î¶Î±Ï‚ á½ƒ Ï„á½³Ï„Î±Ï„Î¿ Ï†á½±Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î½ ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Ï… Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚,
ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ Î±á½– Î½Î¹Î½ Ï†Î¿Î¹Î½á½·Î± Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î½ÎµÏÏ„á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 601

ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ Î±á½– â€¦ á¼€Î¼á¾·, = ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î¼á¾· Î±á½–, â€˜mows down in its turnâ€™ (not, â€˜otherwise than we hopedâ€™). In my first edition I adopted the conjecture ÎºÎ¿Ï€á½·Ï‚. Prof. Tyrrell's able defence of the MS. Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Ï‚ (Classical Review, vol. 11. p. 139), though it has not removed all my difficulties, has led me to feel that more can be said for that reading than I had recognised. I now prefer, therefore, to leave Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Ï‚ in the text, and to re-state here the arguments for and against it.

(1) If Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Ï‚ be right, Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Ï‚ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î½ÎµÏÏ„á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ is the dust, belonging (due) to the gods infernal, which Antigone strewed on her brother's corpse; it is Ï†Î¿Î¹Î½á½·Î±, because the corpse was gory. The strongest point in favour of Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Ï‚ is that it is in harmony with the following words, Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï… Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½Î¿Î¹Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á¿¶Î½ á¼ÏÎ¹Î½á½»Ï‚. The whole sense then is: â€˜She, tooâ€”the last hope of the raceâ€”is now to die,â€”for a handful of blood-stained dust (i.e., for a slight, yet obligatory, act of piety towards her slain brother)â€”and for those rash words to Creon,â€”the expression of her frenzied resolve.â€™ On the other hand, the objection to Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Ï‚ is the verb ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î¼á¾·, which implies the metaphor of reaping. (See Appendix.) The proposed version, â€˜covers,â€™ is impossible, and, if possible, would be unsuitable. What we want is a verb meaning simply â€˜destroys,â€™ or â€˜dooms to death.â€™ Now it is true that Greek lyric poetry often tolerates some confusion of metaphor (see on v. 117, and cp. O. T. p. lviii): the question is whether this example of it be tolerable. Prof. Tyrrell holds that it is excused by the tumult of feeling in the mind of the Chorus. That is, the metaphor of a young life â€˜mowed downâ€™ is not completed by a mention of the agent, the Destroyer: it is swiftly succeeded in the speaker's thought by a dramatic image of the cause, Antigone sprinkling the dust, and defying Creon. This is conceivable; but it is at least extremely bold.

(2) If we read ÎºÎ¿Ï€á½·Ï‚, then ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î¼á¾· is appropriate, and Ï†Î¿Î¹Î½á½·Î± also has a more evident fitness. The great objection is the want of unison with Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï… Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½Î¿Î¹Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á¿¶Î½ á¼ÏÎ¹Î½á½»Ï‚. If the Ï„â€™ after Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï… means â€˜both,â€™ the ÎºÎ¿Ï€á½¶Ï‚ Î½ÎµÏÏ„á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ is the deadly agency as seen in the girl's rash speech and resolve: if the Ï„â€™ means â€˜and,â€™ it is an agency to which these things are superadded. On either view the language is awkward. This must be set against the gain in unity of metaphor.

It has further been urged against ÎºÎ¿Ï€á½·Ï‚ that the word is too homely. This may be so; but we lack proof. ÎºÎ¿Ï€á½·Ï‚ seems to have been a large curved knife, known to the Greeks chiefly as (a) a butcher's or cook's implement, (b) an oriental military weapon. It does not follow, however, that the effect here would be like that of â€˜chopper,â€™ or of â€˜scimitar,â€™ in English. The dignity of a word may be protected by its simplicity; and ÎºÎ¿Ï€á½·Ï‚ is merely â€˜that which cuts.â€™ Pindar was not afraid of homeliness when he described a chorus-master as a ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½µÏ, or an inspiring thought as an á¼€Îºá½¹Î½Î± (cp. O. C. 1052 n.). Nicander could say, of the scorpion, Ï„Î¿á½·Î· Î¿á¼± Îºá½³Î½Ï„ÏÎ¿Î¹Î¿ ÎºÎ¿Ï€á½·Ï‚ (Ther. 780). If ÎºÎ¿Ï€á½·Ï‚ be right, the change to Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Ï‚ may have been caused, not by a misreading of letters, but by mere inadvertence,â€”the copyist having the word Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Ï‚ in his thoughts at the moment: it has already occurred frequently (247, 256, 409, 429).â€”See Appendix.

á¼€Î¼á¾· Îºá½¹Î½Î¹Ï‚ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï… Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½Î¿Î¹Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á¿¶Î½ á¼ÏÎ¹Î½á½»Ï‚.
Î§Î¿. 605 Ï„Îµá½±Î½, Î–Îµá¿¦, Î´á½»Î½Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Ï„á½·Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÎ²Î±Ïƒá½·Î± ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î¹;

Line 606

The MS. Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚ is unquestionably corrupt. Sleep, the renewer of vigour, could not be described as â€˜bringing old age to all.â€™ Nor can the epithet be explained as â€˜enfeebling all,â€™ in the sense of â€˜subduing themâ€™; nor, again, as â€˜attending on all, even to old age.â€™ The neighbourhood of á¼€Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚ is not in favour of Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚, but against it; in the case of Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï€á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚â€”á¼„Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (360), and of á½‘Ïˆá½·Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Ï‚â€”á¼„Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Ï‚ (370), there is a direct contrast between the two words. Either Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼€Î³Ïá¿¶Î½ or Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î±Î³ÏÎµá½ºÏ‚ (see cr. n.) would be good, if Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ could be taken from the next verse, and added to this. But Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ clearly belongs, I think, to the next verse,â€”as will be seen presently. Bamberger proposed Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Î¸á½µÏÎ±Ï‚, or Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¹Î¸Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚. The former would be a subst. like á¼°Ï‡Î¸Ï…Î¿Î¸á½µÏÎ±Ï‚, â€˜fisherman,â€™ á½€ÏÎ½Î¹Î¸Î¿Î¸á½µÏÎ±Ï‚, â€˜fowlerâ€™: the latter (which I should prefer), an adj. like Ï€Î¿Î»á½»Î¸Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚, â€˜catching muchâ€™ (Heliodorus 5. 18), Îµá½”Î¸Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚, â€˜having good sport.â€™ Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¹Î¸Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚ would suit the sense well. But its probability depends on the way in which we conceive the corrupt Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚ to have arisen. It is evident that the genuine á¼€Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚ in the next line had something to do with it. It seems most likely that the eye of the transcriber who first wrote Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚ had wandered to á¼€Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚, and that by a mere inadvertence he gave a like ending to the earlier word. Now this might most easily have happened if the sixth letter of the earlier series had been Î“, but would obviously have been less likely if that letter had been Î˜. I therefore think it more probable that Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚ arose from Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼€Î³ÏÎµá½»Ï‰Î½ than from Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¹Î¸Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚. It is immaterial that the last four letters of the latter are nearer to the MS., since, on the view just stated, the transcriber's error arose from the fact that the consecutive letters á¼€Î³ were common to á¼€Î³ÏÎµá½»Ï‰Î½ and á¼€Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚, and that, from these letters onwards, he accidentally copied á¼€Î³á½µÏÏ‰Ï‚. It may be added that such an error would have been easier with a separate word like á¼€Î³ÏÎµá½»Ï‰Î½ than with the second part of a compound like Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¹Î¸Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚.â€”The verb á¼€Î³ÏÎµá½»Ï‰, â€˜to catchâ€™ (common both in verse and in prose) is used by Soph. in fr. 507.â€” Soph. was thinking of Il. 14.244 ff. á¼ Î³á½°Ï Î´á½µ Îº.Ï„.Î». The Î³á½±Ï introduces an explanation of the law just stated. â€˜No inordinate desire comes to men without bringing á¼„Ï„Î·. For hope, which can be a blessing, can also be a curse, by luring a man to pursue forbidden things; and then he sins blindly, till the gods strike him. The gods cause him to mistake evil for good; and his impunity is of short duration.â€™ Creon is destined to exemplify this. Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼€Ï€á½±Ï„Î± ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ï†Î¿Î½á½¹Ï‰Î½ á¼Ïá½½Ï„Ï‰Î½Â· ğŸ—©
Line 616

Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ á½„Î½Î±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚, by cheering them, and inciting to worthy effort. This clause is inserted merely for the sake of contrast with the next. When Greek idiom thus co-ordinates two clauses, the clause which we should subordinate to the other is that which has Î¼á½³Î½; as here, â€˜though a blessing to many.â€™ So O. C. 1536 (n.), Îµá½– Î¼á½²Î½ á½€Ïˆá½³ Î´â€™, â€˜late, though surely.â€™

Line 617

á¼€Ï€á½±Ï„Î± â€¦ á¼Ïá½½Ï„Ï‰Î½. The gen. is best taken as subjective, a cheating (of men) by desires; i.e., á¼”ÏÏ‰Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼€Ï€Î±Ï„á¿¶ÏƒÎ¹. (like other ancient poets) easily tolerated repetition of words (see on O. C. 554); secondly, that tragic lyrics could admit refrains, and might, by a kindred instinct, permit such verbal echoes as these.

This shows that Ï„á¾¶Î»Î¹Ï‚ could mean, not only an affianced bride, but also a bride after marriage: just as Î½á½»Î¼Ï†Î· can mean either. The epithet Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»Î¿Î³á½±Î¼Î¿Ï… is not, then, superfluous; and Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»Î¿Î½á½»Î¼Ï†Î¿Ï… in 633 is no argument against it. His point is simply that á¼¡ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»á½¹Î½Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ï‚ is more correct than á¼¡ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»Î¿Î½á½»Î¼Ï†Î·.â€”Curtius connects Ï„á¾¶Î»Î¹Ï‚ with Ï„á½³Ïâ€Î·Î½, tender; Î¸Ïá½¹Î½Î±, flowers: Sanskrit ta/r-una-s, youthful, tender, ta/l-unI, girl, young woman. Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î±Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï‚, having good counsels, á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¸Î¿á¿–Ï‚ (Î±á½Ï„á½±Ï‚) Î¼Î¿Î¹, thou settest them before me as rules. á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¸á½¹Ï‰ (a rare word) means, like á¼€Ï€ÎµÏ…Î¸á½»Î½Ï‰, (1) â€˜to straighten out.â€™ and then (2) â€˜to guide in a straight course.â€™ Plat. ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ á¼¡Î³Î¿Ï…Î¼., (with Î¼Îµá½·Î¶Ï‰Î½), than thy good guiding: cp. Her. 1.34 Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° Î´á½² Î£á½¹Î»Ï‰Î½Î± Î¿á¼°Ï‡á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½. â€”It is a mistake (I think) to detect a mental reserve in the participle (â€˜than thy guiding, if, or when, it is goodâ€™). Haemon knows that his one chance of saving Antigone is first to mollify his father, and then to urge the argument from public opinion (688 ff.). His deference is unqualified.

Î³á½±Ï in assent (O. T. 1117).

Î´Î¹á½° ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ½Ï‰Î½ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½, lit., â€˜to be disposed in one's breast,â€™=Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½, or Î´Î¹Î±ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. The phrase differs in two points from others which seem like it. (1) The gen. with Î´Î¹á½± in such phrases regularly denotes a state or act of the mind, whereas ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ½Ï‰Î½ represents the mind itself. (2) á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ in such phrases is always trans., the intrans. verb being Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹. Thus á¼”Ï‡Ï‰ Ï„Î¹Î½á½± (or Ï„Î¹) Î´á¿‘ Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î½Î·Ï‚, Î±á¼°Ï„á½·Î±Ï‚, á½€ÏÎ³á¿†Ï‚, Ï†Ï…Î»Î±Îºá¿†Ï‚, etc. But Îµá¼°Î¼á½¶ Î´á¿‘ á¼¡ÏƒÏ…Ï‡á½·Î·Ï‚ (Her. 1.206), Î´Î¹á½° Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Ï… (Thuc. 6.59), Î´á¿‘ á½„Ï‡Î»Î¿Ï… (Aristoph. Line 659

Ï„á½± Î³â€™ á¼Î³Î³. Ï†á½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹, those who, by birth, are relatives: for the place of the adverbial Ï†á½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹, cp. El. 792 Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼€ÏÏ„á½·Ï‰Ï‚, Aesch. á¼„ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÎ¼Î±, unruly: so of Thersites, Il. 2.213 á½…Ï‚ á¿¥â€™ á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ± Ï†ÏÎµÏƒá½¶Î½ á¾—ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼„ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÎ¼á½± Ï„Îµ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½± Ï„Îµ á¾”Î´Î·, | Î¼á½±Ïˆ, á¼€Ï„á½°Ï Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Îºá½¹ÏƒÎ¼Î¿Î½, á¼ÏÎ¹Î¶á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î±Î¹ Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»Îµá¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½. Cp. 730.

Î¸Ïá½³ÏˆÏ‰ with predicative adj., as 1080, O. T. 98, etc.

Îºá½±ÏÏ„Î± Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼”Î¾Ï‰ Î³., sc. á¼€Îºá½¹ÏƒÎ¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î¸Ïá½³ÏˆÏ‰. It is needless to supply a more general verb, like Ï€Î¿Î¹á½µÏƒÏ‰: the ruler's relation to his people justifies Î¸Ïá½³ÏˆÏ‰: cp. O. T. 1 á½¦ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î±. â€˜If I allow my own kindred to be unruly, I shall be obliged to tolerate unruliness in the citizens at large. For my authority as a ruler will be gone.â€™

660 á¼„ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÎ¼Î± Î¸Ïá½³ÏˆÏ‰, Îºá½±ÏÏ„Î± Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼”Î¾Ï‰ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚
á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á¼°ÎºÎµá½·Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ á¼”ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼€Î½á½´Ï ğŸ—©
Line 661661-671

Seidler transposes vv. 663â€”667, placing them after 671. The object is to bring vv. 668â€”671 into immediate connection with 662. In this there is one slight grammatical gain; since, as the vv. stand in the MSS., Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ ...Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± (668) means, â€˜the man who acts thusâ€™ (viz., as described in vv. 666 f.). But the order given in the MSS. is right. The transposition obliterates one of the finest touches in the speech. Creon demands that the obedience of the citizens to the ruler shall be absolute (666 f.). And then he supplements this demand with a remark on the dignity of such obedience. The man who so obeys gives the best proof that he could also rule (668 ff.). Seidler destroys the point of vv. 668 ff. by placing them after 662.

The connection of thought in the whole passageâ€”which is slightly obscured by compressionâ€”may be most clearly shown by taking the verses in small consecutive groups. (1) 659 f. If I tolerate disloyalty

in my own relatives, I shall encourage it in other citizens. (2) 661 f. For (Î³á½±Ï) only a man who is firm (Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÏ„á½¹Ï‚) where his own relatives are concerned will be found to uphold justice in the State (i.e. will have the authority necessary for doing so). (3) 663 f. Now, I recognise disloyalty in any one who breaks the law and defies the government, as Antigone has done. (4) 666 f. Instead of so doing, the citizen is bound to obey the government in everything. (5) 668â€”671. There is nothing slavish in that; on the contrary, it shows that the citizen is not only a good subject, but would, if required, be a good ruler;â€”as he would also be a good soldier.â€”Then comes the general censure on unruliness (672â€”676). And then the conclusion:â€”I must vindicate my authority, and punish Antigone (677 â€”680).

á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ Î´â€™ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÎ²á½°Ï‚ á¼¢ Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î²Î¹á½±Î¶ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ ğŸ—©
Line 663

Line 674

ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î¼á½±Ï‡Î¿Ï… is a certain correction of L's ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î¼á½±Ï‡Î·Î¹. The meaning is, â€˜Disobedience causes allied forces (Ïƒá½»Î¼Î¼Î±Ï‡Î¿Î½ Î´á½¹ÏÏ…) to break up in flight.â€™ It turns union into disunion,â€”the hope of victory into defeat. With Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î¼á½±Ï‡á¿ƒ the sense would be, â€˜Disobedience, aiding the spear (of the foe), causes rout.â€™ But this would represent disobedience as merely one cause of defeat,â€”an incident that turns the scale. It is evidently more forcible to represent it as breaking up an army which might otherwise have stood united and firm.

Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï€á½°Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏÏá½µÎ³Î½Ï…ÏƒÎ¹, lit., causes rout to break forth, i.e. breaks up the army in rout. Cp. Athen. 130 C á½ Î³ÎµÎ»Ï‰Ï„Î¿Ï€Î¿Î¹á½¸Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ïƒá¿†Î»Î¸Îµ...ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á½ºÏ‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÏÏÎ·Î¾ÎµÎ½ á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½ Î³á½³Î»Ï‰Ï„Î±Ï‚, â€˜and caused shouts of laughter to break forth among usâ€™: (not, â€˜wreaked many witticisms upon us,â€™â€”as Casaubon took it.) The only peculiarity in the use of the verb is that it is here equiv. to Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿– ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏÏá½µÎ³Î½Ï…ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. We cannot compare Theocr. 22. 172 Î½Îµá¿–ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î±ÏÏá½µÎ¾Î±Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚, â€˜having broken into strifeâ€™ (said of the parties to it), which is merely like á¿¥á¿†Î¾Î±Î¹ Ï†Ï‰Î½á½µÎ½, etc.

Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÎ¼Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ (neut.), the regulations made by Î¿á¼± ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÎ¼Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, the rulers: meaning here, his own edicts. For the act. ÎºÎ¿ÏƒÎ¼Îµá¿–Î½, cp. Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½·. Creon had urged that filial piety demands the submission of the son's judgment to the Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î· Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î± (640); and had warned Haemon against disregarding the voice of reason (648). Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹Ï‚, causal dat.: thy face is terrible to the citizen on account of such words as shall displease thee: i.e. the citizen imagines the stern king's face growing darker at the sound of frank speech, and restrains his lips. Î¿á½Î´â€™, not even: O. C. 1429 (n.) Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼€Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î¼ÎµÎ½ Ï†Î»Î±á¿¦ÏÎ±. So far am I from showing honour to evil-doers, that I would not even wish others to do so. ÎšÏ. 750 Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î·Î½ Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼”ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á½¡Ï‚ á¼”Ï„Î¹ Î¶á¿¶ÏƒÎ±Î½ Î³Î±Î¼Îµá¿–Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 750750-757

Objections have been made to the traditional order of these verses, chiefly in two respects. (1) 755 Îµá¼° Î¼á½´ Ï€Î±Ï„á½´Ï á¼¦ÏƒÎ¸â€™ isâ€”it is arguedâ€”the strongest thing said by Haemon, and ought therefore to come immediately before Creon's final outburst, á¼„Î»Î·Î¸ÎµÏ‚; (758). How could it be followed by merely so mild a phrase as Î¼á½´ Îºá½½Ï„Î¹Î»Î»á½³ Î¼Îµ?â€”We may reply:â€” Haemon says that, if Creon were not his father, he would have thought him mad. It is to this that Î¼á½´ Îºá½½Ï„Î¹Î»Î»á½³ Î¼Îµ refers, meaning, â€˜Do not seek to deceive me by an affectation of filial deference.â€™ (2) 757 Î²Î¿á½»Î»ÎµÎ¹ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï„Î¹ is too mild a remarkâ€”it is saidâ€”to form the climax of provocation to Creon's anger. We may reply:â€”It is in substance, if not in form, such a climax, â€”for a father who holds that unquestioning obedience (640) is a son's first duty. It asserts Haemon's right to maintain his own views against his father's,â€”Î´Î¹á½° Î´á½·ÎºÎ·Ï‚ á¼°á½³Î½Î±Î¹, as Creon put it (742). The traditional order seems, therefore, to be right.

Three modes of transposition have been proposed. (1) Enger puts 756 and 757 after 749. Then Îºá½½Ï„Î¹Î»Î»Îµ (756) refers to Haemon's plea that he has his father's cause, and that of religion, at heart. We lose nothing by such a transposition; but neither do we gain.

(2) Donner (in his transl., ed. 1863) simply transposed verses 755 and 757, leaving the rest as they stand. For this it may fairly be said that 757 comes very fitly after 754. On the other hand it seems to me that 756 does not aptly follow 757.

(3) Pallis arranges thus:â€”749, 756, 755, 754, 757, 750â€”753. Thus ÎºÎµÎ½á½°Ï‚ Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î±Ï‚ (753) becomes the last sting.â€” The fact is that, in a stormy altercation, we do not look for a closely logical texture and a delicately graduated crescendo. The MS. order is (to my mind) the best; but other arrangements are possible, and would be nearly as good.

Creon, instead of replying to v. 749, abruptly repeats his resolve. Î¿á½Îº á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á½¡Ï‚ Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î·Î½ á¼”Ï„Î¹ Î¶á¿¶ÏƒÎ±Î½ Î³Î±Î¼Îµá¿–Ï‚ (fut.) Ï€Î¿Ï„á½³, it cannot be that you shall ever wed her while she yet lives; i.e. she is to die at once, and can become your bride, if ever, only á¼Î½ á¼Î¹Î´Î¿Ï… (654). Ï„á½¼ Î´â€™ Î¿á½–Î½ Îºá½¹ÏÎ± Ï„á½½Î´â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€Î±Î»Î»á½±Î¾ÎµÎ¹ Î¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï…. ğŸ—©

Ï„á½¼ â€¦ Ï„á½½Î´Îµ: cp. 561 (Ï„á½½), O. T. 1472 (Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½), O. C. 1600 (Ï„á½½), El. 977 (Ï„á½½Î´Îµ Ï„á½½ï¼‰â€”all fem.â€”Attic inscriptions of c. 450â€” 320 B.C. present numerous instances of fem. dual Ï„á½½, Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½, Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹Î½, Î¿á¼¶Î½, but no instance of fem. dual Ï„á½±, Ï„Î±á¿–Î½, Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î±Î¹Î½, or Î±á¼·Î½. (Meisterhans p. 50.) Hitherto the gen. and dat. Ï„Î±á¿–Î½, Ï„Î±á¿–Î½Î´Îµ, Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î±Î¹Î½ have been retained even by those edd. who give Ï„á½½, Ï„á½½Î´Îµ, etc. (cp. O. T. 1462, 1504: O. C. 445, 859, 1149, 1290, etc.). But, so far as epigraphic evidence goes, the distinction is arbitrary.

ÎºÏá½»ÏˆÏ‰ Ï€ÎµÏ„Ïá½½Î´ÎµÎ¹ Î¶á¿¶ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½½ÏÏ…Ï‡Î¹, ğŸ—©
Line 774

Ï€ÎµÏ„Ïá½½Î´ÎµÎ¹ â€¦ á¼Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½½ÏÏ…Ï‡Î¹, â€˜in a rocky cavernâ€™; schol., á¼Î½ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î³Îµá½·á¿³ ÏƒÏ€Î·Î»Î±á½·á¿³. Verse 773 shows that Creon is not yet thinking of any particular spot. And ÎºÎ±Ï„á¿¶ÏÏ…Î¾ shows that he is not thinking of some merely natural grotto or cavern. This word, usu. an adj., here a subst., means a cavern, or chamber, excavated by man's hand: cp. Eur. Hec. 1002 Ï‡ÏÏ…ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹Î±á½¶ Î ÏÎ¹Î±Î¼Î¹Î´á¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½½ÏÏ…Ï‡ÎµÏ‚. So the place is described by ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÎºÎ±Ï†á½µÏ‚ (891). The ÎºÎ±Ï„á¿¶ÏÏ…Î¾ actually used was near the furthest and highest part of the plain, where Polyneices lay (1197). What, then, was the poet's conception? He seems to suppose the existence of tombs artificially constructed in the rocky Ï€á½±Î³Î¿Î¹ (411) which bordered on the Theban plain. In one of these tombsâ€” chosen for the remoteness of its situation (773)â€”Antigone is to be immured. The general type of sepulchral chamber supposed here can be illustrated from actual remains which have been discovered in Greece: see below on vv. 1216 ff.

775 Ï†Î¿ÏÎ²á¿†Ï‚ Ï„Î¿ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ á½¡Ï‚ á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚, ğŸ—©
Line 775

á½¡Ï‚ á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½, sc. Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹, so much as to be barely an expiation; only just enough to avoid the Î¼á½·Î±ÏƒÎ¼Î±. The conjectural change of á½¡Ï‚ into á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î½ (adopted by several edd.) would be necessary if the indic. á¼ÏƒÏ„á½· had to be supplied, since we could not say Ï„Î¿ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ á½¡Ï‚ (instead of á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î½) á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·. That change is unnecessary, because it is the inf. Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ that is understood. Cp. Xen. An. 7. 3Â§ 22 á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Î³Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, and see n. on O. C. 790 for other instances where the inf. is expressed. The inf. is understood, as here, in Xen. An. 7. 8Â§ 19 á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï€Ïá½¹Î²Î±Ï„Î± á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Î¸á½»Î¼Î±Ï„Î± (sc. Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹): so ib. 7. 3 Â§ 20 á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½...á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î½ á¼Ï†á½¹Î´Î¹Î¿Î½.

á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ was used by Soph. in his lost Phaedra to denote á¼…Î³Î½Î¹ÏƒÎ¼Î± Î¸Ï…Ïƒá½·Î±Ï‚ (Hesych. 1. 63), i.e. â€˜an expiatory sacrificeâ€™ (cp. Aesch. Eum. 325 á¼…Î³Î½Î¹ÏƒÎ¼Î± Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…). In Aesch. Cho. 154 also á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ has been taken as=â€˜expiation,â€™ but there it seems rather to be â€˜pollution.â€™ Cp. the schol. here: á¼”Î¸Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹á½¹Î½, á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¸ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³Î½á½»Î½Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¹Î½á½° á¼€Ï†Î¿ÏƒÎ¹Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡á½º Ï„Î¹Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†á¿†Ï‚, ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ½á½¹Î¿Ï…Î½ Îºá½±Î¸Î±ÏÏƒÎ¹Î½ Ï„á½¸ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿, á¼µÎ½Î± Î¼á½´ Î´Î¿Îºá¿¶ÏƒÎ¹ Î»Î¹Î¼á¿· á¼€Î½Î±Î¹ÏÎµá¿–Î½Â· Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Î³á½°Ï á¼€ÏƒÎµÎ²á½³Ï‚.â€”Curtius, Etym. 5th ed., Â§ 118, would write á¼…Î³Î¿Ï‚ here. He distinguishes two roots. (1) á¼€Î³â€, á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚, â€˜guilt,â€™ á¼Î½Î±Î³á½µÏ‚, â€˜accursedâ€™; Sanskr. Aa/g-as, â€˜vexation,â€™ etc. (2) á¼Î³â€, á¼…Î³Î¿Ï‚, â€˜consecration, sacrifice,â€™ á¼…Î³Î¹Î¿Ï‚, etc.: Sanskr. jag-. On the other hand the analogy of piaculum suggests that á¼„Î³Î¿Ï‚ might combine the sense of â€˜expiationâ€™ with that of â€˜pollution.â€™

Creon's edict had announced that the transgressor would be publicly stoned to death (36). It is to this that the anxious question of the Chorus alludes (772). Creon had already said that Antigone's doom was to be Îºá½±ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ (489). But now, at least, he feels that he cannot inflict such a death on the maiden, his kinswoman. She shall die, not by stoning, but by starvation. The choice is not prompted by cruelty, but simply by the desire to avoid physical violence.

The danger of a Î¼á½·Î±ÏƒÎ¼Î±â€”to be avoided by a dole of foodâ€”has no relation to the special circumstances,â€”Antigone's royal birth, and the nature of her offence. In the ancient belief, that danger existed whenever a person was put to death by starvation. Two notions were probably blended; (a) that, if a little food was given, the death was nature's work, not man's; (b) that the Î½á½³ÏÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Î¹ claimed an indemnity for the usual á¼Î½Î±Î³á½·ÏƒÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±. So the Greeks put Philoctetes ashore on desolate Lemnos, â€”á¿¥á½±ÎºÎ· Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¸á½³Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Î²Î±Î¹á½° ÎºÎ±á½· Ï„Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î²Î¿Ïá¾¶Ï‚ | á¼Ï€Ï‰Ï†á½³Î»Î·Î¼Î± ÏƒÎ¼Î¹ÎºÏá½¹Î½ ( Ph. 274). So, too, when a Vestal was to be buried alive, the small vault in the Campus Sceleratus was furnished with a couch, a burning lamp, and a small table, on which the dole was placed,â€”bread, olives, milk, and a jug of water ( Plut. Num. 10).

á¼Î½ ÎºÏ„á½µÎ¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€á½·Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, who fallest upon men's possessions; who makest havoc of their wealth and fortunes. Cp. Od. 24.526 á¼Î½ Î´â€™ á¼”Ï€ÎµÏƒÎ¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¼á½±Ï‡Î¿Î¹Ï‚, â€˜they fell on the fore-fightersâ€™: so á¼Î¼Ï€á½·Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½ is oft. said of the attacks of disease or passion. Love makes men reckless of possessions: it can bring ruin on great houses and proud cities. Sophocles himself has given us the best commentary: see Tr. 431, referring to the capture of Oechalia by Heracles, who loved IolÃ¨, the daughter of its king, Eurytus: á½¡Ï‚ Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î·Ï‚ Ï€á½¹Î¸á¿³ | Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Ï‚ Î´Î±Î¼Îµá½·Î· Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ±, ÎºÎ¿á½Ï‡ á¼¡ Î›Ï…Î´á½·Î± | Ï€á½³ÏÏƒÎµÎ¹ÎµÎ½ Î±á½Ï„á½µÎ½, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´â€™ á¼”ÏÏ‰Ï‚ Ï†Î±Î½Îµá½·Ï‚. The same thought is finely expressed by Eur. , in a choral ode to á¼œÏÏ‰Ï‚, which this passage has certainly helped to inspire ( Eur. Hipp. 525 ff.): á¼œÏÏ‰Ï„Î± Î´á½³, Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï„á½»ÏÎ±Î½Î½Î¿Î½ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½, | ...Î¿á½ ÏƒÎµÎ²á½·Î¶Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½, | Ï€á½³ÏÎ¸Î¿Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´Î¹á½° Ï€á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ | á¼°á½¹Î½Ï„Î± ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá¾¶Ï‚ | Î¸Î½Î±Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚, á½…Ï„Î±Î½ á¼”Î»Î¸á¿ƒ. The resistless power of Love is the central thought of this ode. All that men prize most becomes his prey.â€”See Appendix.

á¼”Î½ Ï„â€™ á¼€Î³Ï. Î±á½Î»Î±á¿–Ï‚. á¼€Î³Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î¼Î¿Î¹ Î±á½Î»Î±á½· =dwellings in á¼€Î³Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î½ÎµÎ¼á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚, pastoral wilds: cp. 349 á¼€Î³ÏÎ±á½»Î»Î¿Ï…: O. T. 26).â€”Some take the sense to be, â€˜Love conquers not man only, but fishes and wild beastsâ€™; cp. fr. 856.9 (Îšá½»Ï€ÏÎ¹Ï‚) Îµá¼°Ïƒá½³ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼°Ï‡Î¸á½»Ï‰Î½ Ï€Î»Ï‰Ï„á¿· Î³á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹, | á¼”Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹ Î´â€™ á¼Î½ Ï‡á½³ÏÏƒÎ¿Ï… Ï„ÎµÏ„ÏÎ±ÏƒÎºÎµÎ»Îµá¿– Î³Î¿Î½á¿‡. (How could á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÏ€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¹Î¿Ï‚ imply a visit to the fish?) Others find a reference to Paris carrying Helen over the Aegean, Aphrodite visiting Anchises in the pastures of Ida, etc. Rather the poet is merely saying, quite generally, how boundless is the range of Love.

ÎºÎ±á½· Ïƒâ€™ Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼€Î¸Î±Î½á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ Ï†á½»Î¾Î¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´Îµá½¶Ï‚

á¼€Î´á½·ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ï‚ proleptic: cp. on 475: Tr. 106 Îµá½Î½á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼€Î´Î±ÎºÏá½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ Î²Î»ÎµÏ†á½±ÏÏ‰Î½ Ï€á½¹Î¸Î¿Î½ (so that they shall not weep).â€” Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÏƒÏ€á¾·Ï‚ (cp. 298), a metaphor from a driver jerking his horses aside out of their course: El. 732 (the charioteer) á¼”Î¾Ï‰ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÏƒÏ€á¾· (sc. 795 Î½Î¹Îºá¾· Î´â€™ á¼Î½Î±ÏÎ³á½´Ï‚ Î²Î»ÎµÏ†á½±ÏÏ‰Î½ á¼µÎ¼ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚ Îµá½Î»á½³ÎºÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï… ğŸ—©
Line 795

á¼Î½Î±ÏÎ³á½µÏ‚, â€˜clearly seen,â€™ â€˜present to the lover's sight,â€™ marks the vivid appeal to the senses, in contrast with the invisible and spiritual majesty of the Î¸ÎµÏƒÎ¼Î¿á½· which Love overrides. For á¼Î½Î±ÏÎ³á½µÏ‚ as =â€˜before our eyes,â€™ â€˜in bodily presence,â€™ cp. O. C. 910; Tr. 11, 224.

Î²Î»ÎµÏ†á½±ÏÏ‰Î½á¼µÎ¼ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚, love-influence from the eyes, Îµá½Î»á½³ÎºÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï… Î½á½»Î¼Ï†Î±Ï‚, of the fair bride. Both genitives are possessive, but Î²Î»ÎµÏ†á½±ÏÏ‰Î½ goes more closely with á¼µÎ¼ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚, denoting the latter's source. Cp. 929: O. C. 729 á½€Î¼Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½... | Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Î½...Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼Î¼á¿†Ï‚ á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïƒá½¹Î´Î¿Ï…, fear, shown in your eyes (possess. gen.), of my entrance (objective gen.). In Phaedr. 251 B Plato describes á¼µÎ¼ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚ as the desire infused into the soul by an emanation of beauty (Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏÏÎ¿á½µ) proceeding from the beloved, and received through the eyes of the lover (Î´Î¹á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½€Î¼Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½). So the soul is spoken of (ib. So Soph. fr. 161 á½€Î¼Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼„Ï€Î¿ | Î»á½¹Î³Ï‡Î±Ï‚ á¼µÎ·ÏƒÎ¹Î½: 733 á½€Î¼Î¼á½±Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ Ï€á½¹Î¸Î¿Ï‚: 430 (Hippodameia speaking of Pelops), Ï„Î¿Î¹á½±Î½Î´â€™ á¼Î½ á½„ÏˆÎµÎ¹ Î»á½·Î³Î³Î± Î¸Î·ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Ïá½·Î±Î½ | á¼”ÏÏ‰Ï„Î¿Ï‚, á¼€ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï€á½µÎ½ Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á½€Î¼Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½, á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ (â€˜such a subduing arrow of love, a lightning from the eyesâ€™): Aesch. Line 804

Ï€Î±Î³ÎºÎ¿á½·Ï„Î·Î½. The question between Doric and Attic forms in tragic anapaests cannot be decided by a rigid rule. It depends on the presence or absence of a lyric character. Thus in 110 f. the Doricisms are justified by the purely lyric stamp of the anapaests. Here, Attic forms are preferable. The lyric strains

of Antigone are brought into finer relief by the different tone of the choral anapaests. Cp. 822, and see Appendix on 110.â€”Cp. O. C. 1578 (Death) Ï„á½¸Î½ Î±á¼°á½³Î½Ï…Ï€Î½Î¿Î½. Î¾Î¹Ï†á½³Ï‰Î½ (possessive gen.) á¼Ï€á½·Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ±, â€˜the wages of swords,â€™ i.e. the reward of strife with the sword,â€”viz. a violent death.
