Î¼Î¹Ï„á½½Î´ÎµÎ¹, thread-like, i.e., formed by a thread-wrought fabric (the ÏƒÎ¹Î½Î´á½½Î½), and not, as usual, by a cord. Î¼á½·Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (á½), the thread of the warp: Eur. I. Line 1223

Haemon has thrown his arms around her waist (á¼€Î¼Ï†á½¶ Î¼á½³ÏƒÏƒá¿ƒ Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Ï€ÎµÏ„á¿†), embracing her (Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎµá½·Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½), where she hangs lifeless. But verses 1236â€”1240 require us to suppose that Antigone's body is then stretched on the ground. We are left to understand that Haemon, while uttering his lament (1224 f.), has lifted the corpse, so as to extricate it from the noose, and has laid it down. Cp. O. Line 1232

Ï€Ï„á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½½Ï€á¿³. Haemon is momentarily insane with despair and rage: the very words Î±á½‘Ï„á¿· Ï‡Î¿Î»Ï‰Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚, 1235, indicate the transport of frenzy which these verses were meant to depict. Nothing could do more violence to the language, or more injury to the dramatic effect, than the Scholiast's theory that Ï€Ï„á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½½Ï€á¿³ has a merely figurative sense, â€˜with an expression of loathing on his face.â€™ When the figurative sense of a word (like Ï€Ï„á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚) is to be marked by a qualifying addition (like Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½½Ï€á¿³), that addition must not be such as equally to suggest the literal sense. Thus a socialist riot might be called â€˜a fire not of Hephaestusâ€™ (Eur. Or. 621); but it would not be equally happy to describe it as â€˜a fire kindled by the tables of the rich.â€™ Ï€Ï„á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½½Ï€á¿³, instead of á¼Ï€Î¹Ï€Ï„á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½½Ï€á¿³ (Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚), is merely an instance of the boldness with which poetry could use a simple dative to express the object to (or against) which an action is directed. Such a dat. is often equivalent to (a) á¼Ï€á½· with dat., (b) á¼Ï€á½·, Ï€Ïá½¹Ï‚, or Îµá¼°Ï‚, with acc., â€”in various relations, and with various shades of meaning. Thus we have such phrases as ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ Î³ÎµÎ»á¿¶Î½ (Ai. 1042)=ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼Ï€ÎµÎ³Î³ÎµÎ»á¿¶Î½: Ph. 67Î»á½»Ï€Î·Î½...á¼ˆÏÎ³Îµá½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î²Î±Î»Îµá¿–Ï‚ = á¼Î¼Î²Î±Î»Îµá¿–Ï‚: Eur. Suppl. 322 Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÎºÎµÏÏ„Î¿Î¼Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹ Î³Î¿ÏÎ³á½¸Î½ á½¡Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î±Î²Î»á½³Ï€ÎµÎ¹, how she looks up sternly at her revilers: Il. 7.101 Ï„á¿·Î´Îµ Î´â€™ á¼Î³á½¼Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Î¸Ï‰Ïá½µÎ¾Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹, against him: ib. 23. 635 á½…Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Î¹ á¼€Î½á½³ÏƒÏ„Î·, against me: and below 1236 á¼¤ÏÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎµ Ï€Î»ÎµÏ…ÏÎ±á¿–Ï‚ = á¼Ï€á½µÏÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎµ. Prose would have Ï€Ï„á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ (or á¼Ï€á½¶) Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ‰Ï€Î¿Î½.

á¼•Î»ÎºÎµÎ¹ Î´Î¹Ï€Î»Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚. á¼Îº Î´â€™ á½ÏÎ¼Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï… ğŸ—©
Line 1233

Î´Î¹Ï€Î»Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Î¾á½·Ï†Î¿Ï…Ï‚, his cross-hilted sword. ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ are the two projecting cross-pieces at the point where the hilt joins the blade. The hilt (Îºá½½Ï€Î·) of the Greek sword had no guard, nor had it always the cross-pieces; but these, when used, served partly to protect the hand. The ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, or cross-hilt, can be seen on some of the swords given by Guhl and Koner, p. 244, fig. 277 (a, d). The cross-hilt was sometimes simply a straight cross-bar; sometimes the side next the hand was rounded. Cp. Silius Italicus Pun. 1. 515 pressumque ira simul exigit ensem, | Qua capuli statuere morae. â€”ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Ï‰Î½ (ÎºÎ½á½±Ï‰, á½€Î´Î¿á½»Ï‚) meant properly any tooth-like prong or spike: see Cyneg. 10. 3, where boar-spears (Ï€ÏÎ¿Î²á½¹Î»Î¹Î±) have ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ á¼€Ï€Î¿ÎºÎµÏ‡Î±Î»ÎºÎµÏ…Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï†ÏÎ¿á½»Ï‚, stout teeth forged of bronze, projecting from the shaft a little below the head (Î»á½¹Î³Ï‡Î·). In Ai. 1025, Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ Î±á¼°á½¹Î»Î¿Ï… ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚, â€˜this gleaming spike,â€™ is the end of the sword-blade projecting through the body of Ajax. So in Kaibel Epigr. 549. 11 (an epitaph of the 1st cent. A.D. ) Ï†Î±ÏƒÎ³á½±Î½Î¿Ï… ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Î¿Î½Ï„Î¹=â€˜with the point (not, â€˜edgeâ€™) of the swordâ€™: the ref. is to thrusting, not cutting.â€”The Scholiast wrongly explains Î´Î¹Ï€Î»Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ by Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á¾¶Ï‚ á¼€ÎºÎ¼á½±Ï‚, â€˜double edge.â€™ This interpretation was obviously suggested by Î´Î¹Ï€Î»Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ (since a sword is often called Î´á½·ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¼Î¿Î½ or á¼„Î¼Ï†Î·ÎºÎµÏ‚), while the true sense of ÎºÎ½á½½Î´Ï‰Î½ was not accurately remembered: thus the Schol. vaguely calls it Ï„á½¸ á½€Î¾á½º Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¾á½·Ï†Î¿Ï…Ï‚.

á¼Îº Î´â€™ á½ÏÎ¼., tmesis: cp. 427.

Ï†Ï…Î³Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½, dat. of manner (620 n.). The poet. plur. of Ï†Ï…Î³á½µ, when it does not mean â€˜remediesâ€™ (364), usu. means â€˜exileâ€™ (Eur. El. 233). The gen. might be absol., but is more simply taken with á¼¤Î¼Ï€Î»Î±Îºâ€™.

Haemon, in his madness, meant to kill his father. He had harboured no such purpose before (see on 752); and his frantic impulse is instantly followed by violent remorse. Arist. ( Arist. Poet. 14) observes that it is not conducive to a properly tragic effect (Î¿á½ Ï„ÏÎ±Î³Î¹Îºá½¹Î½, á¼€Ï€Î±Î¸á½³Ï‚) if a person contemplates a dreadful act, and then desists from it, in the light of sober thought or fuller knowledge: Î´Î¹á½¹Ï€ÎµÏ Î¿á½Î´Îµá½¶Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿– á½Î¼Î¿á½·Ï‰Ï‚ Îµá¼° Î¼á½´ á½€Î»Î¹Î³á½±ÎºÎ¹Ï‚ (such incidents in Tragedy are rare), Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ á¼Î½ á¼ˆÎ½Ï„Î¹Î³á½¹Î½á¿ƒ ÎšÏá½³Î¿Î½Ï„Î± á½ Î‘á¼µÎ¼Ï‰Î½. It need not be assumed that Arist. meant to censure Sophocles; it is more natural to suppose that he cited the exception as one justified by the circumstances. But it should further be noticed that Aristotle was not accurate in taking this incident as the exception which illustrated his rule. For Haemon did not abandon his dreadful purpose; he was simply foiled by his father's flight. And then, in swift remorse, he actually did Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼€Î½Î·Îºá½³ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½ Ï„Î¹.

Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï†Ï…Î³Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼¤Î¼Ï€Î»Î±Îºâ€™Â· Îµá¼¶Î¸â€™ á½ Î´á½»ÏƒÎ¼Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï‚

Î³á½¹Î¿Ï…Ï‚ â€¦ á¼€Î¾Î¹á½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½=to think them á¼„Î¾Î¹Î¿Î¹, i.e., meet. On the other hand, á¼„Î¾Î¹Î¿Ï‚, as applied to actions, oft.=â€˜proper,â€™ â€˜becomingâ€™: as Aristoph. Eq. 616 Î½á¿¦Î½ á¼„Ïâ€™ á¼„Î¾Î¹á½¹Î½ Î³Îµ Ï€á¾¶Ïƒá½·Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á¼Ï€Î¿Î»Î¿Î»á½»Î¾Î±Î¹. Line 1253

Îµá¼°Ïƒá½¹Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±, Î¼á½µ Ï„Î¹ â€¦ ÎºÎ±Î»á½»Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹, â€˜we shall know (about our fear) lest (Î¼á½µ) she is concealing,â€™ i.e., whether we are right in fearing that she conceals something. As Goodwin says (Moods and Tenses, Â§ 46, N. 5 a), this passage is one of the most favourable to the view that Î¼á½µ has an interrogative force, and yet here also Î¼á½´ ÎºÎ±Î»á½»Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹ plainly expresses a fear. The pres. indic. is used, because the fear is strictly present; there is no thought that the thing feared can possibly be prevented. Before assuming that Î¼á½µ could have the force of Îµá¼° Î¿á½ (â€˜whether notâ€™), we should require an example in which the clause with Î¼á½µ, after a verb like Î¿á¼¶Î´Î±, expressed something which is not feared (but hoped; or else regarded with neither fear nor hope). As if here we had, Îµá¼°Ïƒá½¹Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î± Î¼á½´ Î¶á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼”Ï„Î¹ Î¼á½³Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹. Cp. 278 n. The use of Î¼á½µ in direct question (O. C. 1502) is, of course, elliptical: e.g., Î¼á½´ Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹; comes from (Î´á½³Î´Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ±) Î¼á½´ Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹.

This ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚ is composed of four strophes and four antistrophes, which correspond as follows. (1) 1st strophe 1261â€”1269=1st antistr. 1284â€”1292. (2) 2nd str. 1271â€”1277 =2nd ant. 1294â€”1300. (3) 3rd str. 1306â€”1311=3rd ant. 1328â€”1333. (4) 4th str. 1317â€”1325=4th ant. 1339â€” 1347.

The lyric strophes and antistrophes are divided from each other by iambic trimeters, spoken by the Chorus or by the Messenger.â€”See Metrical Analysis.

á¼”Ï‡Ï‰ Î¼Î±Î¸á½¼Î½ = Î¼ÎµÎ¼á½±Î¸Î·ÎºÎ± (21 n.), though here with a slightly stronger emphasis than that of an ordinary perf.: â€˜I have fully learned.â€™â€”No change is required in 1273. Construe: á½ Î´á½² Î¸Îµá½¸Ï‚ á¼Î½ Ï„á¿· á¼Î¼á¿· Îºá½±Ïá¾³ á¼”Ï€Î±Î¹Ïƒá½³ Î¼Îµ, Î¼á½³Î³Î± Î²á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½. Three points claim notice. (1) The place of Î¼Îµ. This was possible, because Î¼á½³Î³Î± Î²á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚, without á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½, could have stood as an adverbial cognate acc.: hence á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ is rather a superfluity than a word for which the ear was waiting. Greek poetry (esp. lyric) often has bold arrangements of words: cp. 944, 960 (n.). (2) Î¼á½³Î³Î± Î²á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ = ÏƒÏ†á½¹Î´ÏÎ± Î²Î±Ïá½ºÏ‚ á½¤Î½. (3) á¼Î½ Î´â€™ á¼Î¼á¿· Îºá½±Ïá¾³ might have been followed by á¼Î½á½µÎ»Î±Ï„Î¿, or the like; but, á¼”Ï€Î±Î¹ÏƒÎµ being used, the enclitic Î¼Îµ was required to make it clear. The charge of redundancy would be just only if á¼Î¼á¿· were followed by á¼Î¼á½³.â€”For the image, cp. 1345: Aesch. Ag. 1175 Î´Î±á½·Î¼Ï‰Î½ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÎ²Î±Ïá½´Ï‚ á¼Î¼Ï€á½·Ï„Î½Ï‰Î½: and see O. T. 263n. Triclinius understood the blow on the head to mean a disordering of the intellect (á¼€Î½Ï„á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦, á¼Î¾á½³ÏƒÏ„Î·ÏƒÎµ Ï„á½°Ï‚ á¼Î¼á½°Ï‚ Ï†Ïá½³Î½Î±Ï‚). But it is simply a poetical picture of the fell swoop with which the god descended on his victim,â€”taking possession of him, and driving him astray. Perhaps á¼Î¼Î²Ïá½¹Î½Ï„Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚ helped to suggest the other view. For the form of the dat. Îºá½±Ïá¾³, cp. O. C. 564 n.

á¼Î½ Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎµÎ½, tmesis (420).

á¼€Î³Ïá½·Î±Î¹Ï‚ á½Î´Î¿á¿–Ï‚: cp. Pind. P. 2. 85á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï„Îµ Ï€Î±Ï„á½³Ï‰Î½ á½Î´Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÏƒÎºÎ¿Î»Î¹Î±á¿–Ï‚, in paths of guile.

Line 1275

Î»Î±ÎºÏ€á½±Ï„Î·Ï„Î¿Î½, proleptic (475). The form Î»Î±Î¾Ï€á½±Ï„Î·Ï„Î¿Î½, which Eustathius treats as the normal one (adding, á½… Ï„Î¹Î½ÎµÏ‚ ..Î´Î¹á½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Îº Î³Ïá½±Ï†Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½), is defended by Ellendt. He thinks that the Îº form came from correctors who supposed that Î¾Ï€ was an impossible combination for Attic Greek. We find, indeed, á¼‘Î¾Ï€Î·Ï‡Ï…ÏƒÏ„á½· Soph. fr. 938, and the â€˜Atticâ€™ forms á¼•Î¾Ï€Î¿Ï…Î½, á¼•Î¾ÎºÎ»Î¹Î½Î¿Î½, á¼‘Î¾Î¼á½³Î´Î¼Î¹Î½Î¿Î½ (O. T. 1137 n.). But, though Î»Î±Î¾Ï€á½±Ï„Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ may well have been admissible, it is evident that the Îº form would be recommended by ease of pronunciation. The compound occurs only here.

á¼€Î½Ï„Ïá½³Ï€Ï‰Î½, as though it were an altar, a statue, or a fair building. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 383, Eum. 539(quoted on 853 ff.).â€”For the apocopÃ¨ of á¼€Î½á½± in comp., cp. O. á½¡Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎµÎºÏ„Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚. Creon is actually touching (or helping to support) his son's corpse (1258 Î´Î¹á½° Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½, 1297 á¼”Ï‡Ï‰ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼Î½ Ï‡Îµá½·ÏÎµÏƒÏƒÎ¹Î½). Cp. Plat. Theaet. 197 B Î¿á½ Ï„Î¿á½·Î½Ï…Î½ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï†Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Ï„á¿· ÎºÎµÎºÏ„á¿†ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á½¸ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½. Line 1281

Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½. In order to form a judgment on this difficult verse, a careful scrutiny of Sophoclean usage is required. (1) The reading closest to the MSS. would be, Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ Î±á½–; Îºá½±ÎºÎ¹Î¿Î½ á¼¦ kakw=n e)/ti; This involves merely a change of punctuation, and of accent (á¼¦ for á¼¤). But it suggests these difficulties. (a) The interrogative á¼¦ occurs about 50 times in Soph. : and in every instance it is the first word of the interrogative clause. Only a vocative sometimes precedes it, as O. C. 1102 á½¦ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î½, á¼¦ Ï€á½±ÏÎµÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½; so ib. 863, Ph. 369.Eur. , indeed, does not always observe this rule: El. 967 Ï„á½· Î´á¿†Ï„Î± Î´Ïá¿¶Î¼ÎµÎ½; Î¼Î·Ï„á½³Ïâ€™ á¼¦ Ï†Î¿Î½Îµá½»ÏƒÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ½; In Eur. Hec. 1013 I should point thus, Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Î´á¿†Ï„Î±; Ï€á½³Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ á¼Î½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á¼¦ ÎºÏá½»ÏˆÎ±Ïƒâ€™ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚; (á¼¦ Valckenaer for á¼¢). But, if we read Îºá½±ÎºÎ¹Î¿Î½ á¼¦ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Î½ á¼”Ï„Î¹ here, it would be a solitary departure from the practice of Soph. , as seen in fifty other examples. (b) The formula Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹ (cp. on v. 20) occurs 21 times in Soph. (including Soph. Ph. 733, where the MSS. give Ï„á½· á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹ without Î´â€™) as a question complete in itself. But there is not one instance of Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ Î±á½–; which is, indeed, illsuited to the rhythm of the tragic senarius.

(2) Transposing Î±á½– and á¼¤, we could read, Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½; á¼¢ [or better, á¼¦] Îºá½±ÎºÎ¹Î¿Î½ Î±á½– ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Î½ á¼”Ï„Î¹; But: (a) if this had been the original order, it is most improbable that á¼¤ and Î±á½– would have changed places. The sense would have been perfectly clear, whereas with Î±á½–...á¼¤ (the order in the MSS.) it is obscure. (b) The prominent place of Î±á½– in the MSS. is confirmed by many like instances: e.g. 1172: O. C. 1500 Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î±á½– Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á½‘Î¼á¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼ Ï‡Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹ Ï‡Ï„á½»Ï€Î¿Ï‚; Ph. 1089Ï„á½·Ï€Ï„â€™ Î±á½– Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½¸ ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼†Î¼Î±Ï | á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹; ib. 1263 Ï„á½·Ï‚ Î±á½– Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼„Î½Ï„ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ Î¸á½¹ÏÏ…Î²Î¿Ï‚ á¼µÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î±Î¹ Î²Î¿á¿†Ï‚;

á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿–, said to the Messenger. It has been objected that, at such a time, Creon could not use those words except with reference to Haemon (as in 1266, 1340). From a modern literary point of view, the objection is just. But we should remember how very familiar á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿– actually was as a mode of address, whether by elders to juniors, or by masters to slaves. Here it is used, not as to a slave, but merely as to a younger man; there is in it a certain pathetic appeal for sympathy. (Cp. á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿–, á½¦ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î½, as said by the Messenger to Oed. in O. T. 1008, 1030.) Enger's conjecture, á½¢ Ï„á½·Î½â€™

Î±á½– (instead of á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿– Ï„á½·Î½Î±), has not much palaeographical probability. It gives, indeed, a closer correspondence with 1266. But the form of dochmiac which the MS. reading gives here is equally correct. (See Analysis. Met.) Seidler was certainly right in omitting Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ (see cr. n.): and that remedy suffices.

Construe: Ï„á½·Î½Î± Î½á½³Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ†á½±Î³Î¹Î¿Î½ Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–Î¿Î½ Î¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Î½ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±á½· Î¼Î¿Î¹ á¼Ï€â€™ á½€Î»á½³Î¸Ïá¿³, â€˜what new death,â€™â€”the bloody death of a woman,â€”dost thou describe as heaped on destruction (i.e., superadded to Haemon's death), for my sorrow (Î¼Î¿Î¹)?' (Cp. 595 Ï€á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± Ï†Î¸Î¹Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€á½µÎ¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€á½·Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½Ï„â€™.) Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–Î¿Î½ = Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá½¹Ï‚: cp. Aesch. Pers. 8 Î½á½¹ÏƒÏ„á¿³ Ï„á¿· Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»Îµá½·á¿³.â€”The notion expressed by á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ á¼Ï€â€™ á½€Î»á½³Î¸Ïá¿³ seems to be, strictly, that of death entwined with death, like corpse embracing corpse (1240). The verb á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ prop.=â€˜to be set aroundâ€™ (as a wall round a city). Perhaps the bold phrase here was partly prompted by the fact that persons embracing each other could be described (O. C. 1620 n.) as á¼Ï€â€™ á¼€Î»Î»á½µÎ»Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÎºÎµá½·Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹. I prefer this view.

But another version is possible, if Î¼Î¿Î¹ is taken with á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹: â€˜besetting me,â€™ á¼Ï€â€™ á½€Î»á½³Î¸Ïá¿³, for (my) ruin. Cp. 1285 Ï„á½· Î¼â€™ á½€Î»á½³ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚; For á¼Ï€á½·, cp. Thuc. 4.86 Î¿á½Îº á¼Ï€á½¶ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿·, á¼Ï€â€™ á¼Î»ÎµÏ…Î¸ÎµÏá½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹ Î´á½³. The difficulty is that á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ cannot well be said of one sorrow (EurydicÃ¨'s death), and that, therefore, we have to evolve from the epithet Î½á½³Î¿Î½ the notion of a circle of woes of which this Î¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚ is one. Thus the image would be much more obscurely expressed than that in Ai. 351, á¼´Î´ÎµÏƒÎ¸á½³ Î¼â€™ Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ á¼„ÏÏ„Î¹ Îºá¿¦Î¼Î± Ï†Î¿Î¹Î½á½·Î±Ï‚ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Î¶á½±Î»Î·Ï‚ | á¼€Î¼Ï†á½·Î´ÏÎ¿Î¼Î¿Î½ ÎºÏ…ÎºÎ»Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹, (â€˜behold what a surge hath but now burst around me and hemmed me in, under stress of a deadly storm,â€™) where Ajax is sitting in the midst of the carnage which he has wrought. It is altogether improbable that á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ alludes to EurydicÃ¨'s corpse having been brought (by the á¼ÎºÎºá½»ÎºÎ»Î·Î¼Î±) into such a position that Creon stood between it and Haemon's. See 1298, where Creon speaks of her as being á¼”Î½Î±Î½Ï„Î±.

1290 Î±á¼°Î±á¿– Î±á¼°Î±á¿–,
ÏƒÏ†á½±Î³Î¹Î¿Î½ á¼Ï€â€™ á½€Î»á½³Î¸Ïá¿³
Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–Î¿Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹ÎºÎµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Î½;
Î§Î¿. á½Ïá¾¶Î½ Ï€á½±ÏÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½Â· Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï á¼Î½ Î¼Ï…Ï‡Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼”Ï„Î¹.
ÎšÏ. Î¿á¼´Î¼Î¿Î¹, ğŸ—©
Line 1294

á½Ïá¾¶Î½ Ï€á½±ÏÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½. The corpse of EurydicÃ¨, and probably also the altar at which she fell (1301), are now shown to the spectators by means of the á¼ÎºÎºá½»ÎºÎ»Î·Î¼Î±. The precise mechanism of this contrivance is unknown; but the texts leave no doubt as to its general nature. It was a small stage, with space enough for

three or four persons; and was low enough to admit of an actor stepping off it with ease. It was pushed on through the central stage entrance, and was usually brought sufficiently far forward to allow of actors entering or making their exit behind it. Here, the corpse of EurydicÃ¨ is evidently in full view of the house (cp. 1299). Soph. has used the á¼ÎºÎºá½»ÎºÎ»Î·Î¼Î± in two other plays: El. 1458 (the corpse of Clytaemnestra, with Orestes and Pylades beside it); and in Ai. 344 (Ajax in his tent among his victims). See Albert MÃ¼ller, Gr. BÃ¼hnenalterthÃ¼mer, pp. 142 ff. (1886).

Recent explorations in the Dionysiac theatre at Athens have given rise to a theory that there was no permanent raised stage or proscenium before the Roman age. Even if this could be proved, it would still, however, remain certain that some such expedient as the á¼ÎºÎºá½»ÎºÎ»Î·Î¼Î± was used in the fifth century. This is proved by the texts of Aesch. , Soph. , and Eur. , as well as by the two scenes of Ar. where the tragic á¼ÎºÎºá½»ÎºÎ»Î·Î¼Î± is parodied ( Ar. Ach. 408â€”479; Thesm. 95â€”238). Ar. has the words á¼ÎºÎºÏ…ÎºÎ»Îµá¿–Î½ and á¼ÏƒÎºÏ…ÎºÎ»Îµá¿–Î½. Wecklein thinks that the á¼ÎºÎºá½»ÎºÎ»Î·Î¼Î± was employed when a part of the interior of the house was to be disclosed, but the á¼Î¾á½½ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ± when merely a single object was to be shown; and that the á¼Î¾á½½ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ± was used here (N. Jahrb. 1870, vol. 101, p. 572: Philol. 31. 451). The meaning of á¼Î¾á½½ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ± is, however, doubtful.

á¼¥Î´â€™: he indicates the dead body of EurydicÃ¨, now made visible by the á¼ÎºÎºá½»ÎºÎ»Î·Î¼Î±.â€”Arndt's first emendation is given in the text. His later substitution of Ï€Ï„á½½ÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ for Î²Ï‰Î¼á½·Î± was not an instance of second thoughts being wiser. The altar meant is that of Î–Îµá½ºÏ‚ á¼™ÏÎºÎµá¿–Î¿Ï‚ in the Î±á½Î»á½µ of the house (487). The objection made to Î²Ï‰Î¼á½·Î± here is to the effect that one could say Î²á½½Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚ á¼Ï†á½³Î¶ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ or á¼µÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î±Î¹, but not Î²á½½Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿– Ï„Î¹: i.e. that the verb must refer directly to the assuming of the position denoted by Î²á½½Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï‚. It is quite true that this is usually the case; Eur. Suppl. 93 Î²Ï‰Î¼á½·Î±Î½ á¼Ï†Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î·Î½: O. T. 32 á¼‘Î¶á½¹Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¸â€™ á¼Ï†á½³ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î¿Î¹: and cp. above, 785 f. But here Î²Ï‰Î¼á½·Î± is not merely an adverbial word, to be taken closely with Î»á½»ÎµÎ¹. It is rather an instance of an adj. used with the force of a participle, and virtually equivalent to Î²Ï‰Î¼á½·Î± ÏƒÏ„á¾¶ÏƒÎ±: i.e. it means, â€˜having taken her place at the altar,â€™ she slew herself. Cp. O. C. 83 á½¡Ï‚ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Î¼á½¹Î½Î·Ï‚ Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚ (sc. Î¿á½”ÏƒÎ·Ï‚): and see above on 471. Further: even if it were necessary to bind Î²Ï‰Î¼á½·Î± closely with Î»á½»ÎµÎ¹, it would be bold to say that poetry could not permit this slight modification in the ordinary use of the word, when we remember how free was the adverbial use of adjectives in poetry (e.g., Ai. 217 Î½á½»ÎºÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ»Ï‰Î²á½µÎ¸Î·).

Î¾á½·Ï†ÎµÎ¹. A sacrificial knife, which lay on the altar. Cp. Eur. Alc. 74 (Death speaks) ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Ï‡Ï‰ Î´â€™ á¼Ï€â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½µÎ½, á½¡Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±ÏÎ¾Ï‰Î¼Î±Î¹ Î¾á½·Ï†ÎµÎ¹. For the prep. cp. Ai. 828 Ï€ÎµÏ€Ï„á¿¶Ï„Î± Ï„á¿·Î´Îµ Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Î½ÎµÎ¿ÏÏá½±Î½Ï„á¿³ Î¾á½·Ï†ÎµÎ¹.

Î»á½»ÎµÎ¹ ÎºÎµÎ»Î±Î¹Î½á½° Î²Î»á½³Ï†Î±ÏÎ±, allows her eyes to close in darkness. Î»á½»ÎµÎ¹=relaxes: the eyelids are deprived of power to remain open. The phrase has been suggested by the epic Î»á¿¦ÏƒÎµ Î´á½² Î³Ï…á¿–Î±, Î»á½³Î»Ï…Î½Ï„Î¿ Î´á½² Î³Ï…á¿–Î±, etc., and seems quite intelligible; though, doubtless, it would have been more natural to say ÎºÎ»á¿„ÎµÎ¹, as Soph. has done in fr. 640, Î²Î»á½³Ï†Î±ÏÎ± Îºá½³ÎºÎ»á¿ƒÏ„Î±Î¹. In [Eur.] Rhes. 8 we have Î»á¿¦ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Î²Î»ÎµÏ†á½±ÏÏ‰Î½ Î³Î¿ÏÎ³Ï‰Ï€á½¸Î½ á¼”Î´ÏÎ±Î½, of opening the eyes; but that has no bearing on the different use here. Wolff brings what at first sight is a perfect parallel: Anthol. P. 3. 11 á¼„Î½Î¸â€™ á½§Î½ á½„Î¼Î¼Î±Ï„â€™ á¼”Î»Ï…ÏƒÎµ Ï„á½° Î“Î¿ÏÎ³á½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î½Î¸á½±Î´Îµ Î ÎµÏÏƒÎµá½»Ï‚. But unfortunately neither he nor Bellermann has observed the meaning. It is not, â€˜caused the Gorgon 's eyes to close,â€™ but â€˜uncovered the Gorgon 's head.â€™ The epigram refers to Perseus bringing Medusa's head to Seriphos, and therewith petrifying Polydectes, who had married DanaÃ«, and sent her son on his perilous mission.â€”The objection to Î¼á½»ÎµÎ¹ is that elsewhere the verb has these usages:â€”(1) intrans.,â€”á½„Î¼Î¼Î±Ï„Î± Î¼á½»ÎµÎ¹, the eyes close, or Î¼á½»Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½, we shut our eyes. (2) trans., as Anth. P. 9. 558 á½•Ï€Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Î¼Ï…ÏƒÎµ Îºá½¹ÏÎ±Ï‚ (with the post-classical Ï…â€”), â€˜caused to close.â€™ That is, there is no classical example of such a phrase as Î¼á½»ÎµÎ¹ á½€Ï†Î¸Î±Î»Î¼Î¿á½»Ï‚, she shuts her eyes.

Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ÎœÎµÎ³Î±Ïá½³Ï‰Ï‚ ÎºÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Î½ Î»á½±Ï‡Î¿Ï‚, ğŸ—©
Line 1303

ÎœÎµÎ³Î±Ïá½³Ï‰Ï‚. Cp. Aesch. Theb. 474 ÎœÎµÎ³Î±ÏÎµá½»Ï‚, ÎšÏá½³Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ÏƒÏ€á½³ÏÎ¼Î±, Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÏƒÏ€Î±ÏÏ„á¿¶Î½ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚, where he is one of the Theban warriors who guard the gates: his patriotic death is foreshadowed ib. 477 Î¸Î±Î½á½¼Î½ Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†Îµá¿–Î± Ï€Î»Î·Ïá½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹ Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½·. The story is thus told by Eur. ( Eur. Phoen. 930â€”1018), who calls him Menoeceus. While the Argives are pressing Thebes, Creon and Eteocles send for Teiresias. The seer says that Ares is wroth, because Cadmus of old slew the god's offspring, a dragon (or serpent?) which had its lair outside the walls. One of the Cadmean race, sprung from the dragon's teeth, must die to appease him. Now, Creon and his two sons are the only pure-bred ÏƒÏ€Î±ÏÏ„Î¿á½· left. And Haemon is married. The seer therefore suggests that Menoeceus should die. Menoeceus pretends that he means to fly to Delphi. Creon leaves the scene, in order to provide him with money for the journey. Menoeceus then rushes to the top of a tower on the walls, where he cuts his throat, and falls into the dragon's former den (ÏƒÎ·Îºá½¸Î½ á¼Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î±Î¼Î²Î±Î¸á¿† | Î´Ïá½±ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚, Ph. 1010, see n. above on 411). Statius, who also calls him Menoeceus, tells the story in Theb. 10. 589â€”782, and, like Eur. , makes the son practise a pious fraud in order to hinder his father from preventing the sacrifice.

ÎºÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Î½ Î»á½±Ï‡Î¿Ï‚: cp. Eur. Î¼á½¹ÏÏ‰Î½ á½ Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½. I have adopted á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½, a conjecture of Pallis for á¼Î¼á¿¶Î½, on the following grounds. Hence it has been proposed to render Î¼á½¹ÏÏ‰Î½ á¼Î¼á¿¶Î½ here, (a) â€˜the deaths caused by meâ€™: as Hermann, â€˜veniat caedium per me factarum suprema, exoptatissime mihi ultimum diem adducens.â€™ (b) Figuratively, â€˜the many deaths that I have diedâ€™; cp. 1288 á½€Î»Ï‰Î»á½¹Ï„â€™ á¼„Î½Î´Ïâ€™ á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¾ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³á½±ÏƒÏ‰. But neither version is tolerable. (2) Triclinius proposed to make á¼Î¼á¿¶Î½ fem., and to take it with Ï„ÎµÏÎ¼á½·Î±Î½: when it would at least be necessary to write á¼Î¼á¾¶Î½ (sc. á¼Î¼ÎµÏá¾¶Î½). But, either with á¼Î¼á¿¶Î½ or with á¼Î¼á¾¶Î½, the relation of á½ Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„â€™ ...á¼„Î³Ï‰Î½ to the gen. Î¼á½¹ÏÏ‰Î½ is exceedingly awkward. â€˜That one among fates which best brings my last day,â€™ cannot be explained as an equivalent for, â€˜that best of fates which brings itâ€™; i.e., for Î¼á½¹ÏÏ‰Î½ á½ Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚, á½...á¼„Î³Ï‰Î½.

Both these difficulties (which to me seem insuperable) are removed by reading Î¼á½¹ÏÏ‰Î½ á½ Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½, the best of fates. That á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ could have been changed to á¼Î¼á¿¶Î½, either by conjecture or by accident, is shown by v. 575, where at the end of the verse L has the probably true á¼Î¼Î¿á½·, while other MSS. have á¼”Ï†Ï…. (If Îºá½»Î½ÎµÏ‚ is right in 467, and Î¾á½·Ï†ÎµÎ¹ in 1301, these, too, are instances of final words corrupted.) A question of punctuation remains. The comma might follow either á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ or á¼Î¼Î¿á½·. á½•Ï€Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚, an emphatic repetition of á½ Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½,â€”â€˜supreme of fates,â€™â€” far best. Thus in an epitaph on an Italian, a certain Aelius, Apollonides writes (Anthol. Nor does it seem in harmony with the pervading spirit of the poet's work. Rather Creon is exhorted to recognise, with pious resignation, the fixity of the divine decrees. Cp. the closing words of the Oed. Col., á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï€Î±á½»ÎµÏ„Îµ Î¼Î·Î´â€™ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€Î»Îµá½·Ï‰ | Î¸Ïá¿†Î½Î¿Î½ á¼Î³Îµá½·ÏÎµÏ„ÎµÂ· | Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ Ï„á½±Î´Îµ Îºá¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚. ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÎºÎ±Î½Î¿Î½ is the best, as it is the simplest, emendation of ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÎºÏ„Î±Î½Î¿Î½ (see cr. n.). Though the pres. ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÎºÎ±á½·Î½Ï‰ is not classical, the aor. is frequent; Xen. uses it ( Xen. An. 3. 1. 2, etc.).

Ïƒá½³ Ï„â€™ Î±á½– Ï„á½±Î½Î´â€™ is a certain correction of Ïƒá½³ Ï„â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½±Î½. Here the latter would be like saying, â€˜and actually thee,â€™â€”as if the slaying of Haemon had been comparatively venial. It cannot be naturally explained as meaning, â€˜the mother with the son.â€™

Ïƒá½³ Ï„â€™ Î±á½– Ï„á½±Î½Î´â€™, á½¤Î¼Î¿Î¹ Î¼á½³Î»ÎµÎ¿Ï‚, Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰
á½…Ï€á¾³ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ± ÎºÎ»Î¹Î¸á¿¶Â· Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Î³á½°Ï ğŸ—©
Line 1342

Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï€á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ â€¦ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Î³á½±Ï. The reading of this verse cannot be certainly determined. The traditional text (see cr. n.) exceeds the metre. My own view is as follows:

(1) The MS. á½…Ï€á¾³ should be struck out. It evidently came in from the margin, having been a gloss on Ï€á¾·, meant to show that Ï€á¾· ÎºÎ»Î¹Î¸á¿¶ is not a direct question, but depends on Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰. Retaining á½…Ï€á¾³, we should have to suppose a double question: â€˜nor do I know in what direction, (or) to which thing, I am to look.â€™ This is not only very awkward, but very weak. The hiatus after á¼”Ï‡Ï‰, though not unexampled, is at least another point against á½…Ï€á¾³.

(2) L has Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Î³á½±Ï in a line by itself: but, considering the caprices of lyric division in that MS. (as in the rest), we cannot urge that fact as a hint of interpolation. If á½…Ï€á¾³ was a spurious addition to 1342, then Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Î³á½±Ï might easily have been carried over. Again, the words Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Î³á½±Ï are not indispensable; yet the effect of Î»á½³Ï‡ÏÎ¹Î± Ï„á¼€Î½ Ï‡ÎµÏÎ¿á¿–Î½, without them, would be rather oddly abrupt. Therefore we are by no means warranted (I think) in ejecting Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Î³á½±Ï.
